## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#what-is-kali) What is KALI?

KALI is an application to simplify DAO and legal structuring. It includes end-to-end tokenization, voting, and legal support such as LLC formation and agreement drafting software.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#what-is-a-dao) What is a DAO?

A DAO is like a shared bank account, but operated by code or ‚Äúsmart contracts‚Äù.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#what-is-a-smart-contract) What is a Smart Contract?

A smart contract is code on a blockchain that will run exactly as programmed. They can manage assets without inference and for DAOs, enforce proposals, such as membership and payments. Smart contracts deployed on KALI will survive the platform, don‚Äôt depend on KALI developers, and will persist as long as blockchains run. Smart contracts therefore give KALI users true ownership of their organizations.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#why-do-daos-need-legal-structure) Why do DAOs need Legal Structure?

DAOs are managed by people, and as they typically involve the pooling and use of assets, can create traditional legal liabilities for all involved parties. Without a formal legal structure, jurisdictions may treat DAOs as unincorporated general partnerships, giving members joint and several liability for claims made against the DAO. This effectively means that a single member could be held responsible for the entire sum of damages in the event of unfavourable litigation. Limiting the liability of DAOs through light-weight legal structures has therefore been seen as a common sense solution to scale and operate with ‚ÄúIRL‚Äù concerns, such as hiring and making investments.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#how-does-kali-provide-legal-support) How does KALI provide Legal Support?

KALI allows users to immediately wrap their DAO in a Delaware LLC, as a ‚Äúchild‚Äù of the [KaliCo Ricardian Series LLCopen in new window](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/#kalico-ricardian-llc). Effectively, each DAO will have its own rights and liability protection, separate and apart from each other, enforced by Delaware law and under the terms of the [LLC master operating agreementopen in new window](https://gateway.pinata.cloud/ipfs/QmdHFNxtecmCNcTscWJqnA4AiASyk3SHCgKamugLHqR23i).

Additionally, KALI integrates with a community of legal and knowledge service providers, [LexDAOopen in new window](https://www.lexdao.coop/#/directory), and can assist with formation and compliance through its contact form and referral network.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#what-should-i-be-thinking-about-when-i-create-a-dao) What should I be thinking about when I create a DAO?

The more consideration as to the needs and structure of your DAO at the start, the fewer changes may be required in the future through proposals (which will reduce gas fees and decision friction).

The most important considerations to make (other than, of course, your DAO name and symbol) are:

- Who are the founders?;
- What are their fair token allocations?;
- What voting procedures should the DAO operate by?; and
- Do you want to establish your DAO with a legal wrapper? _KALI and LexDAO recommend that you discuss this decision with a legal and tax expert prior to establishing your DAO_.

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#how-do-i-create-my-dao) How do I create my DAO?

### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#select-a-chain) Select a chain

Different networks may provide security, speed, and fee advantages. Kali DAOs are currently deployable on:

- Ethereum Mainnet
- Arbitrum One
- Rinkeby (Testnet)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152905615-fb491efc-55b9-4f4c-8cdf-322b6fbb2593.png)

### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#identify-your-org) Identify your Org

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152905714-5ca81ac6-15de-4ae4-a075-04cfcf2f1347.png)

### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#select-a-template) Select a template

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152905834-aff8cc20-c6b8-430f-94fe-9839696a4131.png)

A DAO established for social purposes - anyone can join by paying the established tribute, and a smaller quorum is required to pass proposals to keep things moving and fun!

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#investment-club) Investment Club

A DAO established for collective investing (including ERC-721 and ERC-1155 NFTs) - upon summoning, the DAO will immediately commence a 30 day ETH crowdsale at a price of 10 shares per ETH.

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#company) Company

A DAO established for providing services and receiving on-chain payments. Smaller quorum required to pass proposals and a shortened voting period emphasizes speedier operations.

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#customize-your-governance) Customize your governance

Establishing a custom DAO allows the organizer to determine the required Voting Period, Quorum, Supermajority, and Share Transferability.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152906785-99011ee4-57f4-41be-9617-3cf2daaef41f.png)

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#voting-period) Voting Period

How much time a proposal can be voted on by members before being ratified or rejected by the DAO.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#quorum) Quorum

What percentage of DAO tokens (out of total outstanding) need to participate in a given proposal in order for it to be passed. Proposals that don‚Äôt achieve a minimum quorum will fail, even if the final vote is in favour of the proposal.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#supermajority) Supermajority

What percentage of DAO tokens (out of total outstanding) need to vote in favour of a proposal in order for it to be approved prior to the end of the voting period.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#share-transferability) Share Transferability

Determines whether DAO tokens are transferable by their holders without approval by the DAO. If shares are Transferable then DAO token holders will be able to send those token freely to other addresses. If non-transferable, then the tokens will be locked to the original founder addresses (or subsequent holders) and will not be transferaable until a proposal making such a change is approved.

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#extensions) Extensions

Kali DAOs can add applications to help automate certain membership and business functions.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#redemption) Redemption

Allows DAO members to burn or 'ragequit' their DAO tokens for a proportionate share of DAO treasury assets.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#crowdsale) Crowdsale

Allows the DAO to fundraise for a set period where the public can exchange assets for DAO tokens.

##### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#tribute) Tribute

Allows DAO candidates to bid on DAO tokens by making a proposal with an escrowed deposit.

Please note _all of the above decisions may impact the legal status and standing of your DAO. Please consult a lawyer in your jurisdiction prior to determining the features of your DAO._

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#build-your-cap-table) Build your cap table

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152907382-4dc7b408-7ac5-4bf9-9dec-a5f3954514ec.png)

Enter the Founder‚Äôs Ethereum addresses and the number of DAO Tokens to be assigned to them upon deployment.

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#add-legal-docs) Add legal docs

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152907663-b71ec113-386e-43eb-b20d-a4c633b12498.png)

Select which legal structure you would like to summon for the DAO.

#### [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#confirm-deployment) Confirm Deployment

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92001561/152907776-5a288f61-e8a7-4180-9357-8846cf751e01.png)

## [\#](https://docs.kalidao.xyz/faq/\#limitations-on-legal-advice) Limitations on Legal Advice

The content of this website has been prepared for informational purposes only and does not constitute legal advice. The information on this website shall not be construed as an offer to represent you, nor is it intended to create, nor shall the receipt of such information constitute, an attorney-client relationship. We hope that you will find the information informative and useful, and we would be delighted to speak with you to answer any questions you may have.

_Kali core contributors include Shivanshi Tyagi, Jordan Teague, Ross Campbell and Stamford Hwang. It is supported by the friendly shadowy super lawyers at [LexDAOopen in new window](https://www.lexdao.coop/)._

results.content:
## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#article-i-overview)    Article I ‚Äì Overview

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-i-declaration)    Section I - Declaration

We hereby declare MetricsDAO.

A DAO for data providers.

A DAO for analysts.

A DAO for the data curious.

A DAO for education.

A DAO for growth.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-ii-metricsdao-values)    **Section II - MetricsDAO values**

MetricsDAO contributors pledge to uphold the foundational values of the DAO:

- Collaboration

- Curiosity

- Integrity

- Inclusiveness

- Scientific rigor

- Transparency


### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-iii-goal)    **Section III - Goal**

The goal of this constitution is to codify the governing principles of the DAO.

These principles are designed to cultivate social coordination, achievement, education, and growth through maximally efficient & fluid foundations of governance.

Humans will run the DAO, in service to the system.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-iv-tooling-and-processes)    **Section IV - Tooling and Processes**

#### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#pods)    Pods

Each distinct social or business unit in the DAO will be designated a Pod.

Each pod has a leader and contributors. Contributors are highly skilled, dedicated members of the DAO. Leaders are full-time managers of their pod.

All pods in aggregate make up the DAO.

#### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#badges)    **Badges**

Badges are assigned by DAO administrators to manage roles in the DAO. There are currently three kinds of badges: Contributor, Governor, and Curator.

For more information on MetricsDAO tooling and processes, please view thispage: [https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/metricsdao/tooling-and-processes](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/metricsdao/tooling-and-processes)

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-v-constituents-and-bodies)    **Section V - Constituents & Bodies**

Constituents & Bodies of the DAO are defined as, but not limited to:

- **Contributors** \- Members of one or more pods, providing time & effort in exchange for reward & recognition.

- **Governors**\- Elected leaders of their respective pods, responsible for day-to-day operations of the DAO.

- **Governing Council (Gov Co)**\- Comprised of all elected Governors, serves as the ratifying body of the DAO. Members are on and off-boarded following seasonal elections.

- **Genesis Council (Gen Co)**\- The founding members of the DAO, serve an advisory role and retain voting power. This group is made up of nine individuals and is expected to remain static.


### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-vi-seasons)    **Section VI - Seasons**

The DAO will operate on fiscal quarters known as Seasons.

Following each season, there will be a two week off-season period where the DAO members and administration can reflect and implement any changes needed.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-vii-amendments-to-the-constitution)    **Section VII - Amendments to the constitution**

This constitution is designed to be a living, breathing document.

Proposed changes to the constitution can be submitted by and voted on by DAO members who hold the Governor badge.

Votes to amend the constitution will be structured with the 1wins51 method:

1 vote per member - simple majority wins - 51% quorum

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#article-ii-operations)    **Article II - Operations**

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-i-voting)    **Section I - Voting**

#### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#voting-eligibility)    **Voting Eligibility**

To be eligible to vote, electors must hold the contributor badge for the current season.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-ii-proposals)    **Section II - Proposals**

Any DAO member who holds the contributor badge can post a proposal to the forum, which will start a 48 hour period for feedback.

After 48 hours, if there is no feedback that would stop the proposal, a poll is posted on Snapshot for all eligible pod contributors to vote on. This poll will be up for 48 hours and operates in an optimistic manner - proposals are assumed to pass unless 25% of the contributor base votes no OR 25% of the Governing Council votes no. ‚ÄòNo‚Äô votes are required to come with a written dissent, explaining the vote.

If the proposal is vetoed, the author is given a chance to edit the proposal based on the dissenting opinion(s) and post it back to the forum, entering another 48 hour period for feedback.

If it passes, the proposal will move to the Governing Council for ratification.

The Governing Council will then have 48 hours to vote.

If a DAO member holds the governor badge in addition to the contributor badge, they must also post a proposal on the forum for feedback, but can bypass the Snapshot poll as long as there is no opposition on the forum. These proposals will be sent directly from the forum to the Governance Council to ratify and vote on. This allows proposals that facilitate routine procedures such as contributor payments to be streamlined through the governance process.

Governing Council votes will use 1wins51:
1 vote per member - simple majority wins - 51% quorum

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-iii-special-circumstances)    **Section III - Special Circumstances**

DAO Members can be offboarded from the DAO through a two part system. If three contributors file a complaint about a member, the issue will be brought up to the Governing Council which will then examine the case and vote on whether to retain the contributor or begin the offboarding process. If complaints come from members of the Governing Council, these members will recuse themselves from the examination and voting process.

If a leadership or contributor position needs to be filled mid-season, the Governing Council will appoint a member to the position with the input of contributors. This intermediary will only be assigned the position till the end of the season, at which point the position will be filled through normal processes.

All votes settled by 1wins51

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#section-iv-submitting-amendments-to-the-constitution)    **Section IV - Submitting Amendments to the constitution**

Any DAO member who holds the Governor badge can post an amendment proposal to the forum, which will start a 5 day period for feedback.

The Genesis Council will hold a poll for each draft amendment, with polling conducted during the following off-season.

If contradictory amendments exist for a given Section, only one can be implemented for the upcoming Season.

Polls will be open for 48 hours, 1wins51.

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#amendments)    Amendments

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/constitution\#amendment-i-incorporation-and-bylaws)    Amendment I - Incorporation and Bylaws

In July of 2022, MetricsDAO was formally incorporated as MetricsDAO Assoc, a non-stock, non-profit Delaware corporation. As part of the incorporation process, MetricsDAO voted to ratify a set of bylaws that formally outline the purpose of MetricsDAO, requirements for membership, and responsibilities of members and designated leaders within the organization.

In addition to ratifying the bylaws, MetricsDAO appointed Daphne Kwon to be designated as the first signatory on behalf of MetricsDAO. This signatory has the authority to sign contracts and other legally binding documents on behalf of MetricsDAO. The signatory is not a permanent position and may be replaced by the DAO following a proposal put forward and voted on by members of the Governing Council.

The full bylaws can be viewed here: [MetricsDAO Bylaws](https://drive.google.com/file/d/1LItjh_igK1KMMcx4L35RKuaQ7eh23x99/view)

[PreviousNetwork List](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/networks/network-list) [NextTeam Structure](https://docs.metricsdao.xyz/operations/team-structure)

Last updated 3 years ago

Was this helpful?

# [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/how-it-works.html\#how-octant-works) How Octant works

This article describes Octant's rationale and mechanics, if you want to know how to use the app, clik [here](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/using-the-app.html).

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/how-it-works.html\#overview-and-rationale) Overview and rationale

With the [Ethereum switch from Proof-of-Work to Proof-of-Stake(opens new window)](https://ethereum.org/en/upgrades/merge/) consensus mechanism, the [Golem Foundation(opens new window)](https://golem.foundation/), which is developing Octant, has decided to become a [validator in the network(opens new window)](https://ethereum.org/en/developers/docs/consensus-mechanisms/pos/#validators). The Foundation has staked 100,000 ETH to secure the network and assist in reaching consensus.

In exchange for staking its Ether and serving as a validator, the Foundation receives a steady stream of [rewards directly from the protocol(opens new window)](https://etherscan.io/address/0xba1951dF0C0A52af23857c5ab48B4C43A57E7ed1). A portion of these staking rewards is transferred to the Octant community every 90 days. Community members then decide, through individual actions and polls, how to allocate these funds. They can choose to either claim a portion of the reward for themselves or donate it to qualifying public goods causes.

Through this initiative, the Golem Foundation aims to gather empirical evidence on user participation in decentralized governance. This information will guide [our search for effective decentralized governance solutions(opens new window)](https://golem.foundation/2021/12/16/udo1.html) and further the development of the [User-Defined Organization(opens new window)](https://golem.foundation/2021/12/16/udo2.html) project.

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/how-it-works.html\#the-distribution-of-the-golem-foundation-s-staking-yield) The distribution of the Golem Foundation's staking yield

Initially, the transfer of staking rewards from the Golem Foundation to Octant depended on [the percentage of the total GLM supply locked by Octant users(opens new window)](https://octantapp.notion.site/Octant-a-GLM-Governance-Experiment-e098d7ff9d55468db28b8b3584b5959c) ‚Äî the more GLM locked in the Octant contract, the greater the portion of the Foundation‚Äôs staking rewards directed to the Octant community. However, [in Epoch Three, we shifted to a predetermined split(opens new window)](https://blog.octant.build/octants-algorithm-overhaul/):

- 70% of the staking yield contributes to Octant's Total Rewards budget, split evenly between User Rewards and Matched Rewards.
- 25% of the staking yield goes to the Golem Foundation, helping cover expenses like validator management, Octant administration, development, marketing, and other initiatives.
- 5% of the staking yield bolsters the Octant Community Fund.

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/how-it-works.html\#governance-over-octant-s-total-rewards-budget) Governance over Octant's Total Rewards Budget

Anyone holding [GLM tokens(opens new window)](https://octant.build/glm-token/) (the ERC-20 token native to the [Golem Network(opens new window)](https://golem.network/)) can become part of the Octant community by [locking a certain minimum amount of their tokens in the Octant contract](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/glm-locking.html). It's possible to lock as little as 1 GLM, but a minimum effective balance of 100 GLM is required to qualify for user rewards.

The GLM-locking mechanism is non-custodial. Tokens locked by users aren't pooled with others' funds. Users maintain full control over their funds and can unlock their GLM at any time.

Governance of the Total Rewards budget occurs through a cyclical process known as 'epochs,' each spanning 90 days, although this duration is subject to potential adjustments.

Each epoch starts with the Octant community selecting eligible public goods projects for funding. (Details on eligibility and how to submit a project are in the [Propose a project](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html) section.)

During an epoch, users with at least 100 GLM in effective locked balance earn ETH rewards. The distribution of rewards is linear: the percentage of the total GLM supply a user locks in Octant corresponds directly to their percentage of User Rewards.

User Rewards for GLM lockers are further enhanced by the Participation Promotion Fund (PPF), [introduced in Epoch 3(opens new window)](https://blog.octant.build/octants-algorithm-overhaul/). Half of the PPF boosts ETH rewards, with the rest earmarked for a special GLM incentive. (This fund will provide incremental boosts to User Rewards and will decrease periodically as more GLM is locked, phasing out completely at a 35% lock-in rate.)

User Rewards are determined by a time-weighted average: the more GLM locked and the longer it remains, the greater the User Reward. Users can adjust their lock amount during an epoch; however, reducing a lock recalibrates the time-weighted average to the smallest amount locked.

An epoch is followed by a two-week allocation window, during which users can:

- Claim the rewards for themselves,
- Donate all or a portion to any of the shortlisted public goods projects,
- Allocate them to the Octant Matching Fund via [Patron mode](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/using-the-app.html#patron-mode).

Donations from User Rewards to projects are potentially increased by Octant's Matched Rewards, calculated using a [quadratic funding formula](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/quadratic-funding.html). This formula considers both the number of unique contributors and the amount donated, giving more weight to projects with broad community support.

The matching multiplier for each donation depends on [the user's Passport XYZ score](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/quadratic-funding.html#verifying-uniqueness). Users with a score of 15 or higher receive the maximum matching multiplier, while those with lower scores have their donations scaled down as an anti-Sybil measure.

To ensure a balanced distribution of funds, a maximum funding cap is set at 20% of the total Matched Rewards fund (including funds from Patron mode). Users can still donate to projects that have reached this cap, but these donations will not receive additional matching from the Matched Rewards pool.

Post-allocation window:

- Users opting to claim rewards can transfer ETH to their wallets.
- Projects can withdraw community donations.
- Rewards not claimed or allocated, are returned to the Golem Foundation.

For insights into the Octant App‚Äôs functionality and how to participate, consult the [Using the App](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/using-the-app.html) section.

For a detailed explanation of reward and matched fund calculations, refer to Octant‚Äôs [Technical Outline](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/technical-outline.html).

‚Üê
[Introduction](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/)[Using the app](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/using-the-app.html)
‚Üí

# [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#propose-a-project) Propose a project

Octant is a community-driven platform for experiments in decentralized governance. During its MVP stage we will be using Octant to test various hypotheses related to sustainable financing of public goods and infrastructure. For every 90-day epoch, a range of public good projects will be chosen as potential donation recipients.

[Golem Foundation(opens new window)](https://golem.foundation/) will be maintaining and curating the list of projects eligible to receive funds from the Octant reward pool, based on inputs from the Octant community.

‚ö†Ô∏è To be considered for inclusion, potential donation recipients should meet the Eligibility criteria, and not trigger the Exclusion criteria.

üìù **Note: This is an archival entry. Details for Epoch 10 will be announced soon.**

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#epoch-9) Epoch 9

For Epoch 9, we're covering Ethereum stories.

It‚Äôs time to strengthen Ethereum's narrative. In this epoch, we want to fund creatives: the journalists, storytellers, content creators, and researchers who‚Äôve helped bridge that gap by making Ethereum legible, credible, and engaging to audiences.

We‚Äôre after high-impact marketing, educational, and journalistic content that push Ethereum forward. We want to see work that belongs in classrooms, newsrooms, and dinner table conversations. Think Bill Nye for Ethereum: smart, clear, impossible to ignore.

If you‚Äôve got a vision for how Ethereum‚Äôs stories should be told, this is your stage. Show us the campaign, series, or investigation you‚Äôd run to make Ethereum a part of everyday conversation.

For the application, our ask is to share how/what you want to do, to market Ethereum.

### [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#what-are-we-funding) What are we funding?

This is a retroactive and forward round.

- **You must have already created Ethereum-focused content (not just general crypto or DeFi)**.
- Funding is for your next project + informed by your track record.

We want to reward past excellence and provide fuel for future work.

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#eligibility-criteria) Eligibility Criteria

To apply, **you must**:

- Provide proof of past Ethereum content (video, podcast, article, campaign, etc.)
- Show its impact (audience size, engagement quality, influence).
- Submit a short proposal for your next project, with:
  - Concept and intended impact
  - Distribution plan
  - How you‚Äôd execute with a smaller vs. larger budget (detail what you would do if you got less than 0.1x of the financial $ vs. if you got 10x that amount.

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#eligible-content-formats) Eligible Content Formats

Your **past work** and **proposed new work** may include:

- **Long-form**: Documentaries, explainers, podcasts, essays, investigative journalism
- **Short-form**: Reels, animations, TikToks with educational value
- **Sequential**: Educational series, event coverage, recurring media campaigns

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#evaluation-criteria) Evaluation Criteria

We assess applicants on both what they‚Äôve done and what they propose to do:

### [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#_1-past-work-impact) 1\. Past Work Impact

- Audience reach and engagement
- Narrative clarity and originality
- Ethereum focus (not just general crypto)
- Normie resonance (did it reach beyond the echo chamber?) vs. niche (did it reach a specific audience in crypto)

### [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#_2-proposal-strength) 2\. Proposal Strength

- Creative direction and format
- Clarity of idea and intended impact
- Alignment with Ethereum values and the round theme
- Feasibility and distribution plan based on funding variance (what will it look like if a smaller amount was received vs bigger)
- Proof and reputation of past work

## [\#](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/propose-a-project.html\#ineligible-content-includes) Ineligible content includes:

- Financial advice, price speculation, or token promotion
- Market predictions or ‚Äúmoon/pump‚Äù language
- Event organization as the primary deliverable

Educational or informational content is allowed if free of calls to financial action.

**A detailed description of the submission process is available [here](https://docs.octant.app/en-EN/submission-process.html).**

results.content:
## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting/vote\#who-can-vote-on-proposals)    Who can vote on proposals?

There are several aspects that define if you are eligible to vote on a specific proposal.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting/vote\#voting-strategies)    Voting strategies

Each space specifies their [voting strategies](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting-strategies) in the [space settings.](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/spaces/settings#voting-strategies) You can see the custom setup by opening the space settings. This setup can define if you are eligible to take part in the voting and what is your voting power calculated at the [snapshot of proposal creation](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/create#snapshot-block-number).

In most cases you will be required to have a sufficient amount of tokens in the connected wallet at the time of proposal creation. One of the most common questions we receive on our support channels is [**Why can't I vote?**](https://github.com/snapshot-labs/snapshot/discussions/767)

More often than not the answer is - **you did not hold the sufficient amount of specified token at the time of proposal creation.**

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting/vote\#voting-validation)    Voting validation

Another aspect determining whether you are eligible to vote or not is a [voting validation](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/validation-strategies) defined by the space. It is a mechanism used to define certain conditions like minimum token balance or also to prevent [Sybil Attacks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sybil_attack). In other words the space owner wants to make sure that you are human and that bot or fake accounts are not used to overrule the outcome of the voting.

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting/vote\#cast-a-vote)    Cast a vote

1. Click the `Connect wallet` button in the top right corner.

2. Connect with the wallet provider where you hold the tokens relevant for the space you want to vote in.

3. Go to the space page on Snapshot and selected the active proposal you are interested in.

4. Select the option(s) you want to vote for. The [voting systems](https://docs.snapshot.box/proposals/voting-types) can differ between individual proposals.

5. Click to `Vote` button and sign the message via your wallet provider when prompted.

6. Voil√†! You have casted a vote üéâ


If you are using MetaMask you'll need to scroll to the end of the signature and click on the arrow down for the Sign button to become active.

Voting on Snapshot doesn't affect your account or the funds that are associated to it.

[PreviousVoting](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting) [NextDelegate your voting power](https://docs.snapshot.box/user-guides/voting/delegate-your-voting-power)

Last updated 2 years ago

Was this helpful?

results.content:
## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#overview)    Overview

YAM launched with fully decentralized governance from Day 1 by implementing the Compound governance module. This gives control of the protocol to YAM tokenholders, meaning that updates to the protocol and management of the treasury can only be performed with approval from YAM holders.

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#process)    Process

The governance process begins on [Yam Discord](https://discord.gg/RgHpsmShhE) where ideas are initially discussed. Once discussion has formalized a potential proposal it is submitted to [Yam Governance Forum](https://forum.yam.finance/). If the community signals its interest and any necessary modifications to the proposal are made, the proposal is submitted to [Snapshot off-chain governance](https://snapshot.page/#/yam), where tokenholders can vote with their token balances.

If a Snapshot proposal is passed and no code is required to be implemented, the approved action can be taken.

If code deployment is required, the code will go to audit if necessary, and then be proposed via on-chain governance at which point tokenholders will voteon-chain to deploy.

### [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#timeline)    Timeline

[**Discord Ideation**:](https://discord.gg/hGsu5HD8dA) 1-3 days

[**Forum Discussion**](https://forum.yam.finance/): 3+ days

[**Snapshot Off-Chain Voting**](https://snapshot.page/#/yam.eth): 3 days

[**On-chain Voting**](https://yam.finance/governance): 2 days

**Execution Timelock**: 12 hours

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#delegation)    Delegation

In order to vote, you must [delegate your vote](https://yam.finance/governance) to yourself or to someone else. This applies to off-chain snapshot voting as well. Any YAM tokens being used as an LP in Yam's incentivizer farming Yams are automatically delegated to self. You can currently delegate to yourself via [yam.finance](https://yam.finance/governance), and we are working on an interface to delegate to other addresses. You can also delegate via [etherscan](https://etherscan.io/token/0x0AaCfbeC6a24756c20D41914F2caba817C0d8521#writeContract) directly.

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#quorum)    Quorum

For a proposal to pass and be executed on-chain, it must reach "minimum acceptance quorum," which means having 200,000 BoU YAM voting "For" the proposal, equivalent to 4% of the initial token supply. Quorum requirements for Yam are based on `balanceOfUnderlying`, which are YAMs without the rebasing `scalingFactor` applied. Since the rebase function has been disabled as of Dec 29 the scaling factor is currently fixed to 2.50. Your voting power is your balance of Yam tokens / 2.50.

To submit a proposal:

- In snapshot a user must have 100 BoU YAMs delegated to their address.

- For on-chain voting, a user must have 50,000 BoU YAMs delegated to their address This is equivalent to 1% of the initial token supply.


Basing quorum around a minimum amount of "For" votes eliminates a scenario in which voting "Against" could actually lead a proposal to pass when abstaining would cause it to fail (for example if there were 198k "For" votes and zero "Against", a 2k "Against would allow the proposal to pass if quorum was based on total votes rather than total "For" votes).

## [Direct link to heading](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/governance\#lp-governance-participation)    LP Governance Participation

Only if you provide liquidity to [Sushiswap](https://sushiswap.fi/pair/0x0f82e57804d0b1f6fab2370a43dcfad3c7cb239c) Yam/ETH pool and stake on Yam's incentivizer using [yam.finance/farm](https://yam.finance/farm). Don't forget to register to vote on [yam.finance/governance](https://yam.finance/governance), only needs to be done once. Voting power is determined by distributing the voting power of YAM held in the YAM/ETH Sushiswap pool, but distributed to only YAM Incentivizer stakers. This was done to mitigate flashloan threats in voting, so the Incentivizer contract keeps a record of the necessary values at needed block heights to facilitate those mitigations.

[PreviousHistory](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/history) [NextTreasury](https://docs.yam.finance/yam/treasury)

Last updated 4 years ago

Was this helpful?

# üî¨ DRC: December Report

## Liquid Democracy, Cooperative AI, Web3 Philanthropy, and a Blueprint for Digital Governance

![Author](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/user/profile_picture/1b73fdd9-e095-4145-817c-3a976f854f21/thumb_DRC.jpeg)

[Decentralization Research Center](https://drc.beehiiv.com/authors/1b73fdd9-e095-4145-817c-3a976f854f21)

December 10, 2024

[![DAO Research Collective Logo](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/d28fddcf-035d-40d3-b133-5c29f71be41a/DRC-blackbg.png?t=1652530288)](https://thedrcenter.org/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report)

Welcome to the Decentralization Research Center report, a monthly briefing on events and research relevant to decentralization, DAOs and governance.

# This Month‚Äôs Updates

_**Key Notes**_

This month, we present an eclectic selection of stories, highlighting the areas of research and inquiry that represent some of the most exciting work in decentralized governance.

DAOs continue to experiment with and iterate on new and evolving governance models. Andrew B. Hall and Sho Miyazaki share an empirical political science [study of liquid democracy](https://andrewbenjaminhall.com/Hall_Miyazaki_Delegation.pdf?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report) in real-world settings, analyzing data from over 250,000 voters and 1,700 proposals across 18 DAOs built on the Ethereum blockchain.

In exploring cooperative paradigms for artificial intelligence, Sarah Hubbard explores [alternative ownership and governance structures for AI](https://ash.harvard.edu/resources/cooperative-paradigms-for-artificial-intelligence/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report) that may better serve the public interest than current models: ‚Äú_While there have been some shifts in corporate governance, there must be a greater movement toward empowering people to collectively and cooperatively govern the AI systems that are impacting their lives._‚Äù

[![](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/06434e11-0722-4c3b-9992-565b0d9dc345/Screenshot_2024-12-10_at_09.42.52.png?t=1733820196)](https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/features/hidden-cost-ai-conversation-professor-mark-graham?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report)

[Cooperative Paradigms for Artificial Intelligence](https://ash.harvard.edu/resources/cooperative-paradigms-for-artificial-intelligence/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report)

In assessing how [Web3 can transform social impact](https://pub.superbenefit.org/reimagining-power-how-web3-can-transform-social-impact?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report), a team of collaborators turn their focus to philanthropy: ‚Äú_In the face of multiple crises, systemic inequities, and entrenched power imbalances, philanthropy stands at a pivotal moment. Achieving transformational change requires bold shifts in how we understand and exercise power, mobilize resources, and distribute value._‚Äù

And in their new [Blueprint to Digital Governance](https://www.projectliberty.io/news/project-liberty-unveils-blueprint-to-guide-policymakers-on-digital-governance/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report), Project Liberty proposes policy for a federal right of data portability, interoperability standards, distributed systems for better data stewardship, and for greater partnership with democratic allies in renewing our commitment to a global internet.

_**The Full Rundown**_

Other stories and research we‚Äôre tracking for you:

- Current research in ‚Äúplural alignment‚Äù concentrates on making AI models amenable to diverse human values. But Christina Lu argues that plurality is not simply a safeguard against bias or an engine of efficiency: it's a [key ingredient for intelligence itself](https://www.combinationsmag.com/model-plurality/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report).

- David Gray Widder, Meredith Whittaker, and Sarah Myers West explain how[‚Äòopen‚Äô AI systems are actually closed](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08141-1?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report): ‚Äú_We find that openness alone does not perturb the concentration of power in AI. Just as many traditional open-source software projects were co-opted in various ways by large technology companies, we show how rhetoric around ‚Äòopen‚Äô AI is frequently wielded in ways that exacerbate rather than reduce concentration of power in the AI sector._‚Äù

- a16z asked 50 partners to preview [one big idea](https://a16z.com/big-ideas-in-tech-2025/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report) that will spur innovation in 2025. Answers include liquid democracy and greater adoption of the ‚ÄòDUNA,‚Äôan external "AI brain," big swings in biopharma, infinite games, a nuclear resurgence, "faceless" creators, Google search challengers, and battlefield AI.

- Nathan Schneider joins Flaming Hydra to discuss his conversations and insights with [digital rights activists in India](https://flaminghydra.com/issue-208/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report). ‚Äú_Their concern about democracy was not its slowness or inconvenience‚Äînormally the worry among Americans‚Äîbut the dangers of majoritarian rule._‚Äù

- Kevin Owocki presents the [Onchain Capital Allocation Handbook](https://allobook.gitcoin.co/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report), exploring how, by addressing coordination failures and introducing new onchain strategies, crypto could transform how society allocates resources.

- RadicalxChange introduces their new publicaiton, [Combinationsmag](https://www.combinationsmag.com/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report), exploring ideas about economics, democracy, and the relationship between technology and power.


[![](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/a63063f4-f43e-4413-830c-de70d1d8f3f5/signal-2024-03-11-100120.jpeg?t=1710177688)](https://podcasts.apple.com/ca/podcast/techquitable/id1730611363?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report)

In this episode of Techquitable, we sat down with Sheila Warren, voted one of the most influential women in DC by the Washingtonian and founder of the World Economic Forum‚Äôs blockchain and digital assets team. [Here](http://podfollow.com/1730611363?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-december-report), she shares her perspective on the stalled crypto policy in America, her current work at the Crypto Council for Innovation and much more.

If you‚Äôre working on related research or would like to get involved in our work, please reach out to us via [info@thedrcenter.org](mailto:info@thedrcenter.org). We‚Äôd love to hear from you!

Connor Spelliscy

Executive Director

Decentralization Research Center

- üî¨ DRC: November Report

# üî¨ DRC: November Report

## Public AI, Renewing Section 230, and Election Disinformation Campaigns

![Author](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/user/profile_picture/1b73fdd9-e095-4145-817c-3a976f854f21/thumb_DRC.jpeg)

[Decentralization Research Center](https://drc.beehiiv.com/authors/1b73fdd9-e095-4145-817c-3a976f854f21)

November 12, 2024

[![DAO Research Collective Logo](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/d28fddcf-035d-40d3-b133-5c29f71be41a/DRC-blackbg.png?t=1652530288)](https://thedrcenter.org/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report)

Welcome to the Decentralization Research Center report, a monthly briefing on events and research relevant to decentralization, DAOs and governance.

# This Month‚Äôs Updates

_**Key Notes**_

With the current dominance of just a few key players defining the AI race, calls for democratized and decentralized versions of AI continue to grow. In this context, we feature [Shared Code: Democratizing AI Companies](https://www.cip.org/blog/shared-code?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), a guide from Nathan Schneider, Divya Siddarth, and Joal Stein that offers AI companies a set of viable and achievable options for democratizing the governance structures of their organizations. The Public AI Network has also release their own [paper calling for public AI](https://zenodo.org/records/13914560?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), and these, along with [the call from Mozilla last month](https://assets.mofoprod.net/network/documents/Public_AI_Mozilla.pdf?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), represent a new wave of efforts to achieve more equitable AI ownership and governance.

![](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/84f82799-28aa-46c5-a4b3-a2ed89197992/Screenshot_2024-11-12_at_08.34.18.png?t=1731397362)

[Public AI: Infrastructure for the Common Good](https://zenodo.org/records/13914560?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report)

In a thought-provoking piece, [Sunset and Renew](https://ash.harvard.edu/articles/sunset-and-renew-section-230-should-protect-human-speech-not-algorithmic-virality/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), Jaron Lanier, Allison Stanger, and Audrey Tang argue that Section 230 requires an overhaul: ‚Äú_To truly uphold First Amendment freedoms, we must hold accountable the algorithms that drive harmful virality while protecting human expression_.‚Äù

And, as predicted in our paper, [AI and Democracy‚Äôs Digital Identity Crisis](https://stanford-jblp.pubpub.org/pub/ai-democracy-digital-identity/release/1?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), governments at odds with US interests deployed AI-enabled [impersonation and disinformation campaigns](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/10/29/technology/election-interference-russia-china-iran.html?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report) in the US election.

[![](https://media.beehiiv.com/cdn-cgi/image/fit=scale-down,format=auto,onerror=redirect,quality=80/uploads/asset/file/fc6dbb3b-4741-4148-a94d-97c670347e3c/mariia-shalabaieva-HBkpnDVc_Ic-unsplash-1500x791.jpg?t=1731397470)](https://www.ox.ac.uk/news/features/hidden-cost-ai-conversation-professor-mark-graham?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report)

[Sunset and Renew: Section 230 Should Protect Human Speech, Not Algorithmic Virality. Image credit: Unsplash, Mariia Shalabaieva](https://ash.harvard.edu/articles/sunset-and-renew-section-230-should-protect-human-speech-not-algorithmic-virality/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report)

_**The Full Rundown**_

Other stories and research we‚Äôve been tracking for you:

- As citizens‚Äô assemblies gain prominence as a form of decentralizing power and allowing bottom-up decisions to gain legislative traction, Democracy Next presents their [Assembling an Assembly Guide](https://assemblyguide.demnext.org/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report).

- The Ethereum Foundation has released its [annual report for 2024](https://ethereum.foundation/report-2024.pdf?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), highlighting the teams, grants and institutions that make up its ecosystem and looking at how these help enable the core goals of ‚Äú_long term thinking, subtraction, and stewardship of values_.‚Äù

- [Democracy 2.0](https://www.digitalistpapers.com/essays/democracy-2?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report): ‚Äú_The opportunities afforded by AI to make governance better are unprecedented in human history_.‚Äù A paper by Eric Schmidt.

- Examining [how decentralized tech can preserve election integrity](https://www.forbes.com/sites/astanley/2024/10/28/how-decentralized-tech-can-preserve-election-integrity-in-the-ai-age/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), Kinsman contends that we‚Äôre soon reaching the point where discerning what‚Äôs real is going to be virtually impossible, particularly in the context of politics.

- Vlad Zamfir argues that we‚Äôre squandering the potential of decentralized technology while prioritizing financial opportunism and insiderism. By [understanding blockchains in terms of time, not money](https://www.coindesk.com/opinion/2024/11/07/weve-been-thinking-about-blockchains-wrong-theyre-about-time-not-money/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), he believes we can change that dynamic.

- As diminished state capacity leads to civic disengagement as governments fail to meet public expectations, Jennifer Pahlka advocates for understanding bureaucratic constraints and [using AI to build government capacity](https://www.digitalistpapers.com/essays/ai-meets-the-cascade-of-rigidity?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report) for more effective governance.

- Mona Hamdy, Johnnie Moore, and E. Glen Weyl advocate for an [inclusive, participatory framework](https://www.digitalistpapers.com/essays/misunderstanding-ais-democracy-problem?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report) that fosters collaboration between technology and society, offering an alternative to the dominant techno-ideologies of Libertarianism and Technocracy.

- Centered on the collective creation of new vocal datasets, governance frameworks and polyphonic AI models, [The Call](https://www.serpentinegalleries.org/about/press/holly-herndon-and-mat-dryhurst-the-call/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report) positions the process of data collection and AI model-training as artmaking.

- ‚Äú_Vetocracy_,‚Äù polarization, and how ‚Äú_observing that AI could be used for good is like observing that bulldozers could be used to help build affordable public housing. It is possible, of course, but is it likely?_‚Äù [A paper](https://www.digitalistpapers.com/essays/protected-democracy?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report) by Lawrence Lessig.

- Project Liberty provides a brief overview and multiple avenues for exploration on [the topic of interoperability](https://email.projectliberty.io/how-interoperability-is-central-to-the-internets-future?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report), a sometimes forgotten yet fundamental part of the internet‚Äôs ability to decentralize, or centralize, power


If you‚Äôre working on related research or would like to get involved in our work, please reach out to us via [info@thedrcenter.org](mailto:info@thedrcenter.org). We‚Äôd love to hear from you!

Connor Spelliscy

Executive Director

Decentralization Research Center

[![](https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/yfx7loRaUgumMwjJoqaKi6_OUmtceGR1SrqcGmqZOVIPzPNA4OWpcYaUdw4WRvJUqUaJhxwUEkje2G70L2mb6I9EnGszp4g8y_3_iu2Ljbv6JtRqNfqTu1TdmWTAf1EvzShMSGKkpqimvAJsrC2VMfA)](https://thedrcenter.org/?utm_source=drc.beehiiv.com&utm_medium=referral&utm_campaign=drc-november-report)

# [üìï](https://drepute.github.io/playbook/)

# Hey there! [Anchor link to header](https://drepute.github.io/playbook/index.html\#hey-there)

![](https://drepute.github.io/playbook/img/cover.png)

In our quest to help communities maximize their potential, we couldn‚Äôt help but try and understand how communities work at a deeper level.

- What dynamics govern them?
- How does an average community evolve?
- And, most importantly, how does one start a community around an interest or a goal?

To answer these questions, we started putting together this community building playbook as a public good. And we invite you to co-create it with us!

Distilling community building into a formula is futile and also not our intention here. Instead, we aim to open a two-way dialogue with the reader and discuss the general direction we should move in. As a result, this public good may seem incomplete, and it shall always be so.

As community members, we know the infinite ways in which communities rise and fall. Technological developments often disrupt established processes and ground rules and add to this complexity. As a result, the community building meta keeps changing.

The rules of building a decentralized, digital community differ from those of building an irl one. This playbook focuses on the former type of communities and highlights the concepts and practices that have worked in this domain.

We invite you to share your experiences so we may refine this playbook and make it a possible reference point for the community builders of tomorrow. üòÑ

# BlockchainGov Knowledge Base

BlockchainGov‚Äôs Discord Server has been a hub for sharing valuable papers, books, and articles across our diverse research topics.

After two years of continuous contributions, we have decided to create a unified archive, designed as a public good: the BlockchainGov Knowledge Base. This resource will serve as a shared foundation for researchers, practitioners, and anyone interested in the evolving landscape of blockchain governance. BlockchainGov Knowledge Base groups 400+ research papers, online articles, books and journals.

The Knowledge Base is organized across the main research tracks used in our Discord server:

![ü•∑](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Alegality - Research on the uncharted territory beyond the boundaries of existing legal orders.

![ü§ñ](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Artificial Intelligence - Everything AI-related: innovations, policies, scandals, hallucinations etc

![üìú](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Constitutions - Ideas, concepts and patterns on constitutions

![üåê](<Base64-Image-Removed>)¬†Coordi-Nations - Reflections on new networked sovereignties and techno-nation-building

![ü´Ç](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Exit to Community - Case-studies, speculations and more on exit-to-community

![‚öíÔ∏è](<Base64-Image-Removed>)DAO Workers \- Working conditions and labour in Web3

![üî¨](<Base64-Image-Removed>)¬†Ethnography \- Ethnographic methods for investigating blockchain spaces

![üëÅÔ∏è‚Äçüó®Ô∏è](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Governance - Patterns, coordination games and governance schemas

![üë§](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Identity - Digital identities, proof-of-humanity, online personas

![‚öñÔ∏è](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Legitimacy \- Reflections on legitimacy in monetary and legal systems

![ü´ß](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Metaverse - Virtual worlds, digital real estate and immersive realities

![ü™û](<Base64-Image-Removed>)NFT Licensing \- Research on Non-fungible tokens, IP, digital license

![‚≠ï](<Base64-Image-Removed>)¬†Polycentricity and Pluralism \- Polycentric and Plural system

![üíº](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Regulation and Policy \- Discussing existing or proposed legislation relevant to crypto

![ü§ù](<Base64-Image-Removed>)Trust and Confidence \- Exploring different dimensions of trust

[![üìö](<Base64-Image-Removed>)\\
\\

results.content:
# (((O))) : We Lost The Sea ‚Äì Departure Songs

#### ![](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/a2633842828_101.jpg)By:¬†[Nick Dodds](https://www.echoesanddust.com/project/nick-dodds/ "Nick Dodds")

#### We Lost The Sea \|¬†[website \|](https://www.welostthesea.com/ "website |") [facebook \|](https://www.facebook.com/welostthesea "facebook |") [twitter \|](https://twitter.com/welostthesea "twitter |") [bandcamp \|](https://welostthesea.bandcamp.com/ "bandcamp |")

**Released on¬†July 23, 2015 via [Art As Catharsis Records / Bird‚Äôs Robe Records](https://welostthesea.bandcamp.com/album/departure-songs "Art As Catharsis Records / Bird‚Äôs Robe Records")**

‚ÄúThey were here‚Ä¶.. and now they‚Äôre gone.‚Äù: Challenger Part 1 ‚Äì Flight.

Make no mistake, this is not a happy record. This is not a bbq, Saturday night ‚Äòsingalong around a fire with your friends‚Äô record. This is a heavy slab. It‚Äôs a pressure that weighs upon your chest, pressing down relentlessly for the duration of this stunning release, until (of all people) Ronald Reagan‚Äôs voice appears in your ears to deliver the final killing blow. It‚Äôs also stunningly beautiful. Take your breath away beautiful‚Ä¶ but it‚Äôs the beauty of seeing a hearse drive away with a loved one inside it, and knowing that they‚Äôll live forever inside you, but you‚Äôll never see them again.

This album is dripping with sadness, loss, and glorious failure. It‚Äôs an amazing release, and I‚Äôm actually a little scared to review it. I hope I do it justice. Perhaps it‚Äôs best if you imagine this review as the enthusiastic stranger at a bar after 5 pints finding out that you like the same music, and excitedly yelling at you for 20 minutes.

[iframe](https://bandcamp.com/EmbeddedPlayer/album=3408776844/size=large/bgcol=333333/linkcol=ffffff/tracklist=false/artwork=small/transparent=true/)

**We Lost The Sea** have been around for a while now, and this is their third album, but their first instrumental one. A band re-inventing themselves in such an ambitious fashion is always fraught with potential pitfalls, but in my opinion this is a masterstroke. A nimble dodge of the usual tropes, and a carefully thought out, intelligent and passionate release that drips catharsis, closure and amazing storytelling, without actually singing a single word. I don‚Äôt know many bands that can do that.

This album is a carefully thought out celebration of human attempts, endeavours, honour, love and loss. It‚Äôs palpable on this release, dripping out of your speakers and enticing you deeper, akin to the cave dive David Shaw embarked upon. It‚Äôs an epitaph to faceless men and women that you may not have known, but after you hear this you certainly will. I‚Äôm also going to do something a little different as Matt Harvey (@matterata), guitarist in the band has made stunning artwork for each song, which I shall present here.

[![wlts a gallant gentleman](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-a-gallant-gentleman.jpg)](https://www.echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-a-gallant-gentleman.jpg)

The album opens with ‚ÄòA Gallant Gentleman‚Äô, an ode to Captain Lawrence Oates of the Scott South Pole Expedition who sacrificed himself for the greater good in 1912. A lot of you may have heard his famous words in school, as ‚ÄúI am just going outside and may be some time‚Äù might be one of the most understated goodbyes of all time. Imagine huddling in a tent, blizzards howling outside, barely coherent and knowing that all your exploits failed‚Ä¶ Only to find some inner strength and stumble off into the black night, dying cold, lonely and buried forever in a shapeless white snowdrift, the tundra claiming you as its own. For your friends. And the music matches this perfectly. Slowly chiming guitars build and swirl like the snowstorms of that night, a girls choir eerily echoing in the background doubling as the Antarctic wind until the song peaks, cymbals crashing and a trio of guitars rolling over you, the cadence fixed & forced, lurching, stumbling and inexorably marching forwards until you fall, left with nothing but the ‚Äòwind‚Äô swirling around you. And while this is a lonely sacrifice (and let‚Äôs face it, dying from hypothermia alone in the night is pretty lonely) somehow the music retains an uplifting quality. Out of death comes life. It‚Äôs a delicate balancing act and one that‚Äôs pulled off with aplomb.

[![wlts bogatyri](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-bogatyri.jpg)](https://www.echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-bogatyri.jpg)

‚ÄòBogatyri‚Äô is next, recounting the sacrifice of Valeri Bezpalov, Alexie Ananenko & Boris Baranov at the Chernobyl disaster. Three brave men who selflessly sacrificed themselves to open a valve in heavily irradiated water to save countless lives, then buried in lead coffins ten days later. One can only imagine what they must have felt, their bodies breaking down cell by cell, day by day. A selfless act that consigns them to the annals of history, leaving wives without husbands and children without fathers. Not a failure per se as their actions saved many, but a noble sacrifice. An act resulting in certain death. I‚Äôd had the privilege of seeing this live the week before as the band supported **This Will Destroy You**, and was suckered hard by this rollicking, bleak and heavy track. The Twin Peaks inspired bassline and cymbal work that kicks in around the two minute mark is sublime, all smoky nightclub and grizzled chanteuse leaning into a microphone to warn her listeners of the impending doom‚Ä¶ Until the guitars gradually take over, leading you on for a minute or so as the crescendo builds and builds. And then ‚Äì bang. There‚Äôs a time change and you‚Äôre pulled into the dark, irradiated water along with the Bogatyri (a Ukrainian folklore tale of three valiant knights). Constrained and dark, choking you slowly as the guitars peak again and again, washing over you as the bass rumbles and jars, the cymbals swirling around your head. It swirls for ages, drowning you in sound and an absence of light, just as our three brave men would have experienced. This is 12 minutes of your life that passes all too quickly, until all you‚Äôre left with are the decaying guitars, symbolic of their frail bodies at the end.

[![wlts the last dive of david shaw](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-the-last-dive-of-david-shaw.jpg)](https://www.echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-the-last-dive-of-david-shaw.jpg)

I confess, before this release I had never heard of David Shaw. Now, I‚Äôll always know him. Before you read further I strongly suggest you watch this video, which is the actual last dive in question:

[iframe](https://www.youtube.com/embed/mF4iFJ-G74o?feature=oembed)

Unsurprisingly given the tone of this album, this is heavy stuff. You‚Äôre watching a man die right in front of your eyes. Attempting to do something selfless, brave & noble ‚Äì and failing. At 271 metres underwater. I don‚Äôt dive but that is an insane depth to dive to ‚Äì the human body is just not designed for it. And 5 minutes at that depth equals over 12 hours coming back up to avoid nitrogen narcosis. Again, there really aren‚Äôt enough words to describe how full on this is. But there is this music.

Cloying, claustrophobic and doomed, this track lurches deeper and deeper, beginning with the audio of Dave‚Äôs last dive. The water rushes over you and you start to sink as a distorted wall of feedback wraps its fingers around you until you push through to the clean, sterile guitar tones. These build musically (but not sonically) as Dave‚Äôs audio fades out, leaving you with the track. You sink deeper, drums matching the beating of your heart as you pass fifty, then 100 metres. And then time slows. The music stops. All is quiet, tranquil and serene. Then a country inspired guitar twang cuts through, wrapping around your torso and pulling you down into the depths. Like Dave, you go willingly. Unlike Dave, you‚Äôre coming back. The guitar and cello parts start to entwine, the drums mashing into your head along with the bass as you feel the floor of the cave under your feet. Then things explode, lurching around your head as the guitars wail, their cacophony building over minutes, not seconds, leaving you in a trance until twelve minutes in everything comes together in a glorious dark, sinful melody that for me is a fitting soundtrack to Dave‚Äôs last dive. Musically this is the equivalent of nitrogen narcosis, leaving you ‚Äòdrunk‚Äô and unsure of what‚Äôs just happened. All you know is that it‚Äôs cold, dark and deep.

It‚Äôs deep, you‚Äôre alone and playing with a body that‚Äôs been there for ten years. And soon you‚Äôll be joining him. And yet in this darkness and death there is still a sliver of light, as David Shaw kept his promise to Deon Dryer‚Äôs parents. He brought him back. Four days later Dave and Deon‚Äôs bodies were pulled to the surface. A promise kept ‚Äì at the highest cost of all.

[![wlts challenger pt 1](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-challenger-pt-1.jpg)](https://www.echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-challenger-pt-1.jpg)

It‚Äôs a fairly safe bet that most of the Western world is aware of the Challenger disaster ‚Äì we either experienced it live or have seen the footage numerous times since that fateful day in 1986. Possibly the most dramatic failure of the American space program, it hammered home to a new generation the dangers, pitfalls and sheer science & skill involved in getting our feeble bodies to break free of the bonds of our atmosphere and up into the unknown. But on January 28th of that year it was not to be, a nailbiting 73 seconds permanently etched into the collective consciousness. I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs deliberate or not, but the intro riff of this track is close enough to 73 seconds that watching video of the launch while listening to this is an eerie experience. That is, after we have a beautiful speech by William S. Burroughs on Dreams from 1980. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not there yet‚Äù indeed.

The lonely, melancholic guitar starts things off after the spoken word/ambient intro, all empty sadness, sorrow and reflection on things that could have been, yet weren‚Äôt. It‚Äôs poignant and deep, circuiting the edge of trancelike structure while everything slowly builds around you, a harsh guitar melody climbing out of the fog. A driving beat kicks in around the nine minute mark, bleak, and lacking hope. And this is yet another section where having three guitarists pays off in dividends, as it allows space to build and expand upon a riff, droning and weaving around the anchoring of the bass & drums‚Ä¶ But only briefly. All too soon we‚Äôre taken into space (an overarching theme on this album, but this time literal), back with the fated crew as a lone guitar line soars through everything, cutting you with its distortion. It‚Äôs all melancholic country twang here, reminding me of lonely journeys through dust caked back roads. And then a moog-esque keyboard melody kicks in and tension is immediately there around you. And with a sample from the Challenger launch we‚Äôre there in the climax of the song, 19 minutes in. It‚Äôs glorious. Special. Every band member beating the living shit out of their instruments, wringing every last bent, distorted note out of them that they can. Not just playing the music, but being consumed by it.

And then all too soon, it‚Äôs gone. Over. And we‚Äôre left with samples of the crowd from January 28th. And with a thick ‚ÄòJersey‚Äô accent we have a devastated woman sum up this album better than I ever could, with the quote that opens this review. It‚Äôs powerful, poignant and a little bit soul destroying.

[![wlts challenger pt 2](https://echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-challenger-pt-2.jpg)](https://www.echoesanddust.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/07/wlts-challenger-pt-2.jpg)

And then we‚Äôre into the home stretch. The ‚Äòswan song‚Äô indeed. And yet this track, while similar to the rest of the album differs somewhat. It allows a sliver of light in. It‚Äôs not happy or joyous in the beginning, but affirming. Guitars providing a chiming release as soft cymbal work and (I‚Äôm assuming) mallet-hit floor toms gently push you forwards towards the edge of the cliff. You‚Äôve come this far ‚Äì there‚Äôs no point going back now. And then we‚Äôre falling, wrapped in that blanket of quiet despair that has been prevalent throughout. But if ever there was a slow fall, this is it. You have time to examine your surroundings as the band slowly build the track, layer after layer, until what is possibly the only major chord on the album explodes and before you hit the ground you‚Äôre caught. And brought up. It‚Äôs an affirmation of all the heavy shit that‚Äôs come before, and a promise that there is light to come. As Dylan Thomas said: ‚ÄúDo not go gentle into that good night‚Äù, and this battle helps confirm that.

Is it telling that they chose not to include the line ‚Äúour hopes and our journeys continue‚Äù from Reagan‚Äôs closing speech? I like to think so. I like to think that it‚Äôs superfluous, as this beautiful music tells you that. This is the hand on your shoulder from a loved one while you‚Äôre at your lowest ebb, the smile of a friend as you bare your soul. There‚Äôs no judgement here. Just beautiful, special music.

So here we are. This isn‚Äôt just an album ‚Äì it‚Äôs a baring of humanity‚Äôs soul. It‚Äôs a realisation that you can fuck up, fail and fall and not only have people done it before, but there will be someone, anyone there for you. As a band they‚Äôve managed to write songs that match the tone and feel of each story that they‚Äôre telling, along with stunning artwork to go with it.

This is a special, unique release. This is a band going through dark days and coming out the other side, by embracing it and inviting us to share this with them. This is not something that comes along every day, and I thank them for it. If you ever have a discussion with someone and want to prove the power of music ‚Äì reach for this.

Now if you don‚Äôt mind me, I‚Äôm going to go and listen to it again. They were here and now they‚Äôre gone indeed.

This review is dedicated to Chris Torpy.

[Business News](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/)[Tech](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech)[Tech & Internet](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/technology)Aadhaar data leak \| Personal data of 81.5 crore Indians on sale on dark web: report

# Aadhaar data leak \| Personal data of 81.5 crore Indians on sale on dark web: report

ETtechLast Updated: Oct 31, 2023, 05:43:53 PM IST

[![Google Preference in ET](https://img.etimg.com/photo/123563320.cms)](https://www.google.com/preferences/source?q=economictimes "Google Preference in ET")

[![Whatsapp Follow Channel](https://img.etimg.com/photo/104857408.cms)Follow us](https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb6dOI1EKyZPPqpH7I0y)

Share

Font Size

AbcSmall

AbcMedium

AbcLarge

Save

[Print](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/technology/aadhar-data-leak-personal-data-of-81-5-crore-indians-on-sale-on-dark-web-report/printarticle/104856898.cms)

Comment

### Synopsis

The data breach noticed by Resecurity mentioned that "on October 9, a threat actor going by the alias 'pwn0001' posted a thread on Breach Forums brokering access to 815 million 'Indian Citizen Aadhaar and Passport' records".

![Image for Aadhaar data leak | Personal data of 81.5 crore Indians on sale on dark web: report](https://img.etimg.com/thumb/width-650,height-488,imgsize-20358,resizemode-75,msid-104857466/tech/technology/aadhar-data-leak-personal-data-of-81-5-crore-indians-on-sale-on-dark-web-report/icmr-data-leak-reveals-personal-info-of-81-5-cr-indians-report.jpg)IANS

In what could be one of the biggest data breaches in Indian history, details of over 81.5 crore Indian citizens are on sale on the dark web, US-based [cybersecurity](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/cybersecurity) firm Resecurity reported. The data sets on sale contain crucial information such as Aadhaar and passport details, along with names, phone numbers, and addresses, according to the report.

The details were a part of the Indian Council of Medical Research‚Äôs (ICMR) database.

The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) is expected to probe the incident after the ICMR files a complaint.

The [data breach](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/data-breach) noticed by Resecurity mentioned that "on October 9, a threat actor going by the alias 'pwn0001' posted a thread on Breach Forums brokering access to 815 million 'Indian Citizen Aadhaar and Passport' records".

Moreover, the cybersecurity analysts found one of the leaked samples containing 100,000 records of [PII](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/pii) (personally identifiable information) related to Indian residents.

In this sample leak, the analysts identified valid [Aadhaar Card](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/wealth/personal-finance-news/aadhaar-card) IDs, which were corroborated via a government portal that provides a " [Verify Aadhaar](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/verify-aadhaar)" feature.

The analysts also managed to connect with the threat actor and learned they were willing to sell the entire Aadhaar and Indian passport dataset for $80,000 (over Rs 66 lakh).

However, the threat actor declined to specify how they obtained the data.

Last month, cybersecurity researchers found that the official website of the Ministry of AYUSH in Jharkhand had been breached, exposing over 3.2 lakh patient records on the dark web.

According to the cybersecurity company CloudSEK, the website's database, amounting to 7.3 MB, holds patient records that include PII and medical diagnoses. The compromised data also contains sensitive information about doctors, including their PII, login credentials, usernames, passwords, and phone numbers.

The data breach was initiated by a threat actor named " [Tanaka](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/topic/tanaka)".

_(With input from agencies)_
