\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Third publication (1985)")\]

#### Discovering supercivilizations

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Discovering supercivilizations")\]

In the article _On the Inevitability and the Possible Structure of Supercivilizations_ published in 1985, Kardashev evokes the possible scenarios and the means of investigation available to humanity for the detection of [hypothetical extraterrestrial supercivilizations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_hypothesis "Extraterrestrial hypothesis"). The Soviet astronomer reminds us that we search for these supercivilizations on the basis of our own development criteria, and that predictions are possible only for extraterrestrial worlds close to our technological level, the others being beyond our intellectual representation. Nevertheless, it seems useful to him to conceive models of supercivilizations based at the same time on imagination and on our present scientific knowledge. Since the [laws of physics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law "Scientific law") are immutable, even if new laws are discovered in the future, they will not abolish those already known.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)

According to Kardashev, theoretical models of supercivilizations must meet two basic assumptions. The first is that the range of supercivilization activities that obey the laws of physics is limited only by natural and scientific constraints, while the second is that the evolution of supercivilization activities cannot be interrupted or limited by intrinsic, inherent contingencies, such as large-scale social conflicts. For Kardashev, unlike other scientists, supercivilizations cannot self-destruct or retrogress. According to these principles, there must exist in space [megastructures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megastructure "Megastructure") of great size, emitting a lot of [energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy "Energy") and [information](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information "Information"), and existing for billions of years, while being compact enough to rapidly exchange large amounts of data between them.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-6)

A supercivilization would thus create a technological structure of cosmic dimensions. As an example, Kardashev cites [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson")'s megastructure, in the form of a [sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere") of several [astronomical units](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_unit "Astronomical unit") in diameter. Other phenomena may indicate highly technological activities, such as artificially exploding stars or the changing of stellar [orbits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbit "Orbit") to store mass and energy. [Giant molecular clouds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_cloud "Molecular cloud") also hold great potential for [astroengineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_engineering "Astronomical engineering"). Kardashev even raises the possibility of a supercivilization reshaping the entire galaxy.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-6)

Then he evokes the theoretical and mathematical possibility of the existence of a megastructure in the form of a disk rotating on itself at a constant [angular velocity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_frequency "Angular frequency"). According to him, the search for intelligent signals should be directed to the detection of such megastructures at the characteristic radiation (20 Œºm). [Quasars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasar "Quasar") or galactic centers can be excellent candidates to testify to the existence of a supercivilization since they emit strong [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared "Infrared") radiation, which indicates a solid structure. The astronomer advises to look for these objects in a [wavelength](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength") range from a few microns to a few millimeters. Large intelligent structures can also be detected by the fact that they screen or reflect the surrounding radiation.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)

#### Possible scenarios for the evolution of supercivilizations

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Possible scenarios for the evolution of supercivilizations")\]

See also: [Potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_cultural_impact_of_extraterrestrial_contact "Potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact")

Kardashev believes that it is very likely that a supercivilization has already detected and observed humanity through cosmic-sized telescopes. He discusses this in a 1997 article on the subject, entitled _Radioastron ‚Äì a Radio Telescope Much Greater than the Earth_.[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-2-12) For this supercivilization, the science of "cosmic ethnography" must be highly developed. However, the fact that [no contact has been made so far](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_paradox "Fermi paradox") could be explained by [ethical considerations of these civilizations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo_hypothesis "Zoo hypothesis"). Based on this principle, Kardashev sees only two possible evolutionary scenarios for a supercivilization: natural evolution and [evolution after contact with other extraterrestrial civilizations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Potential_cultural_impact_of_extraterrestrial_contact "Potential cultural impact of extraterrestrial contact"). He considers more likely the scenario based on contact between two highly developed, technologically and culturally advanced civilizations; this scenario, which he calls the "Urbanization Hypothesis", would result in the regrouping and unification of several civilizations within a few compact regions of the [Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universe "Universe").[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)

Kardashev lists, in the form of investigative tools, six possible scenarios (summarized in a table at the end of his 1997 article)[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-2-12) that explain the evolution of a civilization. Each of the scenarios corresponds to a [probability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability "Probability"), one or more objects to be observed, an adapted procedure, and, finally the possible consequences for our civilization:[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)

1. The scenario of a large unification of civilizations over an extent of one to ten billion light-years with concentration in a certain region has a probability of 60%. These civilizations are to be searched for in the most powerful [quasars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasar "Quasar") and in the [galactic bulge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_bulge "Galactic bulge"), at a radiation level higher than 1038 watts, in the wavelengths from 10 Œºm to 1¬†cm, as well as in the other regions of the spectrum. This is to detect megastructures or signals with a wavelength of 1.5¬†mm[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-13) and omnidirectional emission up to 21¬†cm. In the event of contact, humanity would see progress in all areas of society in order to join this supercivilization; it is also expected that an [ethnographic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethnography "Ethnography") conservatory would be created on Earth.
2. The scenario of a unification on the scale of the [galactic cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_cluster "Open cluster") has only a 20% probability of realization. Kardashev advises to observe the [Virgo cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgo_Cluster "Virgo Cluster") (especially [M87](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_87 "Messier 87")) and other clusters in a similar way as in the first scenario. The consequences for humanity are the same as in the first scenario.
3. The scenario of a unification on the scale of galaxies has only a 10% probability. To confirm it, we must study the galactic centers, both of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way") and of neighboring galaxies (such as [M31](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andromeda_Galaxy "Andromeda Galaxy"), [M33](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangulum_Galaxy "Triangulum Galaxy")), according to a procedure similar to that of the first scenario. The consequences for humanity are the same as in the first scenario.
4. The scenario of a complete [colonization of space](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_colonization "Space colonization") has no probability of being realized according to Kardashev because if it were realizable then "they" would already be on Earth; yet this is not the case. However, in the case of a contact, the consequences on humanity are the same as in the first scenario.
5. This scenario assumes that all civilizations would have destroyed themselves before any contact. Kardashev estimates the probability of this to be 10%. Humanity should be able to detect ancient megastructures in the vicinity of the [nearest stars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_nearest_stars_and_brown_dwarfs "List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs"). As a result, no contact with humanity can take place.
6. The last scenario suggests that we are the first or the only ones in the Universe. Kardashev estimates its probability at 10%. Only [exobiology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrobiology "Astrobiology") can confirm or falsify such a scenario. We can imagine a potential [contact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_contact_(science_fiction) "First contact (science fiction)") in the distant future, and then the consequences would be similar to those of the other five scenarios.

### Fourth publication (1997)

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Fourth publication (1997)")\]

[![Color illustration. An object resembling a truncated trumpet has white spots on its surface.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/CMB_Timeline75.jpg/1000px-CMB_Timeline75.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:CMB_Timeline75.jpg) According to the [standard model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Model "Standard Model") describing the [expansion of the Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expansion_of_the_universe "Expansion of the universe") since the [Big Bang](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Bang "Big Bang"), there may be planets older than the Earth, capable of harboring supercivilizations.

In the article _Cosmology and Civilizations_ published in 1997, Kardashev reiterates the need to carefully observe astronomical objects with strong radiation in order to detect supercivilizations. However, the discovery of a civilization at a stage of development similar to ours is unlikely. The existence of such supercivilizations is made possible by the fact that [life on Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_life "History of life") is recent compared to the [age of the Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Age_of_the_universe "Age of the universe") (8 √ó 109 years before the [formation of the Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formation_and_evolution_of_the_Solar_System "Formation and evolution of the Solar System")). He then examines the conditions for the appearance of life on cosmological time scales. Assuming the rate of evolution of life on Earth and considering the age of the Universe, it is reasonable to assume that a civilization could have reached our level of technological development in 6 √ó 109 years. Such civilizations can be observed in nearby regions, since the farther away we observe, the younger the objects are. Recent discoveries of [sources of intense radiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_ray "Gamma ray") deadly to life show that life could have flourished under cover for the time necessary for its appearance and maintenance. Another argument for the possibility of a very old supercivilization is that most of the objects that could be megastructures have not yet been discovered and mapped. In addition, 95% of the [matter remains invisible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_matter "Dark matter") or can only be inferred by the gravitational influence it produces.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-6)

According to Kardashev, it is essential to focus our search tools on new objects radiating at a wavelength of a few microns to a few millimeters, and at a temperature of 3 to 300 [K](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kelvin "Kelvin"), which is characteristic of large structures of solid matter.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-14) It would then be possible to detect structures belonging to Type¬†II in our galaxy or in those nearby. Type¬†III structures can also be observed at large cosmological distances. Kardashev recalls that a study was conducted on 3000 sources of the [IRAS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRAS "IRAS") catalog from the four directions of the sky. Two temperature bands were targeted: from 110 to 120 K and from 280 to 290 K. The analysis showed that the 110‚Äì120 K sources are clustered in the [Galactic plane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_plane "Galactic plane") and in its center. Kardashev explains that only more powerful observations in the [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared "Infrared") and [submillimeter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Submillimetre_astronomy "Submillimetre astronomy") range can reveal possible artificial sources of radiation. He then refers to projects that he has proposed, in particular that of putting into orbit a [cryogenic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryogenics "Cryogenics") [space telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space_telescope "Space telescope") (the _Millimetron Project_).[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-6)[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-15)

According to Kardashev, these results, combined with those of other research on the age of certain cosmic objects, suggest that civilizations dating from 6 to 8 billion years ago may exist in our galaxy. It is likely that they have long since discovered our own civilization, a hypothesis that could answer the question posed by [Enrico Fermi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enrico_Fermi "Enrico Fermi") when he formulated his [paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_paradox "Fermi paradox"): "Where are they?". Without the discovery of artificial sources, however, Shklovsky's theory that civilizations self-destruct as a result of large-scale social conflicts would be proven. Kardashev mentions another hypothesis that, in his opinion, is capable of explaining the dynamics of the supercivilizations: the "feedback effect" (theorized by [Sebastian von Hoerner](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sebastian_von_Hoerner "Sebastian von Hoerner") in 1975),[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-16) which is based on the [hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypothesis "Hypothesis") that at a high technological level, civilizations tend to converge rather than to isolate themselves. The distance between supercivilizations could then be determined by half the time of the technological evolution of the oldest civilization, which would be about 3 to 4 billion years. On the other hand, this supercivilization may not have been present in our galaxy for a long time. Kardashev concludes by saying that since the [expansion of the Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expansion_of_the_universe "Expansion of the universe") is infinite, the number and lifetime of such supercivilizations are also infinite.[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1997-6)

## Categories defined by Kardashev

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Categories defined by Kardashev")\]

The hypothetical classification, known as the Kardashev scale, distinguishes three stages in the evolution of civilizations according to the dual criteria of access and [energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy "Energy") consumption.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Darling-17)[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) The purpose of this classification is to guide the search for extraterrestrial civilizations, particularly within [SETI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_for_extraterrestrial_intelligence "Search for extraterrestrial intelligence"), in which Kardashev participated,[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Zoltan_Gal%C3%A1ntai-19) and this on the assumption that a fraction of the energy used by each type is intended for communication with other civilizations. To make this scale more understandable, Lemarchand compares the speed at which a volume of information equivalent to 100,000 average-sized books can be transmitted across the galaxy. A Type¬†II civilization can send this data using a transmission beam that lasts for only 100 seconds. A similar amount of information can be sent across [intergalactic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warm%E2%80%93hot_intergalactic_medium "Warm‚Äìhot intergalactic medium") distances of about ten million light years, with a transmission time of several weeks. A Type¬†III civilization can send the same amount of data to the entire [observable universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe "Observable universe") with a transmission time of 3 seconds.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Darling-17)[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20)

Kardashev's classification is based on the assumption of a growth rate of 1% per year. Kardashev believed that it would take humanity 3,200 years to reach Type¬†II, and 5,800 years to reach Type¬†III.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2) However, Dr. [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku") believes that humanity must increase its energy consumption by 3% per year to reach Type¬†I in 100‚Äì200 years.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-21) These types are thus separated from each other by a growth rate of several billion.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

### Type I

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Type I")\]

A civilization "close to the level currently achieved on Earth, with an energy consumption of ‚âà4√ó1019 [erg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erg "Erg")/sec" (4√ó1012¬†watts).[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1964-1) A Type¬†I civilization is usually defined as one that can harness all the energy that reaches its home planet from its parent star (for Earth, this value is about 2√ó1017¬†watts), which is about four [orders of magnitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Order_of_magnitude "Order of magnitude") higher than the amount currently achieved on Earth, with an energy consumption of ‚âà2√ó1013¬†watts by 2020. The astronomer Guillermo A. Lemarchand defined Type¬†I as a level close to today's terrestrial civilization, with an energy capacity equivalent to Earth's [solar irradiance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_irradiance "Solar irradiance"), between 1016 and 1017¬†watts.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-22)

### Type II

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Type II")\]

A civilization capable of harnessing the energy radiated by its own large star ‚Äì for example, by successfully completing a [Dyson sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere") or [Matrioshka brain](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrioshka_brain "Matrioshka brain") ‚Äì with an energy consumption of ‚âà4√ó1033¬†erg/sec.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1964-1) Lemarchand defined such civilizations as being able to harness and channel the entire radiation output of their star. The energy consumption would then be comparable to the luminosity of the [Sun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun "Sun"), about 4√ó1033¬†erg/sec (4√ó1026 [watts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watt "Watt")).[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-22)

### Type III

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Type III")\]

A civilization with energy on the scale of its own [galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy "Galaxy"), with an energy consumption of ‚âà4√ó1044¬†erg/sec.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1964-1) Lemarchand defined civilizations of this type as having access to energy comparable to the luminosity of the entire [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way") galaxy, about 4√ó1044¬†erg/sec (4√ó1037¬†watts).[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-22)

In accordance with the data available at the time, Kardashev did not go beyond a Type¬†III civilization. However, new types (0, IV, V, and VI) have been proposed.

## Reassessments of the Kardashev scale

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Reassessments of the Kardashev scale")\]

### Sagan's finer classification

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Sagan's finer classification")\]

In 1973, [Carl Sagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Sagan "Carl Sagan") discovered Kardashev's work on the classification of civilizations.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) He found that the differences between the types Kardashev identified were so great that they did not allow for the best possible modeling of the evolution of civilizations.[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gal%C3%A1ntai-2003-10) Consequently, Sagan proposes a more refined classification, still based on Kardashev's types, but integrating intermediate levels using the following [logarithmic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logarithmic_scale "Logarithmic scale") [interpolation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpolation "Interpolation") formula:[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

K=log10‚Å°W‚àí610{\\displaystyle K={\\frac {\\log \_{10}{W}-6}{10}}}![{\displaystyle K={\frac {\log _{10}{W}-6}{10}}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f175300fc34428548abfe2dc18a30771bdabe9f3),

where _K_ is the Kardashev type of a civilization and _W_ is the amount of power it uses, in watts. Thus, a _Type 1.1_ civilization would be defined by a power of 1017 watts, while a _Type 2.3_ civilization would be able to harness 1029 watts.

Moreover, the above formula could be used to extrapolate beyond Kardashev's original types. For example, a _**Type¬†0**_ civilization, not defined by Kardashev, would control about 1¬†MW of power (equivalent to having around 100 campfires burning at any given time); on Earth, the emergence of Type 0 civilizations is roughly concurrent with the [rise of civilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cradle_of_civilization#Rise_of_civilization "Cradle of civilization") in a general sense.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-25)

Sagan estimated that, according to this revised scale, 1970s humanity would be Type 0.7 (about 10 [terawatts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terawatts "Terawatts")),[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan-19732-26) equivalent to 0.16% of the power available on Earth.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Wilson-20112-27) This level is characterized, according to him, by the ability to self-destruct, which he calls "technological adolescence".[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20) In 2021, the total [world energy consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_energy_supply_and_consumption "World energy supply and consumption") was 595.15 [exajoules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joule#Exajoule "Joule") (165,319¬†[TWh](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilowatt-hour#Watt-hour_multiples "Kilowatt-hour")),[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-28) equivalent to an average power consumption of 18.87 TW or a Kardashev rating of 0.73.[\[note 1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan2sf-29)[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-30)

Sagan also suggests that, for completeness, an alphabetical scale should be added to indicate the level of [social development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_change "Social change"), expressed in the amount of information available to the civilization. Thus, a Class A civilization would be based on 106 [bits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit "Bit") of information (less than any recorded human culture), a Class B on 107, a Class C on 108, and so on. Humanity in 1973 would belong to the "0.7 H" class.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-books.google.com-31) According to Sagan, the first civilization with which humanity would come into contact could be between "1.5 J" and "1.8 K"; a galactic supercivilization would be at the "3 Q" stage, while a federation of galaxies could be at the "4 Z" stage.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20) The information and energy axes are not strictly interdependent, so even a level Z civilization would not have to be Kardashev Type¬†III.[\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-books.google.com-31) Sagan believed that no civilization had yet reached level Z, speculating that so much unique information would exceed that of all the intelligent species in a [galactic supercluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_supercluster "Galactic supercluster"), and observing that the universe is not old enough to exchange information effectively over large distances.

In 2017, the total amount of information generated on the [internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet") was [26 zettabytes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zettabyte_Era "Zettabyte Era") (with an estimated 120 zettabytes in 2023),[\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-32) equivalent to 0.73 R/S on Sagan's combined scale.[\[note 1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan2sf-29)

### Kaku and the knowledge economy

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: Kaku and the knowledge economy")\]

In _[Physics of the Future](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics_of_the_Future "Physics of the Future")_ (2011), American physicist [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku") examines the conditions for humanity to converge on a Type¬†I planetary civilization. This convergence is based primarily on the [knowledge economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_economy "Knowledge economy"). Kaku uses the Kardashev scale, but develops it by adding an additional stage: a Type¬†IV civilization would be able to draw the energy it needs from [extragalactic radiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extragalactic_cosmic_ray "Extragalactic cosmic ray"). By studying the evolution of technologies that have changed history ( [paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paper "Paper"), the [integrated circuit](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated circuit")), Kaku believes that humanity is moving toward a civilization of planetary dimensions, the "starting point" of which is the [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet").[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Hamish-2012-33)

A Type¬†I civilization consumes [power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_(physics) "Power (physics)") on the order of thousands to millions of times our current planetary output, about 100 trillion trillion watts. It would have enough energy to manipulate the occurrence of certain natural phenomena, such as [earthquakes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake") or [volcanoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Volcano "Volcano"), and could build cities on the [oceans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocean "Ocean"). We can see the beginnings of a Type¬†I civilization in the fact that a global language is developing ( [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/English_language "English language")), a global communication system is emerging (the [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet")), a global economic system is in the making (the establishment of the [European Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/European_Union "European Union")), and even a globalized culture is standardizing humanity ( [mass media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_media "Mass media"), [television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Television "Television"), [rock music](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rock_music "Rock music"), and [Hollywood movies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cinema_of_the_United_States "Cinema of the United States")).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2) To achieve Type¬†I, humanity must be able to communicate with the rest of the world and to focus on several areas: building [infrastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrastructure "Infrastructure") to facilitate communication and cooperation, [education](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Education "Education"), [research and development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development"), and [innovation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Innovation "Innovation"), as well as building strong ties between [diasporas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaspora "Diaspora") and their countries of origin, and between migrants and non-migrants.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Hamish-2012-33) If development fails, it is likely that the world will not be able to achieve Type¬†II. If these areas do not develop, Kaku predicts that humanity will sink into the "abyss":[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Hamish-2012-33) an advanced civilization must grow faster than the frequency of occurrence of [extinction-level](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extinction-level_threat "Extinction-level threat") cosmic catastrophes, such as [comet or asteroid impacts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_event "Impact event"). A Type¬†I civilization should also be able to master [space travel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaceflight "Spaceflight") to deflect threatening objects. It would also have to anticipate the onset of [ice ages](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_age "Ice age") and modify the climate long before they occur to avoid them.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

In addition, in his books _[Hyperspace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperspace_(book) "Hyperspace (book)")_ and _[Parallel Worlds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parallel_Worlds_(book) "Parallel Worlds (book)")_, Michio Kaku has discussed a Type¬†IV civilization that could harness "extragalactic" energy sources such as [dark energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_energy "Dark energy").[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-ParallelWorlds-34)

### Zubrin's planet mastery

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=17 "Edit section: Zubrin's planet mastery")\]

In _Entering Space: Creating a Spacefaring Civilization_, [Robert Zubrin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_Zubrin "Robert Zubrin") suggests another form: his definition of a Type¬†I civilization is described as one that has achieved full mastery of the resources of its planet (global), a Type¬†II of its solar system (interplanetary), and a Type¬†III would have unleashed the full potential of the galaxy (starfaring civilization). Metrics other than pure energy consumption have also been proposed.[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Entering_Space-3)

He ponders the possibility of a Type¬†IV civilization, one that would dominate the universe, noting that there are limits to how minds can connect and interact on a galactic or intergalactic basis. As an example, he mentions that communication from the [Galactic Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Center "Galactic Center") of the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way") galaxy to its edge would take about 50,000 years (since [nothing can travel faster than light](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Superluminal_communication "Superluminal communication"), according to our understanding of physics).[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-35)[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Entering_Space-3)

### Barrow's microdimensional mastering

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=18 "Edit section: Barrow's microdimensional mastering")\]

The astronomer [John D. Barrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_D._Barrow "John D. Barrow") of the [University of Sussex](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Sussex "University of Sussex") has hypothesized that there are other stages beyond Type¬†III. These Type¬†IV, V, or even VI civilizations would be able to manipulate cosmic structures (galaxies, galactic clusters, superclusters) and even escape the [Big Crunch](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Crunch "Big Crunch") through holes in space.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

Barrow also proposes an "anti-Kardashev scale": he observes that humans have found it more cost effective to extend their ability to manipulate their environment to smaller and smaller scales rather than to larger and larger ones. He, therefore, proposes a reverse classification, from Type¬†I-minus to Type Omega-minus:

- **[Type I-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_engineering "Mechanical engineering")** is capable of manipulating objects on the scale of itself: building structures, mining, joining and breaking solids;
- **[Type II-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Medical_engineering "Medical engineering")** is capable of manipulating [genes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene "Gene") and altering the development of living things, transplanting or replacing parts of themselves, reading and manipulating their [genetic code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_code "Genetic code");
- **[Type III-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_engineering "Molecular engineering")** is capable of manipulating [molecules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecule "Molecule") and [molecular bonds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Covalent_bond "Covalent bond"), creating new materials;
- **[Type IV-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology")** is capable of manipulating individual [atoms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atom "Atom"), creating nanotechnology at the atomic level, and creating complex forms of [artificial life](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_life "Artificial life");
- **[Type V-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_engineering "Nuclear engineering")** is capable of manipulating the [atomic nucleus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atomic_nucleus "Atomic nucleus") and engineering the [nucleons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nucleon "Nucleon") that compose it;
- **[Type VI-minus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Femtotechnology "Femtotechnology")** is capable of manipulating the most elementary particles of matter ( [quarks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quark "Quark") and [leptons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lepton "Lepton")) to create organized complexity among populations of elementary particles;
- **Type Omega-minus** is capable of manipulating the fundamental structure of [space and time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacetime "Spacetime").[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Impossibility:_Limits_of_Science_and_the_Science_of_Limits-36)

_In Impossibility: The Limits of Science and the Science of Limits_ (1998), Barrow proposes a scale ranging from "BI" to "BVI", with an ultimate stage he calls "BŒ©", the former characterized by the possibility of manipulating one's environment, while the latter allows for the modification of [spacetime](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacetime "Spacetime").[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-37)

### Gal√°ntai's miniaturization and resilience to catastrophes

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Gal√°ntai's miniaturization and resilience to catastrophes")\]

[![Color illustration. A burning object pierces the surface of a much larger object.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Impact_event.jpg/500px-Impact_event.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Impact_event.jpg) For Zoltan Gal√°ntai, a scale classifying civilizations should be based on their ability to survive catastrophes, particularly those of cosmic origin, such as an [asteroid impact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_event "Impact event").

[Zoltan Gal√°ntai](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zoltan_Gal%C3%A1ntai&action=edit&redlink=1 "Zoltan Gal√°ntai (page does not exist)") recognizes the important role that Kardashev's classification has played in the SETI program, but he believes that another scale is possible, without using energy consumption, by resorting to miniaturization. The hypothesis of Donald Tarter, researcher at SETI, is that a civilization based on [nanotechnology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology") would not need an ever-increasing amount of energy. A Type¬†I civilization that masters local space travel could colonize its planetary system and even the [Oort cloud](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oort_cloud "Oort cloud") without needing an amount of energy that would make it Type¬†II.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) This scale loses its meaning beyond Type¬†II, since it is impossible to predict the evolution of civilizations over long distances in a galactic colonization process. Finally, the Kardashev scale is the product of an era of insufficient scientific knowledge, which considered the possibility of stellar object [CTA-102](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CTA-102 "CTA-102") as an artificial Type¬†III source, whereas today we know that it is a [galactic nucleus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_galactic_nucleus "Active galactic nucleus").[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23)

In another article, Zoltan Gal√°ntai suggests considering another scale, no longer based on energy consumption, but on a civilization's ability to survive natural and cosmic disasters. Type¬†I would describe a civilization capable of surviving a local natural disaster, like the [Anasazi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ancestral_Puebloans "Ancestral Puebloans"). A Type¬†II civilization would have the means to withstand a regional or continental disaster, and finally Type¬†III could face a global disaster such as an [asteroid's impact](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impact_event "Impact event"), a [supervolcano](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supervolcano "Supervolcano")'s eruption, or an [ice age](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_age "Ice age"). Beyond the first three types are civilizations that have scattered throughout the galaxy. The Type¬†IV civilization would still be vulnerable to some cosmic threats, while the Type¬†V civilization would be technically immortal, as no cosmic catastrophe could reach it.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) The Kardashev scale can be a relevant tool for preventing catastrophes, whether human or natural, according to Richard Wilson, who relates this scale to the power of destruction, in [TNT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNT "TNT"). A Type¬†I civilization would use 25 [megatons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TNT_equivalent "TNT equivalent") of equivalent TNT per second, a Type¬†II civilization 4 √ó 109 times more (4 billion hydrogen bombs per second), while a Type¬†III civilization would use 1011 times more.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Wilson-20112-27)

## Progression through the types

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Progression through the types")\]

Further information: [World energy supply and consumption](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_energy_supply_and_consumption "World energy supply and consumption")

### Towards type I

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: Towards type I")\]

According to Carl Sagan, Type¬†I should be reached around 2100.[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Hamish-2012-33)

Physicist and futurist [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku") has suggested that, if humans increase their energy consumption at an average rate of 3 percent per year, they could reach Type¬†I status in 100‚Äì200¬†years, Type¬†II status in a few thousand years, and Type¬†III status in 100,000 to a million years.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Interstellar_Travel-38)

Physicist [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson") has calculated that Type¬†I should be reached in about 200 years,[\[38\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-:05-39) while Richard Carrigan has estimated that the Earth is just four-tenths of the way to Type¬†I on the Sagan scale. If Type¬†I is reached soon (in the year 3000 for [Richard Wilson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Wilson_(physicist) "Richard Wilson (physicist)")),[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Wilson-2010-40) it would be accompanied by profound social upheavals, but also by a significant risk of self-destruction.[\[39\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Wilson-2010-40)

According to Per Calissendorff, energy consumption cannot be the main parameter to explain the transition from one type to another. Civilizations must have the means to maintain their growth rate despite climatic conditions and major natural disasters, even on the cosmic scale. A civilization moving towards Type¬†II must have mastered [space travel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spaceflight "Spaceflight"), [interplanetary communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interplanetary_communications "Interplanetary communications"), [stellar engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_engineering "Stellar engineering"), and [climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_engineering "Climate engineering"). It must also have developed a planetary communication system, such as the [Internet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Internet "Internet").[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) For Michio Kaku, the only serious threat to a Type¬†II civilization would be the explosion of a nearby [supernova](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supernova "Supernova"), while no known cosmic catastrophe would be capable of wiping out a Type¬†III civilization.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

According to [Philip T. Metzger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philip_T._Metzger "Philip T. Metzger"), humanity has reached Type¬†I, but faces an energy challenge. In his 2011 paper _Nature's Way of Making Audacious Space Projects Viable_, he states that the Earth's [non-renewable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Non-renewable_resource "Non-renewable resource") energy sources are nearly exhausted; [natural gas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_gas "Natural gas") will be depleted by 2020‚Äì2030, [coal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coal "Coal") by 2035, [uranium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uranium "Uranium") by 2056, while [oil production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraction_of_petroleum "Extraction of petroleum") peaked in 2006‚Äì2008.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Metzger-2011-41) [Nuclear energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_power "Nuclear power") cannot fully meet the world's energy needs (it represented only 6% in 2011). In addition, renewable energy cannot meet the growing demand for energy. Most of the minerals used by humans are in danger of becoming scarce; 11 minerals are already classified as having passed their peak production. For Metzger, humanity must therefore undertake a "100-year project" aimed at building a spacecraft ("100 Year Starship") capable of accessing the vast energy resources of the [Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System").[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Metzger-2011-41) For Metzger, it is even probable that if extraterrestrials coveted the energy resources of our Solar System, they would not look for them on Earth, but on the various [asteroids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid") and [planetoids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_planet "Minor planet"). [Robotics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics "Robotics") is the only way to access so many dispersed resources, and humanity should embark on a second long-term project, which Metzger calls the "robotsphere", that would begin with the energetic exploitation of the [Moon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moon "Moon") (estimated at 2.3 √ó 1013 [J](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joule "Joule")/year). This first step would make it possible to reach Type¬†II in 53 years. Then the robotsphere ( [self-replicating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replicating_machine "Self-replicating machine") and [self-learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning "Machine learning") automated probes) would extend to the rest of the Solar System. Current advances in [artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence "Artificial intelligence") suggest that the foundations of a robotsphere could be reached early in the next century, beginning in 2100. Metzger sees eight benefits for humanity in building the 100 Year Starship, including zero launch costs because the spacecraft will be built in space by robots that can do so with little human assistance (drastically reducing manufacturing costs), the creation of a Solar System-wide economy, and the use of resources from celestial objects and possibly [terraforming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terraforming "Terraforming") them.[\[40\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Metzger-2011-41)

### Towards type II

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Towards type II")\]

[Viorel Badescu](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Viorel_Badescu&action=edit&redlink=1 "Viorel Badescu (page does not exist)")¬†\[ [ro](https://ro.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mihail_Viorel_B%C4%83descu "ro:Mihail Viorel BƒÉdescu")\] and [Richard Cathcart](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Cathcart "Richard Cathcart") have studied the possibility that a Type¬†II civilization could use a 450 million kilometer device to direct [solar radiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_irradiance "Solar irradiance") and thus be able to impart a kinetic motion to its star that deviates it from its usual trajectory by about 35 to 40 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec "Parsec"),[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Badescu-2006-42) allowing it, among other things, to capture its [energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy "Energy") and navigate the galaxy.[\[42\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-43)[\[41\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Badescu-2006-42)

For Claude Semay, "a Type¬†II civilization could be detected at great distances (by what is called "astro-technical leakage"),\[ _[verification needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability")_\] provided that it is not located in a region of the galaxy that is too distant from us, or that it does not occupy a location that is obscured from us by clouds of gas or dust".[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Semay-1998-44)

### Towards type III

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Towards type III")\]

[![Color illustration. A yellow-orange disc in the center is pierced vertically by a spiral of filaments.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9e/Gb1508_illustration.jpg/500px-Gb1508_illustration.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Gb1508_illustration.jpg) Artist's view of [quasar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasar "Quasar") GB1508. According to Russian astronomer Kardashev, a highly evolved civilization, known as "Type¬†III" in his theoretical classification, would be able to draw its energy from such a source.

A Type¬†III civilization should be detectable because of the large amount of radiation captured on a galaxy-wide scale. Calissendorff suggests using 75% of the total light emitted by a galaxy to determine that a Type¬†III civilization uses many [Dyson spheres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere"). If only three or four of these spheres occupy the galaxy, it does not necessarily mean that the civilization has reached Type¬†III, and it may still be in transition;[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) however, such civilizations may remain beyond the reach of our understanding and instruments. Sagan believes that the nearest Type¬†III civilization is at an average distance of 10,000 light-years from us, but that it is not interested in classical radio transmissions, being of a different technological level. Only small, low-level civilizations could communicate with us.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan-19732-26)

Semay observes that "a Type¬†III civilization should not be confused with what science fiction writers call a ' [galactic empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_empire "Galactic empire")'", knowing that it can only exist if [interstellar travel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_travel "Interstellar travel") is achieved. Semay argues that there is no evidence that this will ever be possible.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Semay-1998-44) Based on Dyson's calculations, Semay believes that such a journey would take three centuries, with an average distance between stars of about 7 light years. Overall, the speed of the colonization front, which ranges from 4 √ó 10‚àí4 to 5 √ó 10‚àí3 light-years per year, would result in humanity spreading throughout the galaxy in a period of 16 to 200 million years.[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Semay-1998-44) "A Type¬†III civilization, having thus "domesticated" its galaxy by building a large number of Dyson spheres, would be detectable over intergalactic distances of several million light-years."[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Semay-1998-44)

A Type¬†III civilization could theoretically live inside a [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black hole"), in a stable periodic orbit, which would make it completely undetectable, according to V. I. Dokuchaev.[\[44\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-45)

### Towards type IV

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Towards type IV")\]

Zoltan Gal√°ntai notes that neither Kardashev nor Sagan thought to extend the scale and define a Type¬†IV (which would use the energy of an entire Universe). They simply did not envision a civilization capable of manipulating its environment on the largest possible scale (about 14 billion [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec "Parsec")).[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gal%C3%A1ntai-2003-10) The concept of a Type¬†IV supercivilization approaches divine possibilities, enabling the creation of, and travel through, [alternate universes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiverse "Multiverse") of such a civilization's own design,[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gal%C3%A1ntai-2003-10) although the latter possibility is reserved for a Type¬†V civilization by Carrigan.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24) The fraction of energy captured by a civilization capable of powering itself on a black hole could also be used to classify civilizations.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Inoue-2011-46)

## Possible scenarios

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Possible scenarios")\]

According to Kardashev, the most important parameters to define the existence of a civilization are three: the presence of very powerful energy sources, the use of non-standard technologies, and the transmission of significant amounts of information of various kinds through space.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

### Energy sources

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Energy sources")\]

Kardashev's classification is based on the hypothesis that an advanced civilization uses significant energy, which implies that it must be de facto detectable over long distances, as summarized by Zoltan Gal√°ntai.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) For Kardashev, the limit of a civilization's energy consumption is originally located in the region of the [electromagnetic spectrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum "Electromagnetic spectrum") from 106 to 108 Hz, which allows two observations related to [thermodynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermodynamics "Thermodynamics"). First, all the energy consumed is inevitably converted into heat. Second, this energy can only be dissipated in the form of radiation scattered in space. These two findings are the pillars of Kardashev's theory that cosmic objects with strong radiation could be artificial sources.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) He also considered the possibility of detecting an artificial source by emphasizing the [spectral line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_line "Spectral line") of [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen") in its use for [nuclear fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fusion "Nuclear fusion").[\[47\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-48)

Dutil and Dumas consider several physical limits to continuous energy production, such as [photosynthesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photosynthesis "Photosynthesis") (about 10 [TW](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terawatt "Terawatt")), climate (about 127 TW), and [solar flux](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_irradiance "Solar irradiance") (174,000 TW). The only inexhaustible source of energy that can sustain a civilization for over several billion years, is [deuterium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deuterium "Deuterium") (used in [nuclear fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fusion "Nuclear fusion")).[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Dutil-2007-49) The sustainability of a civilization must therefore involve "strict control of the exploitation of available resources"; this difficulty in exceeding energy limits may explain the fact that the vast majority of civilizations fail to engage in a space colonization project.[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Dutil-2007-49)

Astrophysicist Makoto Inoue and economist Hiromitsu Yokoo have explored the possibility that a Type¬†III civilization could extract energy from a [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black hole") (SMBH). The captured energy could meet the extraordinary needs of a civilization that requires about 4 √ó 1044 erg/s.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Inoue-2011-46) The energy would be captured in the form of radiation emitted by the matter rushing into the star, by means of collectors located within the [accretion disk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accretion_disk "Accretion disk"). These collectors are similar to Dyson spheres. The overflow, as well as the waste of the civilization, would be redirected towards the black hole. A fraction of this energy, directed as a [high-powered beam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maser "Maser"), could be useful for space travel. A galactic club of civilizations could transmit the energy through networks within the galaxy. Within the various central power stations that make up the network, power transmission is periodically switched between transmitter and receiver, according to the galactic rotation. To be efficient, this network should be located at the center of the galaxy.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Inoue-2011-46)

### The technology

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: The technology")\]

Further information: [Stellar engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_engineering "Stellar engineering") and [Megastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megastructure "Megastructure")

This parameter is one of the most undetectable in the Universe due to the fact that solid matter structures are at low temperatures and emit weak radiation. Their luminosity, which is difficult to observe, also makes it impossible to observe them with telescopes. Likewise, we cannot detect them by their [gravitational effects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity "Gravity").[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) However their existence can be detected by analyzing [wavelengths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength") between 8 and 13 microns, corresponding to surface temperatures of 300 K. A hypothetical [Dyson sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere") could thus be detected,[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24) provided that the observation is made from space. Locally, the significant dip in luminosity that would result from a giant Dyson sphere (or "Fermi bubble") would allow the detection of a Type¬†III civilization.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

A [megastructure](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megastructure "Megastructure") like a Dyson sphere could be the result of a technology based on [self-replicating probes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replicating_machine "Self-replicating machine"), as those imagined by [von Neumann](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_von_Neumann "John von Neumann"). A Type¬†III civilization would have the means to disperse a significant number of these spheres throughout the galaxy, which would have the effect of attenuating the light emitted by the galaxy.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) Kaku also considers this to be the most efficient method of colonizing space. For example, a galaxy 100,000 light years in diameter would be explored in half a million years.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2) [Paul Davies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Davies "Paul Davies") has suggested that a civilization could colonize the galaxy by scattering miniature probes, no larger than the palm of a hand, using [nanotechnology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology"). This thesis is realistic, he explains, because it is obvious that the technology is becoming increasingly miniaturized and proportionally less expensive.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

Type¬†II megastructures would be easier to detect. This would be the case of a [Dyson sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere") used as a " [stellar engine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_engine "Stellar engine")",[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Badescu-50) as well as the contribution of heavy elements.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24) Similarly, "Shkadov thrusters", which would produce a lateral thrust of 4.4 [parsecs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parsec "Parsec") on their star by reflecting solar radiation through a structure made of mirrors, would be observable objects. This device would break the symmetry of solar radiation and counteract [gravitational forces](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity "Gravity"), allowing a Type¬†II civilization to move its home solar system through space.[\[50\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-51)[\[49\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Badescu-50) Drake and Shklovski have also considered the possibility of "seeding" a star (Stellar salting) by artificially adding extremely rare elements such as [technetium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technetium "Technetium") or [promethium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Promethium "Promethium"). Such an intervention in a star's composition would be detectable.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

It is still possible that humanity could discover traces of lost Type¬†I, II, or III civilizations. The search for material traces of such civilizations (e.g. Dyson spheres or stellar engines), an "interesting alternative" to the conventional SETI program, lays the foundation for a " [cosmic archaeology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenoarchaeology "Xenoarchaeology")" according to Richard A. Carrigan. Efforts to detect intelligence markers in the atmospheres of [exoplanets](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exoplanet "Exoplanet") (such as [freon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freon "Freon"), [oxygen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen"), or even [ozone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ozone "Ozone"), residues of biotic activity according to [James Lovelock](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Lovelock "James Lovelock")'s research)[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24) are one of the most promising avenues. A civilization watching its star die (as a [red giant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_giant "Red giant"), for example) could have tried to prolong its existence through megastructures that should be detectable.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24) The possible traces could be nuclear remnants, to be sought within the [spectral types](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_classification "Stellar classification") going from [A5](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A-type_main-sequence_star "A-type main-sequence star") to [F2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_sequence "Main sequence") according to Whitmire and Wright.[\[51\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-52) It could also be a change in the [isotopic ratio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_abundance "Natural abundance"), due to a stellar engine, or an unusual spectral modulation in the composition of the star.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

### The interstellar transmission of information

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: The interstellar transmission of information")\]

Further information: [Interstellar communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstellar_communication "Interstellar communication")

[![Color illustration. Geometric shapes in various colors are drawn on a black background.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/SETI%40home_%28version_8.19%29.png/500px-SETI%40home_%28version_8.19%29.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:SETI@home_(version_8.19).png) A screenshot of the [SETI@home](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SETI@home "SETI@home") computer program

According to Kardashev, the transmissions of an extraterrestrial civilization (what [SERENDIP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SERENDIP "SERENDIP") is looking for) can be divided into two types. On the one hand, there can be an exchange of information between highly developed civilizations or civilizations at similar stages of evolution. On the other hand, the transmission of information can be aimed at raising the level of other less developed civilizations. If supercivilizations do exist, the transmissions of the first type must remain inaccessible to our observation because they must be unidirectional and not be directed toward the [Solar System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System"). Conversely, those of the second type must be easily detectable by our listening devices.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

A signal of artificial origin should contain more than 10 and less than 100 [bits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bit "Bit"). The latter would be of two types: transient and stable. Several criteria allow us to distinguish a signal of artificial origin from others. First, the optimal region of the spectrum to host artificial signals is the one where the temperature of the [cosmic microwave background](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_microwave_background "Cosmic microwave background") is the lowest.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Second, artificial sources must have a minimum angular size. The presence of suspicious data in other regions of the spectrum (such as [circular polarization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circular_polarization "Circular polarization"), radio and optical frequencies,[\[52\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-53) or [X-ray emissions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrophysical_X-ray_source "Astrophysical X-ray source")) can confirm that it is an intelligent transmission. Two sources among those studied have parameters close to those expected: 1934-63 and [3C 273B](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_273 "3C 273").[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

For L. M. Gindilis, there are two criteria for a signal to be called artificial: one related to the artificial nature of the source and the other related to a particular radiation, intentionally designed to ensure communication and facilitate detection.[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gindilis-1971-54) Only Type¬†II or III civilizations can communicate using [isotropic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isotropy "Isotropy") transmissions that allow omnidirectional reception. In a 1¬†MHz band (which requires about 1024 watts), detection of signals from a Type¬†II civilization is possible up to 1,000 [light-years](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light-year "Light-year") away, while signals from a Type¬†III civilization are detectable virtually throughout the [observable Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe "Observable universe").[\[53\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gindilis-1971-54) However, building an omnidirectional transmitter powerful enough to transmit over a range of 1,000 light years would take several million years. According to V.S. Troitsky, the energy required and the limitations in its production would be two obstacles to completing this project in a reasonable time.[\[54\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-55)

For Zoltan Gal√°ntai, we would not be able to distinguish between an intelligent extraterrestrial signal and a signal of natural origin. Therefore, he does not believe that Type¬†II, III or even IV civilizations can be detected. Even if humanity reaches Type¬†IV, it will not be able to detect another supercivilization of a similar level, and we will consider their changes in the universe to be the result of natural causes. Thus, there may be many Type¬†IV civilizations in the universe, but none of them will be able to detect the others. Moreover, the dimensions of the universe make these supercivilizations like islands far from the others, which Dyson defines as a " [Carroll](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Carroll "Lewis Carroll") Universe".[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Gal%C3%A1ntai-2003-10)

For Alexander L. Zaitsev, the radio transmission of interstellar messages (IRM) is the most likely method used by civilizations. Planetary [radio telescopes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_telescope "Radio telescope") and those installed on [asteroids](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asteroid "Asteroid") would make it possible to listen to the many messages that could be sent to us.[\[55\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-56) In 2007, the [SETI program](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_for_extraterrestrial_intelligence "Search for extraterrestrial intelligence") analyzed the only television frequencies sent by a Type¬†0 civilization, notes [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku"). Therefore, our galaxy may have communications from Type¬†II and III civilizations, but our listening devices can only detect Type¬†0 messages.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

## Search and detection of civilizations

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Search and detection of civilizations")\]

### The Byurakan Conference (1964)

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: The Byurakan Conference (1964)")\]

From 1962, Kardashev was a member of a [SETI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_for_extraterrestrial_intelligence "Search for extraterrestrial intelligence") research group at the [Sternberg Astronomical Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sternberg_Astronomical_Institute "Sternberg Astronomical Institute") in Moscow. In 1964, he organized the first [Soviet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_people "Soviet people") conference on the possibility of extraterrestrial civilizations, which was held at the Byurakan astrophysical observatory in [Armenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Armenia "Armenia").[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Darling-2-57) This national conference was held in response to the American seminar known as the _Green Bank conference_ of 1961, which was held at the [Green Bank observatory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Green_Bank_Observatory "Green Bank Observatory") in the United States.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Spangenburg-2004-58) It brought together [radio astronomers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radio_astronomy "Radio astronomy") with the aim of "finding rational technical and linguistic solutions to the problem of communication with an extraterrestrial civilization that is more advanced than the Earth's civilization". Kardashev presented his classification, while Troitskii announced that it was possible to detect signals from other galaxies.[\[58\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-59)

For Kardashev, "in the next 5 to 10 years, all the sources of radiation with the largest observable flux, in all the regions of the [electromagnetic spectrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum "Electromagnetic spectrum"), will have been discovered and studied", the sensitivity of the listening devices having indeed reached their technical limits. According to him, the entire electromagnetic spectrum will be known and, consequently, the list of the objects that could be artificial sources could thus be extended. The search for artificial signals will then have to concentrate on objects of maximum [luminosity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luminosity "Luminosity") or radiation belonging to a certain region of the spectrum, but also on objects of significant mass, and on those that represent the essence of matter in the Universe. As early as 1971, Kardashev considered that this observation requires the preparation of a plan of listening and analysis, which will allow the success of the search for extraterrestrial civilizations. Humanity will then be able to solve the " [main dilemma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermi_paradox "Fermi paradox")", as it was stated by [Enrico Fermi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enrico_Fermi "Enrico Fermi").[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) This dilemma is, according to the Soviet astronomer, is certainly connected with our lack of information and knowledge.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)[\[59\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-60)

Kardashev believes that a research project like [Ozma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Ozma "Project Ozma") is incapable of detecting a Type¬†I civilization (an idea also promoted by Kaplan in 1971),[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-:0-61) and that SETI should instead focus on searching for intense radio signals that could emanate from active Type¬†II or III civilizations.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) To prove the effectiveness of this approach, Kardashev therefore turned his attention to two radio sources discovered by the [California Institute of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology "California Institute of Technology"), nicknamed CTA-21 and [CTA-102](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CTA-102 "CTA-102"). Subsequently, Gennadii Borisovich Sholomitskii then used the Russian astronomical research station to study the data from CTA-102.[\[57\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Spangenburg-2004-58) He found that this [radio source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_radio_source "Astronomical radio source") is characterized by its variability. Kardashev then considered that this could be an indication of an artificial emission source, albeit of rather short life span.[\[56\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Darling-2-57)

### Towards a "physical eschatology"

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Towards a \"physical eschatology\"")\]

The knowledge of these hypothetical supercivilizations must fit into a wide range of [physical laws](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_law "Scientific law") that contain the entirety of our current knowledge, since the technical and scientific developments of mankind can be considered as an inevitable and necessary stage in the process of the evolution of a [civilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civilization "Civilization"). Based on this principle, Kardashev proposes to define several concepts applicable to extraterrestrial civilizations.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) The physical laws, which are universal, can be used as a common basis for understanding other civilizations and, in particular, allow us to develop an objective research program.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku") also believes that the evolution of civilizations obeys the "iron laws of physics" and in particular the [laws of thermodynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laws_of_thermodynamics "Laws of thermodynamics"), those of stable matter ( [baryonic matter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baryon "Baryon")) and those of [planetary evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System") (probability of occurrence of natural or cosmic catastrophes).[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2) The [anthropic principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anthropic_principle "Anthropic principle") also makes it possible to predict the sociological characteristics at the basis of any civilization.[\[61\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-62)

However, these universal laws are not the only parameters to consider. Zoltan Gal√°ntai explains that "it is impossible to calculate the future of the Universe over long periods of time without including the effects of life and intelligence", a position close to that of [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson").[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Zoltan_Gal%C3%A1ntai-19) Taking into account these two phenomena, the universal physical laws and the [intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligence "Intelligence") resulting from life, defines a "physical [eschatology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eschatology "Eschatology")", as Gal√°ntai puts it. This approach began in the 1970s with the work of Kardashev, and then physical eschatology gradually interested a number of scientists and thinkers, notes Dyson.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Zoltan_Gal%C3%A1ntai-19)

### A functional definition of civilization

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: A functional definition of civilization")\]
