[![On a black background, a round luminous glow.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Messier_87_Hubble_WikiSky.jpg/500px-Messier_87_Hubble_WikiSky.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Messier_87_Hubble_WikiSky.jpg) Galaxy [M87](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_87 "Messier 87") has an [active galactic nucleus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_galactic_nucleus "Active galactic nucleus"), providing a strong [source of radiation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ultraluminous_X-ray_source "Ultraluminous X-ray source") in all [wavelengths](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength"). This type of radiation was considered by Kardashev to be one of the possible signals of an advanced civilization.

Observation of the development of [living organisms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Organism "Organism") shows that they are characterized by the tendency to store a maximum amount of [information](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information "Information"), both about the environment and about themselves. This information then leads to an abstract analysis, which plays an important role in the development of life forms. Thus, Kardashev defines civilization from a functional perspective as "a state of very stable matter capable of acquiring, abstractly analyzing and applying information in order to extract data about the environment and itself, in order to develop survival reactions ".[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) However, this [functional definition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatism "Pragmatism") of civilization implies that it cannot have a [goal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goal "Goal") or end, since it is based on the principle of accumulating more and more information. Taking up von Hoerner's categories, Kardashev sees four possible scenarios for the development of civilizations:

1. Total destruction of life.
2. Destruction of only intelligent life.
3. Degeneration.
4. Loss of interest.

However, he refuses to see these as inevitable ends. But the assumption that the only limit to the development of a civilization can be the existence of a finite amount of information, in all areas, is also false, since it is highly improbable that information in the Universe is infinite.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Given these two [hypotheses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypothesis "Hypothesis"), Kardashev argues that there is no universal civilization (supercivilization) because highly developed civilizations lose interest in space exploration. In any case, and despite the problem of the end of civilizations, he concludes, in the light of his functional definition of the advanced civilization, that the latter must use mass and energy on fantastic scales. According to him, there is no reason to denounce the hypothesis that the [expansion of the Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expansion_of_the_universe "Expansion of the universe") would not be an effect of the intelligent activity of a supercivilization.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

### Human civilization: a model for extrapolation

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Human civilization: a model for extrapolation")\]

Kardashev poses the following question: "Is it possible to describe the development of a civilization in general terms over large cosmological periods?" Now many of the fundamental parameters that characterize the development of civilization on Earth are [growing exponentially](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_growth "Exponential growth"). In the field of energy, astronomer Don Goldsmith estimated that the Earth receives about one billionth of the Sun's energy, and that humans use about one millionth of it.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2) So we consume about one millionth of a billionth of the Sun's total energy. Since human expansion is exponential, we can determine how long it will take for humanity to go from Type¬†II to Type¬†III according to [Michio Kaku](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michio_Kaku "Michio Kaku").[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kaku-2007-2)

Thus, the rate of development of our own world remains the only criterion for [extrapolating](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extrapolation "Extrapolation") the state of civilizations older than humanity.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) The same is true for social values and basic needs according to Ashkenazi.[\[62\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-63) Therefore, the time to double technical knowledge is about ten years, and to double energy output, available reserves, and population is about 25 years. Two scenarios are then possible: spatial expansion or energy stagnation, the latter being possible only for 125 years, according to Kardashev, using the following relationship Œ±=1.04{\\displaystyle \\alpha =1.04}![{\displaystyle \alpha =1.04}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b9f4c2fdd1591a967111cdba47fcd484837f58fe):

t=log‚Å°(P/Po)log‚Å°Œ±{\\displaystyle t={\\frac {\\log \\left(P/P\_{o}\\right)}{\\log \\alpha }}}![{\displaystyle t={\frac {\log \left(P/P_{o}\right)}{\log \alpha }}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/1bdfb01e51e2cd8b1f963bfd596753e6853dd933)

where t{\\displaystyle t}![{\displaystyle t}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/65658b7b223af9e1acc877d848888ecdb4466560) is the number of years, P{\\displaystyle P}![{\displaystyle P}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b4dc73bf40314945ff376bd363916a738548d40a) is a parameter that increases annually as a function of Po{\\displaystyle P\_{o}}![{\displaystyle P_{o}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/07d20f5b8e09cda22c3552e1da5bf7c7709057d9) and of t{\\displaystyle t}![{\displaystyle t}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/65658b7b223af9e1acc877d848888ecdb4466560) according to P=PoŒ±t{\\displaystyle P=P\_{o}\\alpha ^{t}}![{\displaystyle P=P_{o}\alpha ^{t}}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/567b53a0e93fd9c6f6e645fab317cabdfd25d1ab) and Œ±{\\displaystyle \\alpha }![{\displaystyle \alpha }](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b79333175c8b3f0840bfb4ec41b8072c83ea88d3), a growth rate.

If Œ±=1.04{\\displaystyle \\alpha =1.04}![{\displaystyle \alpha =1.04}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/b9f4c2fdd1591a967111cdba47fcd484837f58fe), then humanity's energy consumption will exceed the incident solar power (1.742 √ó‚ÄØ1017W) after 240 years, the total power of the [Sun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun "Sun") (3.826 √ó‚ÄØ1026W) after 800 years, and that of the Galaxy (7.29 √ó‚ÄØ1036W) after 1,500 years.[\[note 2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-64)[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Based on this calculation, Zuckerman estimates the number of civilizations that could exist in our [galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galaxy "Galaxy") at 10,000.[\[63\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-65) Kardashev concludes that the current exponential growth is a transitional phase in the development of a civilization, and that it is inevitably limited by natural factors. In fact, he believes that the required [mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass "Mass") and [energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy "Energy") will continue to grow exponentially for another 1,000 years.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Civilization is thus defined by an exponential rate of increase. Humanity as a model for thinking about the development of extraterrestrial civilizations has its limitations, which can be truly overcome by a [multidisciplinary approach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interdisciplinarity "Interdisciplinarity") according to the work of Kathryn Denning.[\[64\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-66)

### Research conducted

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Research conducted")\]

In 1963, Nikolai Kardashev and Gennady Borissovich Sholomitskii studied the [CTA 102](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CTA-102 "CTA-102") [radio source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_radio_source "Astronomical radio source") on the 920¬†MHz band from the _Crimea Deep Space Station_, looking for signs of a Type¬†III civilization.[\[65\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-67) CTA 102 had been discovered by Sholomitskii a year earlier, and Kardashev quickly saw it as a possible artificial source to study in order to validate his classification. The observation lasted until February 1965, and on April 12, Sholomitskii announced to the press (via the Russian [ITAR-TASS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TASS "TASS")) that Soviet astronomers had discovered a signal that could be of extraterrestrial origin. On April 14, he gave a conference in Moscow where he repeated his announcement; but by November 1964, two American astronomers had identified CTA 102 as a [quasar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasar "Quasar"), and their publication definitively closed the "CTA 102 case".[\[66\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-68) It was the study of this source that had led to the Byurakan conference in 1964.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Braude-2012-69)

In 1975 and 1976, the American astronomers [Frank Drake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Frank_Drake "Frank Drake") and [Carl Sagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Sagan "Carl Sagan") searched at [Arecibo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arecibo_Telescope "Arecibo Telescope") for signs of Type¬†II civilizations in four galaxies of the [Local Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Local_Group "Local Group"): [M33](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triangulum_Galaxy "Triangulum Galaxy"), [M49](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_49 "Messier 49"), [Leo I](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_I_(dwarf_galaxy) "Leo I (dwarf galaxy)") and [Leo II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_II_(dwarf_galaxy) "Leo II (dwarf galaxy)").[\[68\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan-1976-70)[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Freitas-2008-71) The year before, the two men had sent [mankind's first message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arecibo_message "Arecibo message") to [M13](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Messier_13 "Messier 13").[\[70\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Dick-2006-72) The results were published as "The Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence" in _[Scientific American](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_American "Scientific American")_ in May 1975.[\[71\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan-1975-73)

In 1976, Kardashev, Troitskii, and Gindilis used the [RATAN-600](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RATAN-600 "RATAN-600") radio telescope in the North Caucasus to search for signals from Type¬†II or III civilizations in the [Milky Way](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milky_Way "Milky Way") and other nearby galaxies.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Freitas-2008-71) The radio telescope was built in 1966 under the supervision of Gindilis to listen at centimeter wavelengths.[\[67\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Braude-2012-69)

In 1987, [Tarter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jill_Tarter "Jill Tarter"), Kardashev, and Slysh used the [VLA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Very_Large_Array "Very Large Array") to detect possible infrared sources near the galactic center from the [IRAS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/IRAS "IRAS") telescope catalog. All three were looking for evidence of hypothetical [Dyson spheres](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere"). The objects turn out to be [OH](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxy_group "Hydroxy group")/ [IR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared "Infrared") type stars.[\[69\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Freitas-2008-71)[\[72\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-74)

A small-scale search for possible Type¬†III sources was conducted by James Annis in 1999 and published in the _Journal of the British Interplanetary Society_ under the title "Placing a limit on star-fed Kardashev type III civilizations".[\[73\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-75) An astrophysicist at [Fermilab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermilab "Fermilab") (US), Annis studied a sample of 31 galaxies, both [spiral](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiral_galaxy "Spiral galaxy") and [elliptical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptical_galaxy "Elliptical galaxy"), using the [Tully-Fisher diagram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tully%E2%80%93Fisher_relation "Tully‚ÄìFisher relation"), in which the [absolute magnitude](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_magnitude "Absolute magnitude") is a function of the galaxies' rotational speed. Annis suggested that 75% of the least luminous objects (i.e., those with a decrease in absolute magnitude of 1.5 compared to the diagram) could be considered as possible candidates. However, no object with this characteristic is observed in his survey.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18)[\[43\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Semay-1998-44) On the other hand, Annis uses the available astronomical data to estimate the probability that a Type¬†III civilization could exist. He shows that the average time that could allow for the emergence of such a civilization is 300 billion years, so none can exist in our present Universe.[\[74\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-76)

Per Calissendorff conducted a study on a sample of spiral galaxies from two databases: 4,861 from the _Spiral Field I-band_ (SFI++ catalog compiled by Springob et al. in 2005) and 95 from that of Reyes et al. in 2011.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) The same procedure was followed as in Annis, but the sample of galaxies used is 80 times larger than that used in the Annis study.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) Some sources were classified as "lopsided": they appear [asymmetric](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetry "Symmetry") in shape, meaning that one side of the [galactic disc](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_disc "Galactic disc") is more massive and less luminous than the other. This characteristic, according to Calissendorff, could be an indication that the galaxy is home to a civilization that has placed Dyson spheres in its main part. This can be explained by the fact that the colonization starts from one side of the galactic disk, making it appear darker and leading a distant observer to believe that the core has moved to that same side.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) On the other hand, a galaxy hosting Dyson spheres should be characterized by a significant source of far- [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared "Infrared") radiation.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) The fact remains that a Type¬†III civilization can consume energy through a Dyson sphere without surrounding a star. Indeed, such [megastructures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megastructure "Megastructure") could also extract energy from a [black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole "Black hole"), according to the study by Inoue and Yokoo (2011). However, such a structure would not reduce the luminosity of an observed galaxy.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) Calissendorff's study concludes that 11 of the sources analyzed (out of a catalog of 2,411 galaxies, or 0.46%) show possible evidence of a Type¬†III civilization. Searching for objects that obscure 90% of the light leaves only one source remains that meets the criteria.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) These positive sources show a low [redshift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Redshift "Redshift") (so they are old, about 100 million years), which is consistent with possible Type¬†III civilizations, that could have flourished only in the early past.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18) To have a better chance of detecting Type¬†III artificial sources, Calissendorff suggests taking several photographs in a row, fast enough to fix the movement of turbulence in the atmosphere, applying different [photometric filters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Photometry_(astronomy) "Photometry (astronomy)") and looking for dark areas (the case of a Dyson sphere being assembled by a Type¬†II civilization), or analyzing the infrared spectrum of galaxies. A much larger sample of objects should be studied.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Calissendorff-2013-18)

### Observational evidence

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Observational evidence")\]

In 2015, a study of galactic mid- [infrared](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infrared "Infrared") emissions concluded that "Kardashev Type¬†III civilizations are either very rare or do not exist in the [local Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observable_universe "Observable universe")".[\[75\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-77)

In 2016, Paul Gilster, author of the Centauri Dreams website, described a signal apparently coming from the star [HD 164595](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HD_164595 "HD 164595") as requiring the power of a Type¬†I or Type¬†II civilization, if produced by extraterrestrial lifeforms.[\[76\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-78) In August 2016, however, it was discovered that the origin of the signal was most likely a military satellite orbiting the Earth.[\[77\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-79)

### Possible listening criteria

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Possible listening criteria")\]

#### Kardashev's point of view

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Kardashev's point of view")\]

According to Kardashev, humanity's ignorance of the physical possibilities of communication through space is great.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Only a negligible fraction of the [electromagnetic spectrum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetic_spectrum "Electromagnetic spectrum") as an existing source of information in the universe is known.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Thus, of the 89% of information that humans lack, 42% concerns the range from 109 to 1014 Hz (centimetric, millimetric, submillimetric and infrared waves) and 25% concerns the range from 1015 to 1018 Hz (ultraviolet radiation and X-rays).[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Kardashev distinguishes two categories of listening areas: objects emitting in a broad frequency spectrum and objects emitting on the contrary in a narrow [spectral line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_line "Spectral line"), the second category posing much more theoretical problems than the first, while being central, both for [astrophysics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astrophysics "Astrophysics") and for the search for extraterrestrial civilizations.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

Despite advances in astrophysics, the available information is still insufficient to prove the absence of supercivilizations, based on the inability to observe signs of activity. However, because of the possibility that there are [planetary systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Planetary_system "Planetary system") much older than the Solar System, and considering that cosmic objects such as [quasars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasar "Quasar") could be products of supercivilization activity, a detailed program of listening and searching for intelligent signs remains valid. This program includes:[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

- Monitoring the sky at 3, 10, 30, 100 and 300 microns, especially at 1, 3, and 10¬†mm, in order to identify one hundred of the most powerful sources among those observed and at each frequency;
- Study in detail the properties of quasars and other unusual objects;
- Search for monochromatic anomalies among the most powerful [radio sources](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_radio_source "Astronomical radio source") (such as a [hydroxyl](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxy_group "Hydroxy group") emission line), in the decimeter band;
- Search for periodic signals ( [pulsars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulsar "Pulsar")) of interstellar origin, in the same band;
- Searches for monochromatic signals of different frequencies, always in the same band.

According to Kardashev, only a [radio interferometer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interferometry "Interferometry") with a base, either of the order of or larger than the diameter of the [Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth "Earth"), placed in orbital space, would allow listening to centimetric and decimetric frequencies.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Once a set of unusual sources has been selected, the next step is to look for significant content in the radiations from these objects.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) In 1998, Nikolai Kardashev, S. F. Likhachev, and V. I. Zhuravlev proposed two [SETI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Search_for_extraterrestrial_intelligence "Search for extraterrestrial intelligence") space projects to detect artificial sources: the _Millimetron_ project (an orbiting observatory with a 10-meter diameter mirror) and the _VLBI optical telescope_ (for interferometric synthesis of ultraviolet, optical, and infrared images).[\[78\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-80)

#### Other leads

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Other leads")\]

For [Samuil Aronovich Kaplan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuil_Kaplan "Samuil Kaplan"), "the most reliable criterion" remains the small [angular diameter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_diameter "Angular diameter") of the radio source. The [wavelength](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wavelength "Wavelength") of 21¬†cm, privileged since 1959, according to the study of Cocconi and Morrison, is not the only listening region. Kaplan, in 1971, also mentioned the radio region of the spectrum, characterized by the [hydroxyl radical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroxyl_radical "Hydroxyl radical") (OH). For Livio, the means of detection should focus on [globular clusters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Globular_cluster "Globular cluster"), the regions most likely to harbor planets similar to the Earth.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

For Guillermo A. Lemarchand, extraterrestrial civilizations should not use an omnidirectional transmitter. Instead, they should look for signals of weak information, intermittent and unidirectional. They will certainly need to use [interferometry](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interferometry "Interferometry") to inspect planetary systems where life might appear. From Earth, it would be possible to pick up such signals at distances of up to 35 + (t\_f - 2000) / 2, where t\_f is the observation date in years, knowing that t\_f ‚â• 2000.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20) However, there are many techniques for transmitting an interstellar message, ranging from [bosons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boson "Boson") to [particles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle "Particle") and even [antiparticles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antiparticle "Antiparticle").[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-22)

An artificial source located in the [accretion disk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accretion_disk "Accretion disk") of a [supermassive black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black hole") would be undetectable by the beams used to transmit the collected energy. In fact, the probability of detecting a beam of one [micron](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micrometre "Micrometre") [arc-second](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minute_and_second_of_arc "Minute and second of arc") is less than 10‚àí23. Moreover, the energy emitted by the black hole would not allow detection of the energy used by the Type¬†III civilization. On the other hand, the [specular reflection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specular_reflection "Specular reflection") system of the radiation could be detected by the shadow it casts on the accretion disk.[\[45\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Inoue-2011-46)

A Type¬†III civilization using a " [Fermi bubble](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Galactic_Center "Galactic Center")" would be detectable by the fact that it decreases the luminosity of a region of the galaxy. An infrared observation would make it possible to highlight it, especially in [elliptical galaxies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptical_galaxy "Elliptical galaxy"), Annis suggests.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Carrigan_Jr.-20102-24)

### Unusual objects

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: Unusual objects")\]

[![Color photo. A luminous celestial object appears against a black background.](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Quasar_3C_273.jpg/500px-Quasar_3C_273.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Quasar_3C_273.jpg) Quasar [3C 273](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_273 "3C 273"), the brightest ever observed

The quasar [3C 9](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_9 "3C 9") is cited by Kardashev as early as 1971.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) The study of the quasar [3C 273](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_273 "3C 273") shows that it has a solid structure. Other quasars ( [3C 279](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_279 "3C 279"), [3C 345](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3C_345 "3C 345"), 3C 84) have properties close to those expected from an artificial source, especially since the emissions are powerful in the intermediate region of the spectrum (between radio and optical frequencies).[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47) Quasars are potential artificial sources, especially since their age corresponds to the technical possibilities of supercivilizations. Radio sources at the center of galaxies can also be artificial sources, according to Kardashev, even if in 2013 they were proven to be supermassive black holes. In 1971, Kardashev believed that the objects most likely to be artificial sources could be discovered in the \[then\] next few years.[\[46\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev-1971-47)

The extraordinary periodicity of [pulsar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pulsar "Pulsar") emissions was already considered an artificial source in 1968 by [Antony Hewish](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antony_Hewish "Antony Hewish"), the discoverer of the first pulsar ( [CP 19019](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PSR_B1919%2B21 "PSR B1919+21")). The press of the time nicknamed this object "LGM-1" (for "little green men"), following the clumsiness of Hewish, who did not wait for the necessary verifications. Kaplan, in 1971, removed the pulsar from the list of objects that could be a source of artificial origin.[\[60\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-:0-61)

In 2011, James and Dominic Benford examined the possibilities that exist to distinguish pulsars from possible artificial sources emitting intelligent signals, such as: bandwidth (signals of about 100¬†MHz could be artificial), pulse length (to reduce costs, the pulse should be short) and frequency (about 10¬†GHz, also for economic reasons). The [radio source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomical_radio_source "Astronomical radio source") PSR J1928+15 (observed in 2005 near the Galactic disk, at a frequency of 1.44¬†GHz, at [Arecibo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arecibo_Observatory "Arecibo Observatory")) could be of extraterrestrial origin. James and Dominic Benford consider three scenarios in which the cost factor is taken into account. If the source is cost-optimized, it belongs to a civilization of Type 0.35 (the Earth being of Type 0.73).[\[note 1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Sagan2sf-29) If it is not cost-optimized and operates with a small antenna, the Type is 0.86. With a large antenna, it would be from a Type 0.66. Using this cost/efficiency method, it can be estimated that low-intensity sources may be the most prevalent, but also the most difficult to observe.[\[79\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-81)

## Criticisms of the classification

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=40 "Edit section: Criticisms of the classification")\]

### Irrelevant assumptions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=41 "Edit section: Irrelevant assumptions")\]

William I. Newman and [Carl Sagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carl_Sagan "Carl Sagan") believe that the growth of energy consumption alone cannot describe the evolution of civilizations; it is also necessary to consider [population growth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_growth "Population growth"), and in particular the fact that it can be limited by the transport capacity of interplanetary means of travel. They conclude that there can be no ancient civilizations of galactic dimensions, nor galactic empires, although the possibility of networks of colonized worlds (of about 5 to 10 planets) is strong.[\[80\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-82)

The scale theorized by Kardashev was born in the geopolitical context of the [Cold War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"), in which energy had supreme value.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Wilson-20112-27) According to Guillermo A. Lemarchand, a physicist at the University of Buenos Aires, there are four arguments against Kardashev's classification:[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20)

1. Long range omnidirectional transmitters would be very energy intensive. Using directional or intermittent devices, each pointing in a different direction, would require much less energy. Type¬†II or III civilizations might therefore be defined by something other than exponential energy consumption.
2. The assumption of exponential energy consumption is certainly wrong, because if we analyze per capita energy consumption throughout human history, it forms a series of [logistic curves](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function "Logistic function") with a saturation point for each technological innovation. Therefore, a steady state or limited growth is more likely.
3. According to the [principle of mediocrity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediocrity_principle "Mediocrity principle"), applied to the search for extraterrestrial civilizations by Sagan and Shklovskii in 1966 on the basis of [John Richard Gott](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J._Richard_Gott "J. Richard Gott")'s calculations,[\[81\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-83) civilizations more important than ours must be so rare that they do not have the possibility to dominate and be visible.
4. Finally, research and listening programs in Harvard University and Buenos Aires (Horowitz and Sagan in 1993 or Lemarchand et al. in 1997) have not provided any scientific proof of the existence of artificial sources, neither in the Milky Way nor in nearby galaxies ( [M33](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M33_X-7 "M33 X-7"), [M81](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/M81_Group "M81 Group"), the [Whirlpool Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whirlpool_Galaxy "Whirlpool Galaxy") or [Centaurus A](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centaurus_A "Centaurus A")), or even in the [Virgo cluster](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virgo_Cluster "Virgo Cluster").

For the British meteorologist [Lewis Fry Richardson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Fry_Richardson "Lewis Fry Richardson"), author of a statistical study on mortality (published in _Statistics of Deadly Quarrels_, 1960), man's aggressiveness does not allow us to predict a [life span](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_expectancy "Life expectancy") that will allow humanity to reach more evolved stages. He estimates that man's violent [impulses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impulsivity "Impulsivity") will destroy the social order over a period of 1000 years. Moreover, mankind will probably be destroyed with [weapons of mass destruction](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weapon_of_mass_destruction "Weapon of mass destruction") within a few centuries at the most.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Lemarchand-20002-20)

[Transhumanists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transhumanism "Transhumanism") Paul Hughes and John Smart explain the absence of signals from a Type¬†III civilization with two hypotheses: either it has self-destructed or it has not followed the trajectory described by Kardashev.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23) The growth of energy consumption should lead to a climate crisis, which [Yvan Dutil](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yvan_Dutil "Yvan Dutil") and [St√©phane Dumas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/St%C3%A9phane_Dumas_(astrophysicist) "St√©phane Dumas (astrophysicist)") set at 1 [W](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watt "Watt")/m2 of the [Earth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Earth "Earth") or 127 [TW](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terawatt "Terawatt") for the entire planet. At a growth rate of 2% per year, an industrial civilization should stop growing quite early in its history (after a few centuries).[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Dutil-2007-49) In summary, the impossibility of sustainably securing energy resources may explain the absence of Type¬†II and III civilizations.[\[48\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Dutil-2007-49)

For Zoltan Gal√°ntai, it is not possible to imagine a civilization project that spans centuries (like a [Dyson sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere")) or even millions of years, unless one imagines a thought and an [ethic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics "Ethics") different from ours, within the reach of an ancestral civilization. He therefore proposes to classify civilizations according to their ability to carry out large-scale civilization projects over the long term.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Galantai-2006-23)

Finally, for [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson"), communication and life can continue forever in an [open Universe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shape_of_the_universe "Shape of the universe") with a finite amount of energy; intelligence is therefore the only fundamental parameter for a civilization to survive in the very long term, and energy is then no longer what defines it, a thesis he develops in his article "Time Without End: Physics and Biology in an Open Universe".[\[82\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-84)

## Energy development

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=42 "Edit section: Energy development")\]

See also: [Energy development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_development "Energy development")

### Type¬†I civilization methods

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=43 "Edit section: Type¬†I civilization methods")\]

- Large-scale application of [fusion power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fusion_power "Fusion power"): In terms of [mass‚Äìenergy equivalence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass%E2%80%93energy_equivalence "Mass‚Äìenergy equivalence"), Type¬†I implies the conversion of about 2¬†kg of matter to energy per second. An equivalent energy release could theoretically be achieved by fusing about 280¬†kg of [hydrogen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen") [into](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proton%E2%80%93proton_chain_reaction "Proton‚Äìproton chain reaction") [helium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Helium "Helium") per second,[\[83\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-85) a rate roughly equivalent to 8.9√ó109¬†kg/year. One cubic kilometer of water contains about 1011¬†kg of hydrogen, and the Earth's [oceans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocean "Ocean") contain about [1.3√ó109¬†cubic kilometers of water](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ocean#Physical_properties "Ocean"), meaning that humans on Earth could sustain this rate of consumption over geological time scales, in terms of available hydrogen.
- [Antimatter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimatter "Antimatter") in large quantities would provide a mechanism to produce power on a scale several orders of magnitude beyond the current level of technology.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\] In antimatter-matter collisions, all of the [rest mass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rest_mass "Rest mass") of the particles is converted to [radiant energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radiant_energy "Radiant energy"). Their [energy density](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Energy_density "Energy density") (energy released per mass) is about four orders of magnitude greater than that from using [nuclear fission](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fission "Nuclear fission"), and about two orders of magnitude greater than the best possible yield from [fusion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nuclear_fusion "Nuclear fusion").[\[84\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-86) The reaction of 1¬†[kg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilogram "Kilogram") of antimatter with 1¬†kg of matter would produce 1.8√ó1017 [J](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joule "Joule") (180 [petajoules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petajoules "Petajoules")) of energy.[\[85\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-87) Although antimatter is sometimes proposed as a source of energy,[\[86\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-88) this does not seem feasible. Artificially producing antimatter ‚Äì according to current understanding of the laws of physics ‚Äì involves first converting energy into mass, which yields no net energy. Artificially created antimatter is usable only as an energy storage medium, not as an energy source, unless future technological developments (contrary to the conservation of the [baryon number](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baryon_number "Baryon number"), such as a [CP violation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CP_violation "CP violation") in favor of antimatter) allow the conversion of ordinary matter into anti-matter. Theoretically, humans may be able to cultivate and harvest a number of naturally occurring sources of antimatter in the future.[\[87\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-89)[\[88\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-90)[\[89\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-91)
- [Renewable energy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable_energy "Renewable energy") by converting sunlight into electricity ‚Äì either directly through [solar cells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_cell "Solar cell") and [concentrating solar power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concentrating_solar_power "Concentrating solar power"), or indirectly through [biofuels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biofuel "Biofuel"), [wind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wind_power "Wind power"), and [hydroelectric power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydroelectric_power "Hydroelectric power"): There is no known way for a [human civilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civilization "Civilization") to harness the equivalent of the Earth's total absorbed solar energy without completely covering the surface with man-made structures, which is not feasible with current technology. However, if a civilization constructed very large [space-based solar power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Space-based_solar_power "Space-based solar power") [satellites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite "Satellite"), Type¬†I power levels might become achievable‚Äîthese could convert sunlight to microwave power and beam it to collectors on Earth.

### Type¬†II civilization methods

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=44 "Edit section: Type¬†II civilization methods")\]

[![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Dyson_Swarm_-_2.png/500px-Dyson_Swarm_-_2.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dyson_Swarm_-_2.png) A figure of a [Dyson swarm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_Swarm "Dyson Swarm") surrounding a star

- Type¬†II civilizations could use the same techniques as a Type¬†I civilization, but applied to a large number of planets in a large number of star systems.
- A [Dyson sphere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_sphere "Dyson sphere") or [Dyson swarm](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dyson_swarm "Dyson swarm") and similar constructs are hypothetical [megastructures](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megastructure "Megastructure") originally described by [Freeman Dyson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Freeman_Dyson "Freeman Dyson") as a system of orbiting [solar power satellites](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_power_satellite "Solar power satellite") designed to completely encircle a [star](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star "Star") and capture most or all of its energy output.[\[90\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-92)
- Another means of generating usable energy would be to feed a stellar mass into a [black hole](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_hole "Black hole"), and collect the photons emitted by the [accretion disk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Accretion_disk "Accretion disk").[\[91\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-93)[\[92\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-94) A less exotic means would be to simply capture photons already escaping from the accretion disk, thereby reducing a black hole's [angular momentum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angular_momentum "Angular momentum"); this is known as the [Penrose process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Penrose_process "Penrose process"). However, this may only be possible for a Type¬†III civilization.
- [Star lifting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_lifting "Star lifting") is a process by which an advanced civilization could remove a substantial portion of a star's matter in a controlled manner for other uses.
- [Antimatter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antimatter "Antimatter") is likely to be produced as an industrial [byproduct](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byproduct "Byproduct") of a number of [megascale engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Megascale_engineering "Megascale engineering") processes (such as the aforementioned star lifting), and could therefore be recycled.\[ _[citation needed](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_\]
- In [multiple star systems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Star_system "Star system") with a sufficiently large number of stars: absorbing a small but significant fraction of the output of each individual star.
- [Stellar engines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stellar_engine "Stellar engine") can be used to move stars.

### Type¬†III civilization methods

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=45 "Edit section: Type¬†III civilization methods")\]

- Type¬†III civilizations might use the same techniques as a Type¬†II civilization, but applied individually to all possible stars in one or more galaxies.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-Kardashev1985-5)
- They may also be able to tap into the energy released by the [supermassive black holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Supermassive_black_hole "Supermassive black hole") believed to exist at the center of most galaxies.[\[93\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-95)
- [White holes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_holes "White holes") could theoretically provide large amounts of energy by collecting the matter ejected outward.
- Capturing the energy of [gamma-ray bursts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma-ray_burst "Gamma-ray burst") is another theoretically possible power source for an advanced civilization.
- The emissions from [quasars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasars "Quasars") are comparable to those from small active galaxies and could be a massive power source if they could be collected.

## Civilization implications

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kardashev_scale&action=edit&section=46 "Edit section: Civilization implications")\]

There are many historical examples of human civilization undergoing large-scale transitions, such as the [Industrial Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_Revolution "Industrial Revolution"). The transitions between Kardashev scale levels could potentially represent similarly dramatic periods of social upheaval, as they involve exceeding the hard limits of the resources available within a civilization's existing territory. A common speculation[\[94\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kardashev_scale#cite_note-96) is that the transition from Type¬†0 to Type¬†I could carry a strong risk of self-destruction, since in some scenarios there would be no room for further expansion on the civilization's home planet, as in a [Malthusian catastrophe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Malthusian_catastrophe "Malthusian catastrophe").

For example, excessive energy consumption without adequate heat removal could plausibly render the planet of a Type I approaching civilization unsuitable for the biology of the [dominant life forms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human "Human") and their food sources. Using Earth as an example, ocean temperatures above 95¬†¬∞F (35¬†¬∞C) would endanger marine life and make it difficult, if not impossible, for mammals to cool to temperatures suitable for their [metabolism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metabolism "Metabolism"). Of course, these [theoretical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theoretical "Theoretical") speculations may not become problems, possibly through the application of future [engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_engineering "Climate engineering") and [technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technology "Technology"). Also, by the time a civilization reaches Type¬†I, it may have colonized other planets or established [O'Neill-type colonies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O%27Neill_cylinder "O'Neill cylinder"), so that waste heat could be distributed throughout the star system.

The limitations of biological life forms and the evolution of computer technology may lead to the transformation of the civilization through [mind uploading](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mind_uploading "Mind uploading") and [artificial general intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence "Artificial general intelligence") in general during the transition from Type¬†I to Type¬†II, leading to a [digitized civilization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrioshka_brain "Matrioshka brain").

[Jump to content](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#bodyContent)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Describes how technological innovations occur and are incorporated into society

|     |     |
| --- | --- |
| ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png) | This article **possibly contains [original research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:No_original_research "Wikipedia:No original research")**. Please [improve it](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit) by [verifying](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability "Wikipedia:Verifiability") the claims made and adding [inline citations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Inline_citations "Wikipedia:Citing sources"). Statements consisting only of original research should be removed._(October 2022)__([Learn how and when to remove this message](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal "Help:Maintenance template removal"))_ |

**Technological transitions** (TT) can best be described as a collection of theories regarding how technological innovations occur, the driving forces behind them, and how they are incorporated into society.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Evans-1) TT draws on a number of fields, including [history of science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science "History of science"), technology studies, and [evolutionary economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics "Evolutionary economics"). Alongside the technological advancement, TT considers wider societal changes such as "user practices, regulation, industrial networks (supply, production, distribution), infrastructure, and symbolic meaning or culture".[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels-2) Hughes[\[3\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-3) refers to the 'seamless web' where physical artifacts, organizations, scientific communities, and social practices combine. A technological transition occurs when there is a major shift in these socio-technical configurations.[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels-2)[\[4\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-4)

## Origins

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Origins")\]

Work on technological transitions draws on a number of fields including [history of science](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science "History of science"), technology studies, and [evolutionary economics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_economics "Evolutionary economics").[\[2\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels-2) The focus of evolutionary economics is on economic change, but as a driver of this [technological change](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_change "Technological change") has been considered in the literature.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5) Joseph [Schumpeter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schumpeter "Schumpeter"), in his classic _Theory of Economic Development_[\[6\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-6) placed the emphasis on non-economic forces as the driver for growth. The human actor, the entrepreneur is seen as the cause of economic development which occurs as a cyclical process. [Schumpeter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schumpeter "Schumpeter") proposed that radical innovations were the catalyst for Kondratiev cycles.

### Long wave theory

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: Long wave theory")\]

The Russian economist Kondratiev[\[7\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-7) proposed that economic growth operated in boom and bust cycles of approximately 50 year periods. These cycles were characterised by periods of expansion, stagnation and recession. The period of expansion is associated with the introduction of a new technology, e.g. steam power or the microprocessor. At the time of publication, [Kondratiev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kondratiev "Kondratiev") had considered that two cycles had occurred in the nineteenth century and third was beginning at the turn of the twentieth. Modern writers, such as Freeman and Perez[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Freeman-8) outlined five cycles in the modern age:

- [The Industrial Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Industrial_Revolution "The Industrial Revolution") (1770‚Äì1830)
- Victorian Prosperity: Age of steam and Rail (1830‚Äì1880)
- The Age of Steel (1880‚Äì1930)
- Oil, Mass Production and the Consumer Society (1930‚Äì1980)
- The Information Age (1980-?)

Freeman and Perez[\[8\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Freeman-8) proposed that each cycle consists of pervasive technologies, their production and economic structures that support them. Termed 'techno-economic paradigms', they suggest that the shift from one paradigm to another is the result of emergent new technologies.

After the [2008 financial crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2008_financial_crisis "2008 financial crisis"), authors such as Moody and Nogrady[\[9\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-9) have suggested that a new cycle is emerging from the old, centred on the use of sustainable technologies in a resource depleted world.

### Technological paradigms, trajectories and regimes

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Technological paradigms, trajectories and regimes")\]

[Thomas Kuhn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Kuhn "Thomas Kuhn")[\[10\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-10) described how a paradigm shift is a wholesale shift in the basic understanding of a scientific theory. Examples in science include the change of thought from miasma to germ theory as a cause of disease. Building on this work, [Giovanni Dosi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giovanni_Dosi "Giovanni Dosi")[\[11\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-11) developed the concept of 'technical paradigms' and 'technological trajectories'. In considering how engineers work, the technical paradigm is an outlook on the technological problem, a definition of what the problems and solutions are. It charts the idea of specific progress. By identifying the problems to be solved the paradigm exerts an influence on technological change. The pattern of problem solving activity and the direction of progress is the technological trajectory. In similar fashion, Nelson and Winter (,[\[12\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-12)[\[13\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-13))defined the concept of the 'technological regime' which directs technological change through the beliefs of engineers of what problems to solve. The work of the actors and organisations is the result of organisational and cognitive routines which determines search behaviour. This places boundaries and also trajectories (direction) to those boundaries.

## Multi-level perspective (MLP) on technological transitions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Multi-level perspective (MLP) on technological transitions")\]

### Socio-technical systems and transitions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Socio-technical systems and transitions")\]

Recently, the scope of academic sustainability discourse and investigative focus has broadened beyond the study of technological products, innovations and subsequent transitions.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2005-14) Much of the literature now examines technological artefacts and innovations through a wider scope of socio-technical systems.[\[15\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-15) It has been argued that this contemporary framework has emerged in response to both an increased understanding of the urgency of environmental problems and the recognition that more substantiative transitions are required across multiple interdependent systems to mitigate impacts.[\[16\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-16)

The technological transitions framework does acknowledge the co-evolution and mutual unfolding of societal change alongside technological innovation. However, the socio-technical transitions framework considers a more encompassing view of the interdependent links that technology maintains with systems that both generate the need for new innovations and ultimately produce and maintain them.[\[17\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-17) More specifically, the systems that comprise the socio-technical paradigm include technology, supply networks, infrastructure, maintenance networks, regulation, cultural meaning as well as user practices and markets.[\[18\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-18) As such, socio-technical transitions can be defined as the multi-dimensional shift from one socio-technical system to another involving changes in both technological and social systems that are intrinsically linked in a feedback loop.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2005-14) Generally speaking, socio-technical transitions are a slow process as technological innovation tends to occur incrementally along fixed trajectories due to the rigidity of economic, social, cultural, infrastructural and regulative norms.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-ReferenceA-19) This is referred to as path dependency, creating technological 'lock-ins' which prevent innovation that disrupts the status quo.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Twomey_and_Gaziulusoy_2014-20) Therefore, the breakthrough and dissemination of technological innovations is dependent on more than their respective benefits, providing an insight into the complexity of the forces and multiple dimensions at play.

### Multi-level perspective (MLP) framework

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Multi-level perspective (MLP) framework")\]

The multi-level perspective (MLP) is an analytical tool that attempts to deal with this complexity and resistance to change. Focussing on the dynamics of wider transitionary developments as opposed to discrete technological innovations, the MLP concerns itself with socio-technical system transformations, particularly with transitions towards sustainability and resilience.[\[21\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-21) As the name implies, the MLP posits three analytical and heuristic levels on which processes interact and align to result in socio-technical system transformations; **landscape (macro-level), regimes (meso-level) and niches (micro-level)**.[\[22\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-22) Firstly, the **regime** level represents the current structures and practices characterised by dominant rules, institutions and technologies that are self-reinforcing.[\[23\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-23) The socio-technical regime is dynamically stable in the sense that innovation still transpires albeit incrementally and along a predictable trajectory.[\[14\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2005-14) This makes the regime 'locked-in' and resistant to both technological and social transitions.[\[24\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-24) Secondly, the **landscape** level is defined as the exogenous, broader contextual developments in deep-seated cultural patterns, macro-economics, macro-politics and spatial structures, potentially arising from shocks associated with wars, economic crisis, natural disaster and political upheaval.[\[25\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-25) Additionally, landscapes are beyond the direct influence of actors, yet stimulate and exert pressure on them at the regime and niche levels. Finally, the **niche** is defined as the "locus for radical innovations" where dedicated actors nurture the development of technological novelties.[\[26\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-26) Incubated from market and regulation influences, the niche fosters innovations that differ fundamentally from the prevailing regime and usually require landscape developments that open windows of opportunity in at the regime level.[\[19\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-ReferenceA-19) Therefore, the MLP attributes socio-technical transitions to the interaction of stabilising forces at the regime level with destabilising forces from both the landscape and niche levels.[\[20\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Twomey_and_Gaziulusoy_2014-20)

### MLP application - automobility regime

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: MLP application - automobility regime")\]

Due to the systems approach inherent in the MLP, analysis can be approached from different disciplinary perspectives according to their respective ontologies and priorities. From an urban planning perspective, the framework could be used to pinpoint the barriers and drivers associated with low carbon transport systems to better target policy efforts.[\[27\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-27) To begin, from an urban mobility perspective, the landscape level is currently pressured by both stabilising and destabilising pressures. Namely, Peak Oil, public concern surrounding inaction towards [climate change mitigation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Climate_change_mitigation "Climate change mitigation") and information technologies that digitise daily life (e.g. tele-commuting) destabilises the landscape and automobility regime.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-ReferenceB-28) Conversely, the landscape level is solidified by stabilising forces such as cultural preferences for private ownership, timesaving, autonomy and privacy, as well as car-favouring urban fabric and infrastructure.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2012-29) This is further enhanced by universal pressures of globalisation which presupposes urban mobility to increase flows of goods and people.[\[28\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-ReferenceB-28)

This tension between stabilising and destabilising forces is mirrored in the prevailing automobility regime. The regime is stabilised by persistent investment in road projects, lifestyle norms and consumer preferences that perpetuate car use and resistance to major change by vested actors such as transport planners, policy makers and industry actors (e.g. car manufactures).[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2012-29) Despite this stability, shifts in the landscape has allowed "cracks" in the regime such as traffic management policy (traffic calming, parking restrictions, etc.), diminishing policy commitment to the regime and industry actors proclaiming awareness of landscape pressures associated with climate change [\[30\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-30)

In these contexts, niche socio-technical innovations that challenge the assumptions and norms of the regime have been birthed, mainly in the form of local policy and infrastructure initiatives on a city-scale. For example, intermodal travel in the form of bus/bike-rail integration schemes, bike rental/sharing have been trialled in many cities globally.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2012-29) Also, niche sustainable urban planning concepts such as compact cities, smart growth and transit-oriented development have modestly emerged into sustainably mobility discourse.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2012-29) However, the persistence of the automobility regime due to the general stability of the landscape has resulted in limited, small-scale implementations of these niche innovations.[\[29\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_2012-29) As such, prevailing user preference and cultural values at the landscape level appear to be a major barrier in transport system socio-technical transitions, as they stabilise the automobility regime, disallowing niche innovations to gain a foothold.

## Transition paths

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Transition paths")\]

The nature of transitions varies and the differing qualities result in multiple pathways occurring. Geels and Schot [\[31\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-31) defined five transition paths:

- Reproduction: Ongoing change occurring in the regime level.
- Transformation: A socio-technical regime that changes without the emergence of a monopolising technology.
- Technological substitution: An incumbent technology is replaced by a radical innovation resulting in a new socio-technical regime.
- De-alignment and Re-alignment: Weaknesses in the regime sees the advent of competing new technologies leading to a dominant model. (E.g. the automobile replacing the horse as the primary means of land transport).
- Re-configuration: When multiple, interlinked technologies are replaced by a similarly linked alternative set.

## Characteristics of technological transitions

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Characteristics of technological transitions")\]

Six characteristics of technological transitions have been identified.,[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Evans-1)[\[32\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-32)

_Transitions are co-evolutionary and multi-dimensional_
Technological developments occur intertwined with societal needs, wants and uses. A technology is adopted and diffused based on this interplay between innovation and societal requirements. Co-evolution has different aspects. As well as the co-evolution of technology and society, aspects between science, technology, users and culture have been considered.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5)

_Multi-actors are involved_
Scientific and engineering communities are central to the development of a technology, but a wide range of actors are involved in a transition. This can include organisations, policy-makers, government, NGOs, special interest groups and others.

_Transitions occur at multiple levels_
As shown in the MLP, transitions occur through the interplay of processes at different levels.

_Transitions are a long-term process_
Complete system-change takes time and can be decades in the making. Case studies show them to be between 40 and 90 years.[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Genus-33)

_Transitions are radical_
For a true transition to occur the technology has to be a radical innovation.

_Change is Non-linear_
The rate of change will vary over time. For example, the pace of change may be slow at the gestation period (at the niche level) but much more rapid when a breakthrough is occurring.

## Diffusion: transition phases

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Diffusion: transition phases")\]

Diffusion of an innovation is the concept of how it is picked up by society, at what rate and why.[\[34\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-34) The diffusion of a technological innovation into society can be considered in distinct phases.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Rotmans-35) Pre-development is the gestation period where the new technology has yet to make an impact. Take-off is when the process of a system shift is beginning. A breakthrough is occurring when fundamental changes are occurring in existing structures through the interplay of economic, social and cultural forces. Once the rate of change has decreased and a new balance is achieved, stabilization is said to have occurred. A full transition involves an overhaul of existing rules and change of beliefs which takes time, typically spanning at least a generation.[\[35\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Rotmans-35) This process can be speeded up through seismic, unforeseen events such as war or economic strife.

Geels[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5) proposed a similar four-phase approach which draws on the multi-level perspective (MLP) developed by Dutch scholars. Phase one sees the emergence of a novelty, born from the existing regime. Development then occurs in the niche level at phase two. As before, breakthrough then occurs at phase three. In the parlance of the MLP the new technology, having been developed at the niche level, is in competition with the established regime. To break through and achieve wide diffusion, external factors ‚Äì 'windows of opportunity' ‚Äì are required.

## Windows of opportunity

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Windows of opportunity")\]

A number of possible circumstances can act as windows of opportunity for the diffusion of new technologies:

- Internal technical problems in the existing regime. Those that cannot be solved by refinement of existing technologies act as a driver for the new.
- Problems external to the system. Such 'problems' are often determined by pressure groups and require wider societal or political backing. An example is environmental concerns.
- Changing user preferences. Opportunities are presented if existing technologies cannot meet user needs.
- Strategic advantage. Competition with rivals may necessitate innovation
- Complementary technology. The availability of which may enable a breakthrough

Alongside external influences, internal drivers catalyse diffusion.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5) These include economic factors such as the price performance ration. Socio-technical perspectives focus on the links between disparate social and technological elements.[\[36\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Rip-36) Following the breakthrough, the final phases see the new technology supersede the old.

## Societal relevance

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Societal relevance")\]

The study of technological transitions has an impact beyond academic interest. The transitions referred to in the literature may relate to historic processes, such as the transportation transitions studied by Geels, but system changes are required to achieve a safe transition to a [low-carbon economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Low-carbon_economy "Low-carbon economy"). ([\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Evans-1)[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5)). Current structural problems are apparent in a range of sectors.[\[5\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Geels_a-5) Dependency on oil is problematic in the energy sector due to availability, access and contribution to greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. Transportation is a major user of energy causing significant emission of GHGs. Food production will need to keep pace with an ever-growing world population while overcoming challenges presented by global warming and transportation issues. Incremental change has provided some improvements but a more radical transition is required to achieve a more sustainable future.

Developed from the work on technological transitions is the field of transition management. Within this is an attempt to shape the direction of change complex socio-technical systems to more sustainable patterns.[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Evans-1) Whereas work on technological transitions is largely based on historic processes, proponents of transition management seek to actively steer transitions in progress.

## Criticisms

\[ [edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Technological_transitions&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Criticisms")\]

Genus and Coles[\[33\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-Genus-33) outlined a number of criticisms against the analysis of technological transitions, in particular when using the MLP. Empirical research on technological transitions occurring now has been limited, with the focus on historic transitions. Depending on the perspective on transition case studies they could be presented as having occurred on a different transition path to what was shown. For example, the bicycle could be considered an intermediate transport technology between the horse and the car. Judged from shorter different time-frame this could appear a transition in its own right. Determining the nature of a transition is problematic; when it started and ended, or whether one occurred in the sense of a radical innovation displacing an existing socio-technical regime. The perception of time casts doubt on whether a transition has occurred. If viewed over a long enough period even inert regimes may demonstrate radical change in the end. The MLP has also been criticised by scholars studying sustainability transitions using Social Practice Theories.[\[37\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Technological_transitions#cite_note-37)
