Dan Shipper is the CEO and cofounder of Every. Every week he explores the frontiers of AI in his column, Chain of Thought, and on his podcast, ‚ÄòAI & I.‚Äô

[![](https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/publication/logo/59/small_chain_of_thought_logo.png)Chain of Thought](https://every.to/chain-of-thought)

# ChatGPT and the Future of the Human Mind

AI is a lever that becomes a lens

[![](https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/user/avatar/2743/EVENT.to_SJH_FINALS_-15.jpg)Dan Shipper](https://every.to/@danshipper)

January 12, 2024


![Copy Link](https://every.to/assets/icons/link-00b3b50239c5decb99608a5d746ffe0fd96aecb034433a6cbaefdc45f2ae5183.svg)Link copied![Share on X](https://every.to/assets/icons/x-c02c4b571d1e377ff0b125bd65ba16dbf87be39c9dd1ebbfa333c0e19c47d7f1.svg)![Share on LinkedIn](https://every.to/assets/icons/in-98ec989b39f7091bca62c0f9a8d56d66d9fb05b80160499d8bf8f4823cfe8739.svg)![Share on Facebook](https://every.to/assets/icons/facebook-b4ec85c9120a2cd7a1c7c698e073430cfacd1f9eee761f1082fee06111a90060.svg)

[203](https://every.to/chatgpt-and-the-future-of-the-human-mind/chatgpt-and-the-future-of-the-human-mind/feedback?rating=amazing) [19](https://every.to/chain-of-thought/chatgpt-and-the-future-of-the-human-mind#comments)

I remember when I first saw GPT-3 output writing: that line of letters hammered out one by one, rolling horizontally across the screen in its distinctive staccato. It struck both wonder and terror into my heart.

I felt ecstatic that computers could finally talk back to me. But I also felt a heavy sense of dread. [I‚Äôm a writer](https://every.to/chain-of-thought/admitting-what-is-obvious)‚Äîwhat would happen to me?

We‚Äôve all had this experience with AI over the last year and a half. It is an emotional rollercoaster. It feels like it threatens our conception of ourselves.

We‚Äôve long defined the difference between humans and animals by our ability to think. Aristotle wrote: ‚ÄúThe life of the intellect is the best and pleasantest for man, for the intellect more than anything else is man; therefore, a life guided by intellect is the best for man.‚Äù

Two thousand years later, the playwright and short story author Anton Chekhov agreed in his novella, _Ward No. 6_: ‚ÄúIntellect draws a sharp line between the animals and man, \[and\] suggests the divinity of the latter.‚Äù

The primacy of thinking and the intellect as _the_ feature by which we define ourselves has become even more salient as we‚Äôve moved from an economy driven by industrial labor into one driven by knowledge. Indeed, if you‚Äôre reading this, you probably put a lot of stock into what you know. After all, that‚Äôs what knowledge work is all about. If we define ourselves and our value this way, it‚Äôs no wonder LLMs seem scary.

If AI can now write, and, worse, think, what‚Äôs left that makes humans unique?

I think LLMs will change knowledge work. In doing so, they‚Äôll change how we think of ourselves, and which characteristics we deem uniquely human. But these days I‚Äôm not particularly scared. In fact, I‚Äôm mostly filled with excitement.

My sense of self has changed‚Äîand that‚Äôs a good thing. ChatGPT has made me see my intellect and role in the creative process differently than I did before. It doesn‚Äôt replace me; it just changes what I do. It‚Äôs possible to achieve this feeling of excitement by 1) getting a clearer conception of what LLMs actually do and don‚Äôt do, and 2) expanding your view of what you are and what you are capable of.

Let‚Äôs talk about what that looks like. To start, we have to understand what the intellect is.

## What is the intellect?

For the purposes of this article, the intellect is the thing that humans uniquely have that animals don‚Äôt. This is a fuzzy definition, by design. It reflects what feels threatened by AI: that which makes us human.

In reality, the intellect is a gigantic combination of brain processes that look like thinking. Thinking, the intellect, the mind‚Äîthese are all different processes that we lump under a single heading. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs easier to define it _via negativa_, by what it is not‚Äîit‚Äôs whatever animals don‚Äôt do. (We now know that animals _do_ have thinking processes that look a lot like what we might call intellect, but that hasn‚Äôt filtered into our popular conceptions of self. Read Frans de Waal‚Äôs classic book, [_Are We Smart Enough to Know How Smart Animals Are?_](https://www.amazon.com/Are-Smart-Enough-Know-Animals/dp/0393353664), for an excellent overview of animal intelligence.)

Our fuzzy definition of the intellect is why our first encounter with ChatGPT and its ilk can be so terrifying. It touches a lightning rod within us. For millennia we‚Äôve set ourselves apart by a strange, amorphous, many-dimensional thing called intelligence‚Äîand suddenly there is something encroaching on our turf. Because it can do some of the things we associate with the intellect, we feel both excited, because we‚Äôre no longer alone, and threatened‚Äîbecause we might be replaceable.

In order to regain our sense of self and place in the world, we need to redefine what we mean by ‚Äúintellect.‚Äù We need to create a new sense of separation between what humans do and what AI can do. We need to redefine ‚Äúintellect‚Äù so as to make it work in an AI-driven world.

Fortunately, we‚Äôve done this before, and technology can help.

Psychology is a branch of science that is _full_ of concepts that are fuzzy in the same way the ‚Äúintellect‚Äù is. Take depression and bi-polar disorder. Neither is detected by a blood test, or even has a consistent set of symptoms. Instead, they‚Äôre characterized as syndromes: a set of often associated symptoms that can vary from case to case.

The problem is that there are significant overlaps between depression and bipolar disorder that can both manifest as low mood. As late as the 1960s, depression and bipolar disorder were lumped together under a single heading and understood to have a similar underlying cause. But it turns out that technology‚Äîspecifically, the discovery of the drug lithium‚Äîwas the key ingredient that we needed to pull them apart.

It all started with guinea pigs.

## Pharmacological dissection of mental illness

In the late 1940s, a doctor named J.F. Cade, who apparently had entirely too much time on his hands, discovered that the urine of manic patients was toxic to guinea pigs. (I can‚Äôt believe I just typed that sentence, but, like, we all have our kinks, I guess.)

[![](https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/editor/posts/2918/optimized_zGqQXtGWf71Lda95M0EgQDMay2u4itHED4ydJGZZ09-vF3q8UWRXmwFzBOgcAxwFczMBz1BWNjUMBL4hMHENFEc-WlE8qvo7NpGXObgPrJaZGQgvHcQH1WTTPYtr.png)](https://d24ovhgu8s7341.cloudfront.net/uploads/editor/posts/2918/optimized_zGqQXtGWf71Lda95M0EgQDMay2u4itHED4ydJGZZ09-vF3q8UWRXmwFzBOgcAxwFczMBz1BWNjUMBL4hMHENFEc-WlE8qvo7NpGXObgPrJaZGQgvHcQH1WTTPYtr.png)

_Do not let this man around your guinea pigs. Source: Wikipedia._

Anyway, Cade set out to find out why. He discovered that manic patients had elevated levels of uric acid in their pee and thought that might be what was causing the toxicity. He decided to perform a controlled experiment on the guinea pigs: He would inject them with varying levels of uric acid to see if increasing levels would cause toxicity.

To do the injections, he dissolved the uric acid into a lithium carbonate solution. When he injected the guinea pigs with lithium he noticed that they became remarkably calm. They just sat around in their cages and didn‚Äôt respond to being messed around with‚Äîa side effect he had not anticipated.

Then, in a move that revolutionized the field of psychology, Cade decided to inject the lithium carbonate into his manic patients. The results were astonishing: Lithium resolved their mania.

This is a remarkable series of events for two reasons: One, it resulted in a drug, lithium, that has saved many thousands of lives over the decades since it was discovered. And two, it acted as what the psychiatrist Peter Kramer calls a ‚Äúpharmacological dissection‚Äù that differentiated manic depression as a separate disease from depression, with its own biological cause.

Kramer argued that manic depression hadn‚Äôt previously been thought of as separate from depression. Indeed, psychoanalytic thought, which was the prevailing model of the mind at the time, viewed all psychiatric issues as essentially about internal psychological conflicts resulting from childhood trauma.

But a drug, lithium‚Äîwhich cured manic depression, and only manic depression‚Äîhelped carve the disease out as distinct from the rest of mental illness, and one that was fundamentally biological in origin. In other words, lithium was a lever that became a new lens on the way our minds work.

We can use this model to do a similar technological dissection on our intellect. Once we understand what ChatGPT does, it can help us further define and flesh out our previously fuzzy concepts like the intellect‚Äîwhile leaving our sense of what keeps us different intact.

## ChatGPT is a summarizer

Technically, ChatGPT does next token prediction. Given a string of words, it is very good at statistically predicting the most likely words that come next in the sequence.

In practice, that means that ChatGPT and other LLMs are _incredible_ at reformatting, reconstituting, and recombining old knowledge in new and useful ways. The cognitive scientist Alison Gopnik and colleagues [refer to LLMs as technologies](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/17456916231201401) that enhance ‚Äúcultural transmission‚Äù and are ‚Äúpowerful and efficient imitation engines.‚Äù

In this way, Gopnik argues, LLMs are an extension of previously existing technologies like writing, the printing press, and the internet. They allow existing information to be ‚Äúpassed efficiently from one group of people to another,‚Äù which allows for ‚Äúa new means of cultural production and evolution.‚Äù

What this means, in effect, is that LLMs aren‚Äôt very good at discovering new things thus far. But they _are_ incredible at bringing to bear human knowledge into any given area of inquiry, by effectively compressing and reformatting it in precisely the best way for it to be consumed. Its powers for increasing transmission and understanding of knowledge are better by far than any preceding innovation, from the book to the internet.

To say it plainly: These things are great at summarizing. Calling ChatGPT a summarizer might sound pejorative, but it‚Äôs not. It is powerful and important. Because the sum total of all human knowledge far outstrips any single person‚Äôs ability to remember it, we _need_ LLMs in order to have any hope of enacting all of the things humanity knows.

Thinking about ChatGPT as a summarizer, we can now come back to the word that started us off‚Äî‚Äùintellect‚Äù‚Äîand see how it might help us refine our understanding of our intellect, and ourselves.

## A technological dissection of ‚Äòintellect‚Äô

Here‚Äôs what happened when I started to see ChatGPT as a summarizer.

First, I started to see that summaries are happening everywhere, all the time. Most of the emails I write are summaries, and so is most of the code I write. Even much of this article is a summary. For example, the passage about J. F. Cade, lithium, and pharmacological dissection is a summary of a particularly enlightening section of Peter Kramer‚Äôs book, _Listening to Prozac_.

At this point, it‚Äôs easy for me to again panic and start to feel threatened. If summaries are everywhere in my work life, and ChatGPT can do summaries, what role do I have? The answer is obvious: There‚Äôs a large amount of things that need to be done to write a great essay. The fact that I don‚Äôt have to summarize as much is _fantastic._

When I really sat down to think about this article, the interesting thing, the hard thing, was not the summary. It was everything else that went into it: the life experience, the diversity of reading sources, the emotional journey of interacting with ChatGPT and considering its implications. Summarizing skills are a kind of creative drudgery. I learned them out of necessity, but they‚Äôre no longer as useful as they once were.

Once I start thinking this way, I start to automatically subtract summarizing as a skill that‚Äôs core to my sense of identity, humaneness, and intellect. It feels much more ‚Äúokay‚Äù that ChatGPT is able to do this‚Äîbecause now I get to direct it to summarize for me. I can summarize many more things in a day now, with far less effort, so it increases my writing productivity.

My sense of self, having suffered the loss of summary, heals pretty quickly as soon as I realize that much richness remains. In fact, the loss of summary highlights the richness that I might not have seen otherwise. ChatGPT is a lever that becomes a new lens on what my intellect is‚Äîand what my role in the creative process should be.

A key point is that this doesn‚Äôt have to be specifically about summarizing. If ChatGPT had been good at finding out new knowledge and terrible at summarizing, I would instead extol the virtues of my human ability to summarize. This is good and natural: Humans, above all, are adaptable. I define what‚Äôs interesting by what I can uniquely do. That‚Äôs a human process at work. And our adaptability is the thing we miss when we freak out about AI and ChatGPT.

Sure, it is an important fact that many jobs require a lot of summarizing, and that those jobs will change dramatically, or may no longer exist. Our society will do better if we face that head on, and take care of the people who will need to learn new skills or find new roles in the economy.

But this has nothing to do with our underlying sense of self or what makes humans unique in the universe. That can still be left slightly changed, but intact in a world with LLMs. This has happened before.

## Technology has been changing our brains for generations

In his book [_The WEIRDest People in the World_](https://www.amazon.com/WEIRDest-People-World-Psychologically-Particularly-ebook/dp/B07RZFCPMD?ref_=ast_author_mpb), Joseph Henrich tells a story about English bricklayer and convict William Buckley, who had been sent to Australia to serve his sentence. In 1803, Buckley and a few compadres escaped from their penal colony. All of them died in the wilderness, except him. He got separated from them, and up running into an Aboriginal tribe who saved his life and adopted him.

Henrich tells this story because it teaches us something about how human beings change in response to technology. All of Buckley‚Äôs friends died in the wilderness, despite being almost identical genetically to the Aboriginal tribe that adopted Buckley. Why?

Buckley and his friends came from a modern culture, and he was raised with a set of norms, beliefs, and ideas that equipped him to succeed in that environment. When he was thrust into a completely different environment, he couldn‚Äôt survive. From the outside, he might‚Äôve looked quite similar to the Aboriginals who _could_ survive but there was one distinct difference: They had cultural technology for thriving in that environment that he lacked.

Henrich argues that humans have evolved ‚Äúbrains to allow us to most effectively learn the ideas, beliefs, values, motivations, and practices we‚Äôll need to survive and thrive in whatever ecological or social environments we end up in.‚Äù The way this happens is through culture, which is a dramatic accelerant on our ability to solve problems and thrive.

But Henrich writes, ‚Äú\[T\]hese genetically evolved learning abilities aren‚Äôt simply downloading a cultural software package into our innate neurological hardware. Instead, _culture rewires our brains and alters our biology_‚Äîit renovates the firmware.‚Äù

In essence, our species‚Äîour psychology, biology, brains, and bodies‚Äîis shaped by culture. And culture is, to a large extent, a function of technology. Who we are is shaped by the technology we are surrounded by.

ChatGPT is the latest in a long line of such cultural and technological changes that alter what it means to be human.

We don‚Äôt need to wait for [brain-computer interfaces](https://every.to/p/the-case-for-cyborgs) for AI to modify our biology. That‚Äôs happening already. The question is: Can we use it to do good instead of evil? Can we use it to create more richness and beauty, instead of scarcity and ugliness?

I think we can. Let‚Äôs do it together.

# Self-Organising System

The XR UK Self-Organising System (SOS) defines how we organise, communicate and make decisions. It sets out how we distribute decisions about how we organise, allowing us to reflect our values and leave behind ways of working that reproduce injustices and emotional pain in society.

## Introduction to Self-Organising

XR UK has developed the Self-Organising System (SOS), because it‚Äôs the best way we could find to embody the [Principles and Values](https://extinctionrebellion.uk/the-truth/about-us/#our-principles-and-values) of our movement ‚Äì in particular, that we are based on autonomy and decentralisation, that we actively mitigate power, and that we value reflecting and learning.

We learn from those who have gone before us. Researchers have studied the major civil disobedience movements of the last century. One of the main indicators of successful movements is that they are highly organised and maintain organisational infrastructure under pressure.

The Importance of Structure and Mitigating Power


A group without clear relationships and structure will simply form a hidden structure with hidden power dynamics. We avoid hierarchical power, which we are all familiar with ‚Äî from school, from work and many other places ‚Äî and it takes a change of mindset to work in a different way. We need a cultural shift. We can‚Äôt swap the structural power of hierarchy for a vague idea, it simply won‚Äôt work. We have to find something equally powerful to replace it with.

In the XR UK Self-Organising System, no one is in charge and authority is distributed amongst roles that are consented to by everybody in the group. It shifts power out of people and into the processes of the system, so that no single person has power over another person or the system itself.

It also includes processes that enable us to change the system itself so that XR UK can adapt and grow in the way it needs to.

## Foundations of the Self-Organising System

Some of the foundations of the SOS include distributing power; consent-based decision making; maintaining healthy groups; building a regenerative culture; and more. For an introduction to these topics, check out:

- [SOS Introduction ‚Äì Empowering the Movement](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1-8uN7j1pjtvn9yKFiJkpJS9-2KGh9r8_s8BYTxIH94E/edit)

Here are some common questions and answers that describe foundational elements of the SOS:

Why do we have a self-organising system?


XR‚Äôs tenth principle and value is that we are based on autonomy and decentralisation. The self-organising system (SOS for short) is a set of practices that guarantees this autonomy while also enabling the different parts of the movement to work together.

But why does it have to be a system? Can‚Äôt we just trust people to organise themselves?


For small groups that work more or less autonomously, the full SOS may be more than you need. But when the regions and nations are interacting with the XR UK Actions, and with the Media & Messaging team, and using the technology provided by the Digital team ‚Äî and so on ‚Äî we need some standard ways of organising and deciding, so that we‚Äôre not having to spend time arguing from first principles all the time. These standard ways are set out in the [XR UK constitution](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lsDGm3XKssPae9dlHeRy3eGZp3xkkCpn4IFeYgMbm2M/view).

Who decided how we should organise ourselves?


This decision was made by rebels and founders early in 2019. It is rooted in an evidence-based and tested approach to self-organising called holacracy. As well as safeguarding autonomy, we believe this approach can contribute to a regenerative culture and embody other XR principles and values like mitigating the concentration of power and encouraging reflecting and learning. It aims to avoid some of the pitfalls that have undermined other progressive movements such as Occupy.

OK, so what‚Äôs the gist?


Starting from the aims of the movement as a whole, we break this down into smaller parts. To achieve our demands, what are the things ‚Äî actions, communications, regen, organisational, technical etc ‚Äî that we need to get done?

With each of these, we then ‚Äòmandate‚Äô a team to achieve them. A mandate is what the rest of the movement wants the team to do. Within this mandate the team has complete autonomy (within the Principles and Values) over how it organises itself and its work. Frequently this may involve further decentralisation, dividing the authority in its mandate into smaller mandates. These are given to sub-groups and ultimately to individual roles.

Does a mandate give you power?


The power to decide how you achieve a specified outcome or purpose, yes. But also some responsibilities. As well as the purpose, a mandate also comprises a set of accountabilities. These describe _how_ you will achieve the purpose, in a series of activities that others in the movement can expect you to do. The accountabilities of a group, or a role, are what they can be held accountable for.

Like a job description, then?


Yes, and no. Yes, the mandate gives a general idea of _what_ a group, or role, is working towards, and _how_. But a job description sets the limits of what you‚Äôre allowed to do, and a manager can direct how you do it.¬†A mandate flips that on its head: you can do _anything you need to do_ (that doesn‚Äôt interfere with someone else‚Äôs mandate) to achieve your purpose. You are not restricted to your accountabilities. Your accountabilities define what others can ask and expect of you. There are no managers, and no one can direct how you go about meeting your accountabilities.

Managing without managers? Does that work?


It can if we decentralise our power through mandates, and keep evolving our organisation. We establish feedback loops within relevant groups and roles, so that each limb of the movement can renew itself. This helps embody two of our Principles and Values: mitigating power, and valuing reflecting and learning. But in turn it depends on everyone being transparent about what their mandate is, enabling others across the movement to find who is accountable for what, and to give feedback. Hence all our mandates and as many groups as possible are published on the [organism view](https://organism.extinctionrebellion.uk/) of XR UK.

What roles does every team have?


To work within the [XR UK Constitution](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lsDGm3XKssPae9dlHeRy3eGZp3xkkCpn4IFeYgMbm2M/view), each team needs to have three roles (the ‚Äòcore roles‚Äô):

- someone to organise the work of the team and support members in their roles ‚Äî the Internal Coordinator
- someone to integrate the work of the team with the broader movement ‚Äî the External Coordinator
- someone to keep records of who‚Äôs doing what in the team, and ensure all members are on the team communication channels ‚Äî the Group Admin.

Together these roles make sure that the team is as transparent and accessible as it reasonably can be to the rest of the movement ‚Äî so that we can all quickly find who‚Äôs accountable for what. There are still quite a lot of meetings, but we keep them as short as possible.

What happens when people disagree?


It‚Äôs inevitable we will disagree, sometimes strongly. The [XR UK constitution](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lsDGm3XKssPae9dlHeRy3eGZp3xkkCpn4IFeYgMbm2M/view) outlines an ‚ÄòIntegrative Decision Making‚Äô process. If someone feels that something is not working as it should, they express this tension ‚Äî ideally explaining how it impacts their mandate ‚Äî and make a proposal for addressing it.

And then you put the proposal to a vote, right?


We try to be less binary than Yes/No, less factional than For/Against. First, a facilitator guides the process of checking everyone understands the proposal and its implications ‚Äî particularly for them and their mandates. Then the facilitator invites reactions to the proposal. Finally they ask for any objections.¬†We avoid majority rule ‚Äî voting ‚Äî or minority rule ‚Äî veto. Objections are only valid if they convincingly show that harm would arise from the proposal (for example: if a group would no longer be able to exercise its mandate, that would be harm). ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that‚Äôs going to work‚Äù is a _reaction_ that the proposer may or may not take on when implementing the proposal, but it is _not_ a valid _objection_.

Does a valid objection mean you need to start from scratch with a new proposal?


Maybe, but hopefully not. A proposal can‚Äôt go forward if there‚Äôs a valid objection, but the group is invited to think creatively to suggest changes to the proposal. These changes should retain the desired impact of the original proposal while also avoiding the harm identified in the objection.

### Rebellion Academy Courses

UK Rebellion Academy is an online learning platform where you can work through online trainings in your own time to learn more about Extinction Rebellion

- [Intro to XR Group Structures](https://uk.rebellion.academy/enrol/index.php?id=33)

This training is about how XR organises, communicates and makes decisions. It covers the purpose of the SOS and the six underlying principles of Self-Organising Systems.

- SOS ‚Äî A Change in Culture (link coming soon)

This SOS course follows on from the Intro to XR Group Structures training above. It covers how XR UK‚Äôs Self-Organising System aligns us with XR‚Äôs Principles and Values, and how we approach meetings and decision-making.

## How SOS Works

The Constitution sets out our agreed processes for distributing and making decisions, and for organising within and between teams. Whilst XR UK teams are bound by the Constitution, the Nations and Regions of the UK, as well as Local Groups, are not ‚Äì although they may choose to adopt it, or parts of it, if they wish to (and many have). These smaller, autonomous groups can act under XR‚Äôs names as long as they are in alignment with XR [Principles and Values](https://extinctionrebellion.uk/the-truth/about-us/#our-principles-and-values).

- [The XR UK Constitution](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1lsDGm3XKssPae9dlHeRy3eGZp3xkkCpn4IFeYgMbm2M/view)
- More links coming soon

## How To Guides

The Rebel Toolkit, XR UK‚Äôs library of resources and creative work, gives more in-depth guides on how to use our Self-Organising System in practice to build healthy teams, co-evolve the movement and meet our demands.

You can find information on [how SOS works in terms of the Constitution, Roles, Processes & Policies](https://rebeltoolkit.extinctionrebellion.uk/books/xr-uk-constitution-guides-and-resources/page/xr-uk-sos-%E2%80%94-constitution-roles-processes-policies)

Guidance on how to put these into practice (e.g. decision-making, coordination, working with other teams) can be found as part of a larger cross-movement guide on Building Healthy Teams (link coming soon).

## Contact us

To ask any questions, request support and facilitation, or join the team and deepen your knowledge of self-organising, please email [xr.mandates@gmail.com](mailto:xr.mandates@gmail.com) or speak to us on our [XRUK SOS Mattermost channel](https://organise.earth/uk/channels/self-organising-system).

![](https://extinctionrebellion.uk/act-now/resources/wellbeing/)

# Wellbeing

Wellbeing is an essential element of the regenerative culture of XR. Regenerative Culture is the radical process within Extinction Rebellion which affirms our connected roots to deep and abiding nourishment.

You can contact us at [xr.regenerativeculture@gmail.com](mailto:xr.regenerativeculture@gmail.com)

## A Regenerative Rebellion

Regenerative Cultures seek to bring a different approach to climate and other activist movements. They are how we move towards a practice and demonstration of the change we want to deeply experience in this and all society. We aim to nurture new cultures that are resilient and robust and which can support us all through the changes we must inevitably face together. Regenerative Cultures precede, hold us through and last beyond the actions that we take as part of our rebellion.

In XR we recognise that we have much work to do so that we can truly embody Regenerative Cultures within our movement. It is a necessary way to generate meaningful and lasting change in our shared world. There is no singular definition of regenerative cultures, but a framework based on natural principles allows each of us to develop our own approach to practicing a regenerative way of being. At its simplest this means putting a little bit more in than we take out.

We are experimenting with new ways we can come together to nurture the kind of deep care that will be needed to sustain ourselves and our communities, and we invite you to participate by considering what Regenerative Cultures mean to you. Here you will find some of the tools to support you through Rebellion and beyond.

## XR Don‚Äôt Panic: What to do in an emergency when you don‚Äôt know what to do!

Everyone can feel vulnerable or become vulnerable depending on our personal experiences and the situation in which we find ourselves at any one time.

We are all crew. Always approach problems with others and use the knowledge and skills each person brings. The Don‚Äôt Panic team advise you to avoid working alone.

For more information or advice please email the team on [xr.dontpanic@protonmail.com](mailto:xr.dontpanic@protonmail.com) or click on the dropdown below:

More information and contacts


We are responsible for ourselves and hope to support others.

Please do not try to deal with a situation alone when you have gone beyond your skills and training or when you feel you are out of your comfort zone!¬† Involve others around you and try to make contact with the vulnerable person‚Äôs friends, parents, guardians, carers or family. Having people around that the vulnerable person knows and trusts can be massively helpful.

There are also less urgent, or less clear situations which are on-going which you feel uncomfortable about but aren‚Äôt quite sure how to resolve or help with.¬† Alternatively, you may be planning an event and may want advice ahead of time.¬† Again please email us for advice on [xr.dontpanic@protonmail.com](mailto:xr.dontpanic@protonmail.com).

Other useful numbers:

- Emergency services: 999
- Health advice line: 111
- NSPCC Helpline: 0808 800 5000
- Childline: 0800 1111
- Samaritans: 116 123
- Mind helpline: 0300 123 3393
- Frank drugs helpline: 0300 123 6600

## Don‚Äôt Panic Booklet

This book aims to provide guidance to help you start thinking about dealing with challenging situations. It is packed full of scenarios for when you are feeling panicked and not sure what to do.

[Read the Don‚Äôt Panic Booklet](https://docs.google.com/document/d/10UbkxVAUVBJt0xtS_uE78LXCV8QeFwvW76BB6T_ZSok/edit)

## Action Wellbeing

Civil disobedience can be exciting, exhilarating even, and sometimes also exhausting and stressful. We want to build a regenerative culture where we take care of ourselves and others before, during and beyond actions. Action Wellbeing is one of the Action Support roles which helps activists feel safe and supported. Action Wellbeing is the responsibility of everyone ‚Äì we are all crew!

You can explore more of our resources which may support you in creating or being part of an Action Wellbeing Team

## Post-Action Wellbeing

Getting ‚Äòback to normal‚Äô after an action isn‚Äôt always easy. We‚Äôve got you covered ‚Äì read on for our best advice on looking after yourself and others as we come back down to earth; complete with bundles of free resources!

[Read more about Post-Action Wellbeing](https://rebellion.earth/2019/10/20/post-rebellion-blues/)

## Other Resources

Regenerative Action Cycle


This model is based on the observation of natural cycles as well as teachings from many regenerative cultures and indigenous cultures around the world. It draws out ways we can follow these cycles in our human activities to foster connection and regeneration within ourselves, within our communities and in our relationship with the other-than-human communities we are part of.

![](https://i0.wp.com/extinctionrebellion.uk/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Regenerative-Action-Cycle_1.1.jpg?w=3000&ssl=1)
Arrestee Welfare


Our aim is to support rebels to make informed choices about arrest, reducing the impact of challenging experiences through the arrest process and criminal justice system and support their wellbeing throughout.

Creating a framework within the XR network which ensures adequate pre-arrest preparation, during-action support and post-arrest care enables supporters and arrestees to work together.

[Explore more resources on our Arrestee Welfare page](https://rebellion.earth/act-now/resources/arrestee-welfare/)

Debrief


### Why Debrief?

Through our meetings, actions and rebellions we are filled with thoughts, emotions and hormones, things are messy and beautiful and stressful and passionate and traumatic all at the same time. Burn-out can occur for people who take on or support direct action, because we often take on a lot or find ourselves in high energy or anxiety situations, and of course we take this stuff on because we really care.

It is important to have time to process events in a constructive way.

### Aims of debrief

- Process challenging experiences
- Grow as a movement by learning from what went well and what didn‚Äôt go so well
- Explore tensions and develop conflict resilience

Each affinity group self facilitates a check-in as soon as possible post action, or at least daily for sustained actions, in order that each member can have some time to process: What actually happened? How am I right now? What do I need? How are we as a group? How can I support the health of this group?

In the days following an action a full debrief should be carried out with all involved.

Remember it‚Äôs important to physically nourish ourselves, share our stories and let off some steam before jumping straight in to debrief.

[Download the On-site debrief flyer](https://rebellion.earth/wp/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/On-site-debrief-flyer.pdf) [Download The Off-site full debrief Document](https://rebellion.earth/wp/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Off-Site-Debrief-Template-for-a-thorough-post-action-debrief.pdf) [See more debrief resources](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1D10zWeKYO-Bhg1MGs17nWq4uVfJcnjXX)
Transformative Conflict


Conflict is inevitable. We are in conflict with the degenerative culture that depletes us humans, the Earth and all living beings. We choose to see conflict as an opportunity for learning, and processing conflict is welcomed and encouraged. We also recognise that a relational, transformative, connected approach to conflict asks more of us all than enforcing change in a punitive way. The process of a transformative system engages us in dialogue and connection that allows us to hear other perspectives, repair broken channels of communication and integrate our learnings from this experience.

### **How do I get support?**

Our Transformative Conflict website tells you more about dealing with conflict within your group, initiating a conflict process and how the Transformative Conflict team can support you with guidance or facilitation.

[Find out more on our Transformative Conflict website](https://sites.google.com/view/xruk-transformativeconflict/home)
Consent Advocacy


By rebelling we are withdrawing our consent from the governments and systems that are failing us. Spreading a healthy consent culture is vital for our regenerative culture and community safety, as it aligns us with our desires so we can unleash our creativity in respectful and beautiful ways.

[Read more about XR‚Äôs consent culture, find support and get involved](https://rebellion.earth/act-now/resources/wellbeing/consent-advocacy/)
Grief Tending


Grief is the price we pay for our love. Anyone who loves this Earth and this life is experiencing grief in some form now, coming together to give it space can help both our wellbeing and our capacity to act to avoid climate breakdown. We provide a space in which we can develop an XR culture of grief tending work that draws upon an unbroken ancestry and offers guidance and support to those drawn to the work.

Children and Young People


If you are interested in promoting regenerative culture amongst children and young people we will be putting some resources in this space in the next few weeks.

XR Youth have a regenerative culture team who you can contact for more support and ideas. Email address: [XRYouth.Regen@gmail.com](mailto:XRYouth.Regen@gmail.com)

XR Open Homes


We are over the moon to re-launch the XR open homes program, providing rebels with homes all over the country for rest and reconnection. We have log cabins, remote cottages, rooms in stays ‚Äì all for free for hard working rebels needing some respite and nature connection. We like to think of it as the XR free airbnb!

[See the interactive map of all the homes offered to us](https://www.google.com/maps/d/viewer?mid=1N7DBMTGkCJur_jGechGeurcFSa9y1kyE&ll=54.19347349568635%2C-2.1589738000000125&z=6)

Please contact us at [xr-openhomes@protonmail.com](mailto:xr-openhomes@protonmail.com)¬†to request a stay, providing the following infos: where you‚Äôd like to stay, an¬†idea of when and how long you are looking to stay (NB as this is a¬†volunteer service we cannot guarantee a date or location); and finally some idea of your links and involvement in XR.

## Sign up for news

# Empowering Youth to Care for Nature

**Land-based education and employment training programs for youth from equity-denied communities.**

[Explore Our Programs](https://eya.ca/programs-overview/)

![Yarrow_FullIllustration](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/Yarrow_FullIllustration.png)

## Our Mission

Environmental Youth Alliance (EYA) is a non-profit based in East Vancouver on the unceded, shared territory of the x ∑m…ôŒ∏k ∑…ôyÃì…ôm (Musqueam), S·∏µwxÃ±w√∫7mesh (Squamish), and s…ôlÃì√≠lw…ôta…¨ (Tsleil-Waututh) nations. We empower youth from equity-denied communities to become environmental stewards through land-based education and employment training programs that centre on native plant horticulture, ecological restoration, plant medicine, and community leadership.

[Read Our Story](https://eya.ca/our-mission/)

## Explore Our Programs

[![A young person is standing outside holding a wooden tool for tending to a garden. They are wearing a mask and gardening gloves and are putting up a piece sign with one hand.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-cultivate-e1716922797181.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/cultivate/)

[Cultivate](https://eya.ca/program/cultivate/)

### Cultivate

#### Accepting Applications

Free employment skills workshop series for youth ages 18-25 from equity-denied communities.

[Learn More & Apply Now](https://eya.ca/program/cultivate/)

[![A young person is standing outside holding a wooden tool for tending to a garden. They are wearing a mask and gardening gloves and are putting up a piece sign with one hand.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-cultivate-e1716922797181.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/cultivate/)

1 of 6

[![A large group of youth from a school are holding up a project they created while standing and kneeling outside.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-field-trips.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/school-field-trips/)

### School Field Trips

#### Submit Request Anytime

90-120 minutes of land-based learning for public school classes at EYA‚Äôs programming sites in Strathcona Community Gardens.

[Learn More](https://eya.ca/program/school-field-trips/)

[![A large group of youth from a school are holding up a project they created while standing and kneeling outside.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-field-trips.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/school-field-trips/)

2 of 6

[![Two young women are wearing masks and standing outside. They are wearing gardening gloves and holding a gardening tool.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/nature-stewards-gallery-4-flip.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/nature-stewards/)

### Nature Stewards

#### Applications Closed

Free land-based education programs for youth ages 14-18 from equity-denied communities.

[Learn More](https://eya.ca/program/nature-stewards/)

[![Two young women are wearing masks and standing outside. They are wearing gardening gloves and holding a gardening tool.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/nature-stewards-gallery-4-flip.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/nature-stewards/)

3 of 6

[![Two young women are standing outside in green space. They are smiling.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-peer-mentors.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/peer-mentors/)

### Peer Mentors

#### Applications Closed

Volunteer program for youth ages 18-25 from equity-denied communities who are interested in developing skills in land-based education and youth work.

[Learn More & Apply Now](https://eya.ca/program/peer-mentors/)

[![Two young women are standing outside in green space. They are smiling.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-peer-mentors.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/peer-mentors/)

4 of 6

[![Three youth are outside smiling and showing off their braided grass.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/impact-full-width.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/youth-habitat-crew/)

### Youth Habitat Crew

#### Applications Closed

Paid summer jobs for youth ages 15-25 from equity-denied communities who are interested in developing land-based job skills.

[Learn More](https://eya.ca/program/youth-habitat-crew/)

[![Three youth are outside smiling and showing off their braided grass.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/impact-full-width.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/youth-habitat-crew/)

5 of 6

[![A smiling young woman is standing outside and is holding up a frame with pink flowers inside of it.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-roots-shoots.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/roots-shoots/)

[Roots & Shoots](https://eya.ca/program/roots-shoots/)

### Roots & Shoots

#### Applications on Hold

Paid land-based job training and internship program for youth ages 18-25 from equity-denied communities.

[Learn More](https://eya.ca/program/roots-shoots/)

[![A smiling young woman is standing outside and is holding up a frame with pink flowers inside of it.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/home-slider-roots-shoots.jpg)](https://eya.ca/program/roots-shoots/)

6 of 6

Youth remove invasive plants and steward the land.

![Dandelion_FullIllustration-Flip](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/Dandelion_FullIllustration-Flip.png)

## News & Stories

[Join our newsletter](https://eya.ca/#newsletter) to receive updates on our programs, invites to community workshops, and opportunities to support our work and receive youth-grown native plants.

[See All](https://eya.ca/news-stories/)

![arrow left](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/Group-6669.svg)![arrow right](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/Group-6670.svg)

![Closeup of purple lupine flowers.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/plant-nursery-lupine.jpg)

### Big Leaf Lupine (Lupinus polyphyllus)

Lupine is often grown in our youth programs. They‚Äôre easy to grow from seed and germinating lupine seeds is an excellent learning experience.

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=42742)

![A portrait of a young person holding up a small woven basket.](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/blog-yir-hero.jpg)

### 2021 Year in Review and Annual Report

We reflect back on the year and invite you to read our Annual Impact Report!

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=42747)

![](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/Nature-Stewards-1-1365x2048.jpg)

### Our 2024 Annual Report is Here!

Take a look at our work & impact last year in our latest Annual Report!

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=43318)

![](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/EYA-AGM-2024-2048x1536.jpg)

### You're invited to our 2025 Annual General Meeting!

Join us in the gardens for an evening of food and conversations! You‚Äôll meet EYA staff and board members, learn about our programs, and help us elect Board Directors.

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=43294)

![](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/IMG_2265-scaled.jpg)

### We're hiring a Youth Program Coordinator!

Are you inspired by land-based education for equity-deserving youth? Are you a confident youth facilitator? Do you have experience with land stewardship and/or horticulture? We‚Äôre looking for someone to lead environmental education and environmental job skill training programs for equity-deserving youth in East Vancouver.

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=43273)

![](https://eya.ca/wp-content/uploads/IMG_6477-scaled.jpg)

### Growing with Generosity: Sword Fern (Polystichum munitum)

In the lush forests of the Pacific Northwest, Sword Fern (Polystichum munitum) has thrived for thousands of years growing in the shade beneath the evergreens. As we approach the deadline for our native plant fundraiser orders, we're excited to highlight Sword Fern and its deep-rooted history and enduring presence in our local ecosystem.

[Continue Reading](https://eya.ca/?post_type=news&p=43267)

# üêáüï≥Ô∏è Web3: The Promise of a Denizens-Owned Internet

### FemWealth Issue \#37

[![Anamaria Iuga's avatar](https://femwealth.substack.com/p/fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F0814fb80-0d3d-42f9-9b17-7902612a430c_1476x1230.png)](https://substack.com/@femwealth)

[Anamaria Iuga](https://substack.com/@femwealth)

Nov 21, 2021

4

Share

#### Happy Sunday, FemWealth Friends!

> **‚ÄúWill the digital century be a democratic century?‚Äù** \- [Shoshana Zuboff](https://twitter.com/shoshanazuboff?s=20), Prof. em. of Harvard Business School, author of ["The Age of Surveillance Capitalism"](https://www.publicaffairsbooks.com/titles/shoshana-zuboff/the-age-of-surveillance-capitalism/9781610395694/)

**Web3, DAOs, NFTs, DeFi, Crypto** **Tokens, Metaverse -** What‚Äôs behind the buzzwords?

Billions of dollars are pouring into building the¬†**third generation of the Internet**. **Web3**¬†is a combination of [the decentralized, community-governed ethos of web1 (1990-2005) with the advanced, modern functionality of web2 (2005-2020)](https://future.a16z.com/why-web3-matters/). Its vision and promise are **decentralized,¬†[shared ownership and control of online platforms](https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2021/11/08/li-jin-on-the-future-of-the-creator-economy)**¬†by users and builders,¬†[orchestrated with](https://future.a16z.com/why-web3-matters/) **[tokens](https://future.a16z.com/why-web3-matters/)**¬†\[both non-fungible ( [NFTs](https://a16z.com/2021/04/02/nfts-readings-resources/)) and fungible\].

Subscribe

From music to arts, fashion, media, sports, and financing, **business models** and **organizational structures** are being rethought and powered by emerging technologies. Notably, this week, a group of [17,000 crypto enthusiasts,](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/citadel-ceo-ken-griffin-outbids-crypto-group-constitution-copy-rcna6194) identified as¬†[ConstitionDAO](https://www.constitutiondao.com/)¬†\[DAO stands for decentralized autonomous organization, i.e.¬†[online communities owned and operated by their members, via a token](https://every.to/means-of-creation/legitimacy-lost)\], has raised $47M in a bid to buy a rare copy of the US Constitution through crypto crowdfunding. Though they didn‚Äôt win the auction, they set a powerful example, being the [largest crowdfunding initiative (in fiat or crypto) ever](https://www.nbcnews.com/tech/tech-news/citadel-ceo-ken-griffin-outbids-crypto-group-constitution-copy-rcna6194).

**NFTs**, i.e., non-fungible tokens on the blockchain that serve as certificates of authenticity and ownership, are all the rage on the Internet. Artists, celebrities, and even established institutions, like the media powerhouse The Economist or global brands such as Nike, are experimenting with minting and selling NFTs. But they come with¬†[super volatile](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-11-15/nfts-by-celebrities-like-grimes-john-cena-and-a-ap-rocky-fall-in-value)¬†prices and huge ‚Äúgas fees,‚Äù energy usage, and environmental footprint.

[![](https://femwealth.substack.com/p/fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F905329db-f7f3-4095-a607-cbb07c3b29b8_1280x720.jpeg)](https://substackcdn.com/image/fetch/$s_!Luvt!,f_auto,q_auto:good,fl_progressive:steep/https%3A%2F%2Fbucketeer-e05bbc84-baa3-437e-9518-adb32be77984.s3.amazonaws.com%2Fpublic%2Fimages%2F905329db-f7f3-4095-a607-cbb07c3b29b8_1280x720.jpeg) The Economist‚Äôs [Alice in Wonderland-inspired NFT](https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2021/10/26/how-the-auction-of-our-nft-cover-went)

VR/AR games, performances, and e-commerce in the¬†**[‚Äòmetaverse,‚Äô](https://slate.com/technology/2021/11/web3-explained-crypto-nfts-bored-apes.html)** [i.e., three-dimensional spaces in virtual reality where users can interact with one another](https://slate.com/technology/2021/11/web3-explained-crypto-nfts-bored-apes.html), are also on the rise. The recent Facebook rebrand as¬†[Meta](https://www.theverge.com/2021/10/28/22745234/facebook-new-name-meta-metaverse-zuckerberg-rebrand)(to repair its tarnished reputation and mark a new strategic direction) has fueled the metaverse hype.

And let‚Äôs not forget the money! **[DeFi](https://www.coinbase.com/de/learn/crypto-basics/what-is-defi)**(decentralized finance) aims to disrupt the banking and financial systems by providing **peer-to-peer financial services on public blockchains**. There are many projects out there, but not all are legit in the absence of clear regulatory frameworks.

At the heart of **Web3** lays a super active **community** of enthusiasts, early adopters, ‚Äòbelievers‚Äô and proselytes, each trying to **‚Äòown a piece of the Internet.‚Äô** You find them mainly on **Twitter** and **Discord**. Worth exploring if you are a tiny bit curious about Web3. **Spoiler alert:**¬†it‚Äôs quite male-dominated.

**Questions I‚Äôm pondering on:** Will Web3 hold its democratic promise? Will it be genuinely inclusive, or will it perpetuate the problems of Web2? How quickly will blockchain technology be improved to become more efficient and secure? Will the hype continue, or is a bubble burst (just like the dot-com burst of 2000) imminent?

Over the following weeks, I‚Äôll go down the üêáüï≥Ô∏è to find out more and report back in future editions.¬†In the meantime, here are some resources and people to follow:

> **Resources:**
>
> [What Is Web3 and Why Are All the Crypto People Suddenly Talking About It?](https://slate.com/technology/2021/11/web3-explained-crypto-nfts-bored-apes.html)
>
> [Why Web3 Matters \| Future A16Z](https://future.a16z.com/why-web3-matters/)
>
> [How to Win the Future: An Agenda for the Third Generation of the Internet](https://a16z.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/How-to-Win-the-Future-1.pdf)
>
> [Legitimacy Lost. How Creator Platforms Are Eroding Their Most Important Resource](https://every.to/means-of-creation/legitimacy-lost) \| [Li Jin on the future of the creator economy](https://www.economist.com/the-world-ahead/2021/11/08/li-jin-on-the-future-of-the-creator-economy)
>
> [Creator Manifesto \| Index Ventures](https://www.indexventures.com/perspectives/creator-manifesto/)
>
> [Explainer: What are NFTs?](https://www.reuters.com/technology/what-are-nfts-2021-11-17/) \| [Is the future non-fungible?](https://www.economist.com/podcasts/2021/10/27/is-the-future-non-fungible?utm_campaign=finance-newsletter&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=salesforce-marketing-cloud)
>
> [The beguiling promise of decentralised finance. And its many perils](https://www.economist.com/leaders/2021/09/18/the-beguiling-promise-of-decentralised-finance)
>
> [What are DAOs? Here‚Äôs what to know about the ‚Äònext big trend‚Äô in crypto](https://www.cnbc.com/2021/10/25/what-are-daos-what-to-know-about-the-next-big-trend-in-crypto.html)
>
> [BUILDING AN INCLUSIVE WORLD OF CRYPTO](https://www.fwb.help/wip/building-an-inclusive-world-of-crypto)
>
> [FT Crypto Glossary](https://www.ft.com/content/df9f5795-2aaf-4088-a76e-304056db61ef?utm_source=Sifted&utm_campaign=67e17a2557-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2021_11_08_04_04&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_3d44334990-67e17a2557-189323837)
>
> For more check out this comprehensive curation of [Web3 resources](https://airtable.com/shr2LVB4sRYKkrh2q/tbl6VpdOpR2r5DGsU) by [Patricia Mou](https://twitter.com/patriciamou_?s=20)
>
> **Who to follow:**
>
> **Investors:**
>
> [Li Jin](https://twitter.com/ljin18?s=20), Co-Founder at Variant Fund and Founder of Atelier Ventures
>
> [Katie Haun](https://twitter.com/katie_haun?s=20), General Partner at Andreessen Horowitz
>
> [Gaby Goldberg](https://twitter.com/gaby_goldberg?s=20), Web3 investor at [TCG Crypto](https://twitter.com/tcg_crypto) \| **[Gaby's Web3 Reading List](https://www.notion.so/f7050e62461143d49345e7b46eb5576b)**
>
> **Entrepreneurs & Creators:**
>
> [Gina Bianchini](https://mobile.twitter.com/ginab), CEO & Founder Mighty Networks
>
> [Tiffany Zhongg](https://twitter.com/TZhongg?s=20), founder of [Islands](https://twitter.com/IslandsXYZ?s=20) and host of the podcast [probably nothing](https://itsprobablynothing.xyz/s1/2)
>
> [Sari Azout](https://twitter.com/sariazout?s=20), Founder at [Startupy](https://mobile.twitter.com/startupyworld)
>
> **Artists:**
>
> [Emonee LaRussa](https://twitter.com/Em0n33y?s=20), Emmy Award-Winning Motion Graphics Artist
>
> [Nyla Hayes](https://twitter.com/NylaCollection?s=20), 12year old digital artist, TIME mag 1st Artist In Residence, creator of Long Neckie collection \| Discover more artists [here](https://twitter.com/mariarotilu/status/1461804449748471812?s=20)
>
> **DAOs & Web3 Communities:**
>
> [Boss Beauties](https://bossbeauties.com/), a 10k NFT collection and global brand working to make positive change for young women everywhere
>
> [HERSTORY](https://twitter.com/herstorydao) \- an on//offline art collective dedicated to preserving and incubating the stories of marginalized crypto creators
>
> [Komorebi Collective](https://syndicate.io/syndicate/komorebi) \- a DAO that funds women and non-binary crypto founders.

**Disclaimer:**¬†The content is intended only for informational and entertainment purposes and does not constitute investment advice. Please always do your research!

#### Things to Ponder On

[We need to stop gaslighting women about money](https://www.fastcompany.com/90697342/money-is-making-us-sick-as-women-and-as-a-society-heres-a-solution "We need to stop gaslighting women about money")

> _‚ÄúImagine a country in which money is no longer a source of stress, but a source of strength, for women. Imagine a country, then, in which women have more power, stronger voices, improved health, more agency, greater equality‚Äù. -_ [Sallie Krawcheck](https://twitter.com/SallieKrawcheck?s=20)

[THE BAD GUYS ARE WINNING](https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2021/12/the-autocrats-are-winning/620526/?utm_source=newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=atlantic-daily-newsletter&utm_content=20211115&silverid=%25%25RECIPIENT_ID%25%25&utm_term=The%20Atlantic%20Daily)

> _‚ÄúNowadays, autocracies are run not by one bad guy, but by sophisticated networks composed of kleptocratic financial structures, security services (military, police, paramilitary groups, surveillance), and professional propagandists.‚Äù -_ [Anne Applebaum](https://twitter.com/anneapplebaum?s=20)

[The Fight of Meghan Markle‚Äôs Life. The duchess‚Äôs battle with tabloids and trolls is about more than just her right to privacy.](https://www.thecut.com/2021/11/the-fight-of-meghan-markle-life.html?tpcc=nlbroadsheet)

> _‚ÄúThe [culture of abuse cultivated against Black women](https://www.forbes.com/sites/janetwburns/2017/12/27/black-women-are-besieged-on-social-media-and-white-apathy-damns-us-all/?sh=50d55fbf423e) has to be resoundingly rejected. It‚Äôs time we reimagine the world through the eyes of those harmed, and bring about an end to the relentless commodification and exploitation of Black women‚Äôs lives for sport and for profit. To me, Meghan‚Äôs suit represents what so many of us wish we could do: fight back and win.‚Äù -_ [Safiya Umoja Noble](https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__twitter.com_safiyanoble-3Flang-3Deu&d=DwMFaQ&c=7MSjEE-cVgLCRHxk1P5PWg&r=Nax4hrtcZI7PU_Ut8v_KqfqOHmyU5qCB4x3ZiCVq-IY&m=mzvV8QHS8W2vGJlC5kfhmZrRgMnLDC_4j92HgRuW6f4eTO645LiCuGW6qfu95oxb&s=XGQ3TZoYz8CzAraEEQpOHeJEff1Kcx8BY19QweMdjUM&e=), Ph.D.

[‚ÄòYou Are Mommy Tracked to the Billionth Degree‚Äô](https://www.politico.com/news/magazine/2021/11/15/women-remote-work-penalty-solutions-520601?tpcc=nlbroadsheet)\- _‚ÄòWomen are more likely to want to work remotely. But what if it ends up working against them?‚Äô_

[How Misogyny and Religious Bigotry Have Influenced the Historical Portrayal of the Female Experience](https://lithub.com/how-misogyny-and-religious-bigotry-have-influenced-the-historical-portrayal-of-the-female-experience/?utm_source=Sailthru&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=Lit%20Hub%20Daily:%20November%2016%2C%202021&utm_term=lithub_master_list)

> _‚ÄúWhen we can understand how society judged women in the past, we can see how those forces still operate today. If women are written out, century after century, what message does that give the generations that follow?‚Äù -_ **Lucy Jago**

* * *

Thank you for reading FemWealth! ü•∞ Wish you a wonderful week ahead!

Anamaria, Founder & Writer at FemWealth

[Share FemWealth](https://femwealth.substack.com/?utm_source=substack&utm_medium=email&utm_content=share&action=share)

[Skip to content](https://ffdao.notion.site/DAO-Governance-9ed6f1cb053e4157ad64922449c9ac18#main)

![](https://ffdao.notion.site/image/https%3A%2F%2Fs3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com%2Fsecure.notion-static.com%2Fec3dcf37-ef28-4f69-b3c0-ef03693f07b7%2Fbanner_blue.jpg?table=block&id=9ed6f1cb-053e-4157-ad64-922449c9ac18&spaceId=8bdbe86a-1b2f-43a4-b0bb-70695244bbda&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

![üèõÔ∏è Page icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)![üèõÔ∏è Page icon](https://notion-emojis.s3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com/prod/svg-twitter/1f3db-fe0f.svg)

# DAO Governance

![üëã Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

Season 2 Contributor Applications are now open. [Apply](https://79izjwoju7n.typeform.com/FFSeason2)

![üí° Callout icon](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

We‚Äôve launched our governance process for funding Community-Initiated Projects! Learn what‚Äôs involved and how to pitch us [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IIovfed4Uj7Kg4OGoMCpscB1syc4cmXZOvAIqK7kTJc/edit#heading=h.p6l2a285wi29).

## I. Our approach: Vibez Infinity Flow

> Governance (noun): the act or process of governing or overseeing the control and direction of something (such as a country or an organization)

Governance, or DAO Design generally, is understood and realized in many different ways throughout the DAO space. There has been a recent shift, with many DAO operators and contributors realizing the need for more nuance in current conceptions of decentralization, autonomy and hierarchy.

Community is at the center of all that we do at Forefront. This means that our overarching aim is to nurture and enhance human flourishing and human well-being.

To this end, we have crafted an approach to DAO Design & Governance that we call ‚ÄúThe Vibez Infinity Flow.‚Äù DAO Design & Governance that is optimized for vibez, or human flourishing, must be rooted in the reality of human being, human needs and human aspirations.

In the Vibez Infinity Flow model, we have to contend with a Polarity, or a rhythmic movement or dance between two complementary opposites, that, when harmonized, become generative. At the heart of our DAO Design/Governance is the intentional creation of avenues by which these complementary opposites are brought into relationship - so that they may be reconciled and harmonized, again and again, by the human being.

### Org-Level Polarity

At the org-level, the Polarity is between:

Decentralized aspect of the org (that which is emergent, fluid and adaptable)

Centralized aspect of the org or the Long-Term Vision, or North Star (that which is deliberately designed, stable and held steady)

### Individual-Level Polarity

At the individual-level, the Polarity is between:

Autonomy \- the striving of the human being to create and move toward freedom and self-expression, and

Cooperation or Contextual Awareness \- the striving of the human being to belong, to understand and participate in the Whole of which they are a part

Fundamentally, the org-level and individual-level Polarity are the same.

The Vibez Infinity Flow describes the greater vocation or calling of every human being and community.

As individuals \- We are each called to step out, time and again, from the communal matrix and differentiate through autonomous self-expression. So too, time and again, we are called to fall back into the communal matrix to re-integrate with it and feel at home with our fellow human beings.

As a DAO community - The community is composed of numerous sovereign individuals who, time and again, step out and differentiate from the communal matrix through various contributions formed out of their unique insights (‚ÄúI Consciousness‚Äù). To ensure coherence with the Whole, however, this constant movement toward Differentiation must be continually harmonized via a counter-balancing movement toward Integration, ie, Contributors continually re-integrating into community or ‚ÄúWe-Consciousness.‚Äù

![](https://ffdao.notion.site/image/https%3A%2F%2Fs3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com%2Fsecure.notion-static.com%2F88e284cf-aa4d-4292-bc13-7e1f7af06c8a%2FFF01__.jpg?table=block&id=452a550c-adaf-43d3-a350-3019a5b4e045&spaceId=8bdbe86a-1b2f-43a4-b0bb-70695244bbda&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

S2 ‚Äî Vibez Infinity Flow

ALT

### Vibez Infinity Flow In Action

The Forefront DAO realizes the Vibez Infinity Flow using three principal means of Governance:

Forefront Forum (F3);

Decision-Space Mapping; and

OKRs & Reflection Epochs.

#### Forefront Forum (F3)

A bi-weekly live discussion forum convening Core Staff, team Stewards, and all active Contributors. This continually refreshed contextualization ensures that the actions of sovereign individuals and groups cohere with the mission and priorities of the DAO community as a whole.

The overarching objective is three-fold:

Provide opportunity for teams to update the entire DAO on the most significant developments, opportunities and needs in their respective operating environments (contextualized at the ‚Äúforest level‚Äù, vs the trees);

Cultivate culture of open, P2P sharing of info and resources to empower collective learning and context-enriched autonomous action

Core Staff re-syncs the entire DAO, contextualizing the current state of the org against longer-term North Star, near-term priorities and the culture/values that will get us there.

F3 thus facilitates the Vibez Infinity Flow, harmonizing the movements toward Differentiation and Integration. It empowers individual Contributors and small teams with the context they need for impactful autonomous action. At the same time, this continually refreshed contextualization ensures that the actions of sovereign individuals cohere with the mission and priorities of the DAO community as a whole. F3‚Äôs focus on continuous socialized learning and collective sense-making means that we are empowered, as a whole, to experiment, receive vital feedback from each other and our environment and continuously adjust and iterate.

#### Decision-Space Mapping

Decision-Space Mapping explicitly grants specific decision-making authorities and constraints for all core roles (Staff, Leads, Coordinators and team Stewards) and working groups. Just as F3 facilitates the Vibez Infinity Flow, so too, the clarity provided by specifically articulated (yet adaptable) Decision Spaces empower autonomous action and harmonizes it with the DAO‚Äôs North Star.

#### OKRs & Reflection Epochs.

OKRs (aka Objectives & Key Results) & Reflection Epochs are the means by which individual Contributors and discrete working groups achieve coherence with the aims of the DAO as a whole.

The Core Staff sets strategic, DAO-wide annual and Season OKRs.

Working Groups set tactical monthly OKRs that support and roll up into topline OKRs.

Contributors set individual monthly OKRs that support and roll up into their Working Group OKRs.

The Forefront DAO integrates into our production cadence rhythmic periods of rest & reflection. During these Reflection Epochs, the entire DAO is engaged in reflection, evaluating the impact of our activities against our shared commitments and OKRs.

## II. Season 2 Governance Objectives

![](https://ffdao.notion.site/image/https%3A%2F%2Fs3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com%2Fsecure.notion-static.com%2Fef50ecb9-067b-46da-a993-90c879df4de7%2FFF_03.jpg?table=block&id=66ac98fb-b366-469f-ba3f-2032cc06ed20&spaceId=8bdbe86a-1b2f-43a4-b0bb-70695244bbda&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

S2 ‚Äî DAO Design & Governance

ALT

In our approach to DAO Design & Governance, we strive to optimize for the Vibez Infinity Flow, or this harmonizing of complementary opposites.

Guiding principles include:

‚ÄúMaximal trust and delegation‚Äù

This describes the intentional design of space within which individual autonomy can best unfold in service to the Whole, or Community.

‚ÄúMaximal trust and delegation‚Äù points to our conviction that the well-being of the Whole, or the communal interest, can be faithfully served by an individual or any particular locus of activity (a Team). This assumes the all-important presence of coherence with the culture and overarching purpose or guiding intuition of the Whole.

> Trustlessness may be suited to describe blockchain architecture, but trust is the basis of authentic, restorative community. We trust one another. We trust that we each have unique capabilities, and that this is our collective super power.

Thus, we freely distribute/decentralize governance authority and influence to individuals/Teams who are on the ‚Äúfrontline‚Äù and capable of concretely grasping the situation-specific optimum.

We empower Contributors and Teams with as wide a Decision Space as possible, so that they can freely maneuver and innovate. But the necessary corollary of this freedom of movement is an awareness of, and commitment to, the needs of the Whole.

Decision-making agencies with regard to the day-to-day operational & tactical execution of work should always be pushed to the level of the DAO where the information is richest - where perception of the relevant issue is first-hand - direct and immediate.

In other words, contributors "on the frontline" of any given matter know best how to carry out their work. They should be free from unnecessary ‚Äúdecision-making by committee‚Äù.

Working Group Consensus: working groups are empowered to set internal governance processes (as long as they are consistent with our Community Keystone and DAO-wide protocols) and decide and act on matters within their Decision Space, including setting OKRs, with synch‚Äôing from Core Team.

2\. All decisions that relate generally to equity, justice and rights within the DAO community¬† will be stewarded, initially, by the Core Staff and then progressively decentralized to a dedicated, representative governance body akin to a DAO Legislature.

In Season 2, we are exploring the following questions:

How to create a framework that enables progressive decentralization and sustainable growth.

How to foster a fluid and contextualized engagement from all DAO members.

How to encourage an active culture of participation and value creation while incentivizing and retaining high-value DAO members.

How to create a scalable and progressive decentralized governance mechanism to allow the DAO to expand into new exploration territories.

How to craft an evolving process that both 1) integrates space for experimentation and quick action, as well as intentional design and reflection, and 2) creates continual opportunities for learning, feedback and iterative evolution.

## III. DAO Structure

![](https://ffdao.notion.site/image/https%3A%2F%2Fs3-us-west-2.amazonaws.com%2Fsecure.notion-static.com%2Fc26edb26-5759-472c-a51b-6f823de3ce89%2Fllja______(1).jpeg?table=block&id=750b3a15-baf5-4dd1-8f99-7b52b34186fb&spaceId=8bdbe86a-1b2f-43a4-b0bb-70695244bbda&width=2000&userId=&cache=v2)

S2 ‚Äî DAO Design & Governance

ALT

### A. Core Staff

Core Staff set policies and frameworks on general decisions on DAO roadmap, tokenomics, mission and vision.

#### Membership

The Core team is currently appointed as Core Staff. The core staff sets policies for membership and removal.

#### Process

Core Staff‚Äôs mission is to steward the high-level strategic vision of the DAO. Core Staff also stewards core team projects. Members regularly meet to coordinate the DAO‚Äôs North Star vision, roadmap, near-term and longer-term priorities (OKRs), questions of resource allocations and possible community projects and proposals.

All core decisions will be clearly communicated to the wider community. The core team will be accountable and transparent with all core decisions. This process requires an ongoing process of feedback, learning and improvement in all directions. All feedback is used to improve the governance process, which then is communicated to the wider community.

#### Examples

### B. Working Groups

Working groups (teams) are the basic ‚Äúunit‚Äù of the DAO. They have the ability to decide and act on matters in their domains, which their members agree on via an internal voting process.

#### Membership

To join, members have to be onboarded via an onboarding process. Members of the working group receive a monthly base allocation, with bonus potential, discussed in further detail in the Compensation section.

#### Offboarding

Offboarding of Members may occur through violation of our Community Keystone and/or issues related to work-evaluation. The offboarding may be temporary or permanent.

In the event of violations of our Community Keystone, any community member or Contributor may initiate the process of offboarding by submitting a formal write-up. At present, Core Team will steward the evaluation and resolution of all write-ups. In the future, this will be progressively decentralized to a dedicated working group under Community Ops, or a representative governance body akin to a DAO Judiciary. In the future, we are committed to developing a pathway for ‚Äúrestorative reconciliation‚Äù and integrating it into our general offboarding framework.

By officially onboarding as a Contributor to the Forefront DAO, you agree to honor commitments such as team and DAO-wide meetings; using Basecamp, our project management and team communication forum; and regular peer-to-peer and self assessments of work. Continuing membership in the Contributor community is contingent upon honoring these commitments.

#### Structure

In Season 2, Contributors will be onboarded to specific Working Groups with specific needs/roles. Once Contributors are onboarded, the Working Group Steward will synch with Contributors to create roles with specific responsibilities pertaining to Working Group activities.

With synching from Core Staff and stewards, working groups shall set monthly Objectives and Key Results (‚ÄúOKRs‚Äù) specific to their teams to drive progress toward DAO-level Season OKRs. Members meet on a weekly cadence to coordinate workstreams, track progress against OKRs, and determine upcoming week‚Äôs focus.

#### Process

To optimize for Vibez Infinity Flow, working group membership shall generally be capped at 10 members. Any increase above that number usually indicates that the existing group should get more focused and spin out a new working group. Members may make a proposal for a new project/working group.

Generally speaking, all proposals require a minimum of three (3) active contributors as sponsors before the proposal is eligible for governance; this ensures that the new initiative has a sufficient level of existing community support behind it.

Working group Stewards will coordinate workstream delegation and team activities at a high level. Where needed, working groups use consensus governance to make other supporting decisions. In this framework, consent is reached when no members within the working group present a serious objection to a proposal. The consensus should promote mutual trust and respect, constructive feedback, and relationship building.

#### Example

### C. Funding for Working Groups

Forefront Season 2 operations are funded throughout the season by the DAO via a combination of FF and USDC tokens held in the DAO treasury. Season 2 FF allocation is capped at 300,000 $FF for contributors compensation & rewards, and seasonal projects under FF Labs Program.

An additional $70,000 USDC will be be reserved for contributors stables compensation and $50,000 USDC for ecosystem development (whitelisted funding initiatives includes: FF Residency program, FF grants, and public goods)

At the launch of Season 2, Contributors will be onboarded to a select number of highly prioritized working groups. Under our approach for intentional scaling, we will expand and seed additional working groups when existing teams are strongly rooted via culturally and strategically aligned Contributors.

Within the constraints of this intentional, emergent approach to scaling, it may be possible for Contributors to propose new working groups in Season 2. In order to be considered for funding, all proposed projects/working groups should:

Be strongly linked to the mission and OKRs of an existing working group

Have well defined OKRs and budget

Have a minimum of three (3) active Contributors sponsoring the proposal

Projects that do not meet these criteria are considered in the ‚Äúideation‚Äù phase and therefore won‚Äôt qualify for any funding from the DAO. Highly experimental projects can seek funding from other DAO initiatives, such as Community mini-Seed grants, FF Labs‚Äô Open Call, etc.

The core staff and tokenomics group will be responsible to distribute funding to projects and working groups, as well as monitor and provide suggestions to improve the runway and accounting system.

Last updated Feb 25, 2022
